choices.text: Fertilization occurs in the ampulla within 48 hours of ovulation
Zona pellucida surrounding secondary oocyte prevents polyspermy through the zona reaction
Advanced morula (more than 16 cells) enters uterine cavity on day 4

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about fertilization and implantation?
questions.solution:
• Fertilization must occur within 24 hours of ovulation.
  • After that, the secondary oocyte degenerates and cannot be fertilized.
  • So, the phrase "within 48 hours" is incorrect and exceeds the viable fertilization window.

questions.text: Based on the image, identify the microbiological technique
questions.solution:
The technique shown in the image is the streak culture method.

  • The streak plate method is a microbiological technique used to isolate pure cultures of microorganisms, particularly bacteria, from clinical samples.
  • It involves repeatedly streaking a bacterial sample across an agar plate using loop or straight wire (made of platinum or nichrome), diluting the sample in each successive streak, and eventually isolating individual colonies that are likely to arise from a single cell.
  • The goal of streaking is to separate bacteria on the plate so that individual colonies can grow. This allows microbiologist to identify the pathogenic bacteria and further perform the AST.
  • Flaming the inoculating loop is essential for sterilization, which prevents contamination of the agar plate and the sample being transferred. This step is crucial to avoid unwanted microbial growth.

Explanation of Other Options:

Stroke culture method (Option B):

  • In this method, a sterile straight wire is used to gently streak the surface of an agar slant in a zigzag pattern.
  • It is mainly used for biochemical testing (e.g., urease test) and stock culture maintenance, not for isolation of colonies.
  • It is performed on slant tubes, not flat agar plates as shown in the image.

Lawn culture method (Option C):

  • This technique involves evenly spreading a liquid bacterial suspension over the entire surface of an agar plate using a swab or by flooding.
  • It produces uniform growth and is commonly used for antibiotic susceptibility testing (e.g., Kirby-Bauer disc diffusion) or or bacteriophage typing
  • It does not aim to isolate colonies.

Stab culture method (Option D):

  • This technique involves puncturing a semisolid agar medium vertically with a straight, charged wire.
  • It is used to assess motility, oxygen requirements, and to perform tests like the Triple Sugar Iron (TSI) test.
  • Bacteria requiring oxygen grow on the surface, while anaerobic or facultatively anaerobic bacteria grow deeper in the medium.
  • It's also employed for maintaining stock cultures and observing gelatin liquefaction in suitable media.

questions.text: You have measured the femur length to be 40cm from the skeletal remains of an unknown person. What is the approximate height of the individual?
questions.solution:
• The approximate height of the individual is 150 cm.
  • The stature/femur relationship is 3.74. Thus, stature can be calculated by using the formula, stature = femur length x 3.74 = 40 x 3.74 = 149.6 cm = 150 cm
  • The relationship between the mean stature and the mean length of the femur appears to be fairly stable around the world. However, this factor tends to overestimate tall and underestimate short individuals.
  • Femur length shows a highly statistically significant correlation with stature. (r=0.88 in males and r=0.862 in females).
  • This study revealed that an individual's height is approximately four times their femur length. Since femur length is proportional to height, taller individuals tend to have longer femurs, while shorter individuals have shorter femurs.

questions.text:
Which of the following enzymes are involved in the urea cycle?
1. Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (CPS I)
2. Argininase I
3. Argininosuccinate synthetase
4. Ornithine transcarboxylase (OTC)
5. Citrullinase
questions.solution:
The enzymes involved in urea cycle are

  • Carbamoyl-phosphate synthetase I (rate limiting enzyme of urea cycle)
  • Ornithine transcarbamoylase (Not transcarboxylase)
  • Argininosuccinate synthetase
  • Argininosuccinate lyase
  • Arginase I

Citrullinase is not a recognized or functional enzyme in human metabolism.

Note:

  • Arginase I is a liver cytosolic enzyme that converts arginine to urea and ornithine in the urea cycle.
  • Arginase II is a kidney mitochondrial enzyme that regulates arginine for nitric oxide synthesis and is not involved in the urea cycle.

Urea Cycle:

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is true, but R is false
Both A and R are false.

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Clamping of the common carotid arteries just above the carotid sinus leads to reflex tachycardia and increased blood pressure.
Reason (R): This increases the pressure in the carotid sinus and activates baroreceptors, which in turn stimulate the sympathetic nervous system
questions.solution:
• When the common carotid artery is clamped just above the carotid sinus, it causes increased pressure in the carotid sinus.
  • This increased pressure activates the baroreceptors located in the sinus.
  • These baroreceptors send afferent signals to the cardiovascular control centers in the brainstem (medulla oblongata).
  • The brainstem responds by inhibiting the sympathetic nervous system and activating the parasympathetic nervous system. (Reason is false)
  • This leads to reflex bradycardia and vasodilation, resulting in decreased heart rate and blood pressure. (Assertion is also false)

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of bleeding from nose, nasal obstruction, and difficulty in breathing. He gave the history of bathing in the local pool near his house. On examination, a red, nodular, irregularly surfaced lesion studded with whitish dots is seen in the nasal cavity. Based on the history, examination and given histopathological image, what will be the diagnosis of the patient?
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms of nasal bleeding, obstruction, and difficulty breathing, along with a history of bathing in a local pool, is consistent with rhinosporidiosis.

Rhinosporidiosis:


Explanation of Other Options

Rhinoscleroma (Option A):

  • Bacterial disease (Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis)
  • Presents with crusting, woody nasal mass, not red friable polyp with white dots
  • Histology shows Mikulicz cells (Large vacuolated, 'foamy' histiocytes containing Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis)
  • Treatment: Antibiotics like streptomycin, tetracycline, rifampicin and ciprofloxacin along with steroids for 4-6 weeks

Ringertz Tumor (Option C):

  • Inverted papilloma/transitional cell papilloma/Scheiderian papilloma (premalignant: 10-15% may develop into SCC)
  • Associated with HPV
  • M>F
  • Common site: Lateral wall of nose (U/L)
  • Patient presents with U/L nasal obstruction, rhinorrhea, epistaxis
  • Treatment: Medial maxillectomy (TOC) - Done by lateral rhinotomy or sub labial degloving approach.
  • High chance of recurrence

Rhinophyma (Option D):

  • Aka Potato nose - Hypertrophy of sebaceous glands of tip of the nose
  • Seen in advanced cases of acne rosacea
  • Causes nasal skin hypertrophy, not intranasal bleeding mass
  • Common in middle aged men
  • Treatment: Excision by CO2 laser or sharp knife and skin grafting

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of kidney transplant 7 years ago, on cyclosporine, azathioprine, and prednisone, presents with a 3-month history of a 2.5 cm x 3 cm ulcerated, tender lesion on his scalp with irregular borders and occasional bleeding. Which skin cancer is most likely?
questions.solution:
The most likely skin cancer in this patient with a history of kidney transplant and long-term immunosuppression, presenting with an ulcerated, tender scalp lesion with irregular borders and occasional bleeding, is squamous cell carcinoma (SCC).

Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC):

  • Second most common skin tumor on sun-exposed areas in elderly (after basal cell carcinoma).
  • More common in men (except lower leg lesions).
  • Usually detected early and resectable.
  • <5% metastasize; metastasis seen in deeply invasive tumors.
  • Pathogenesis:
    • Main cause: UV light-induced DNA damage.
    • Other risk factors:
      • Chronic immunosuppression (e.g., chemotherapy, transplants).
      • HPV types 5 & 8 (especially in epidermodysplasia verruciformis).
      • Industrial carcinogens: tars, oils.
      • Chronic inflammation: ulcers, osteomyelitis, old burns.
      • Toxins: arsenic ingestion.
      • Radiation exposure.
      • Tobacco & betel nut (oral cavity).
  • Morphology:
    • In situ SCC: Red, scaling, well-defined plaques.
      • Atypical cells with hyperchromatic nuclei throughout the epidermis.
    • Invasive SCC:
      • Nodular, may Ulcerate.
      • Variable keratin production (hyperkeratotic).
      • Well-differentiated: orderly polygonal cells, keratin pearls.
      • Poorly differentiated: anaplastic cells with dyskeratosis; may require keratin immunostains for diagnosis.

Explanation for other options:

Melanoma (Option A) typically presents as an asymmetrical pigmented lesion with irregular borders and color variation. Although transplant patients have a slightly increased risk of melanoma, it is less common than squamous cell carcinoma in this group, and the described ulcerated, tender, bleeding lesion is less characteristic of melanoma.

Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) (Option B) usually presents as a pearly nodule with telangiectasia or a non-healing ulcer with rolled borders. Although BCC is common in transplant patients, it is less aggressive and less likely to appear as a rapidly growing, tender, ulcerated lesion compared to squamous cell carcinoma.

Merkel Cell Carcinoma (Option D) is a rare, aggressive neuroendocrine tumor that typically presents as a rapidly growing, painless, firm, red-violet nodule. The tender, ulcerated nature of the lesion and the patient's immunosuppression make SCC more likely than MCC.

Key Takeaways:

questions.text: A 25-year-old healthy male volunteer received an intravenous infusion of a new drug in a phase 1 clinical trial. It was found that the drug causes an increase in cardiac contractility, a slight increase in heart rate, and no major changes or a decrease in systemic vascular resistance. Which of the following drugs does the new agent most resemble?
questions.solution:
• Dobutamine is a selective β agonist that activates mainly β1 receptors.
  • It is a derivative of DA, but not a D1 or D2 receptor agonist.
  • Dobutamine acts mainly on β adrenergic receptors, and is a weak α agonist.
  • The only prominent action of clinically employed doses (2-8 μg/kg/min i.v. infusion) is increased force of cardiac contraction and output, without significant change in peripheral resistance and BP.
  • Compared to isoprenaline, increase in heart rate is less marked.
  • As such, it is considered to be a relatively selective β1 agonist.
  • Dobutamine is used as an inotropic agent in pump failure accompanying myocardial infarction, cardiac surgery, and for short term management of severe congestive heart failure.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A, C & D: All of these drugs cause substantial changes in heart rate and systemic vascular resistance.

Key takeaway:

  • Dobutamine acts mainly on β adrenergic receptors, and is a weak α agonist. The only prominent action is increased force of cardiac contraction and output, without significant change in peripheral resistance and BP.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with lactic acidosis following a high glucose intake. The enzyme implicated in this metabolic disturbance is Pyruvate Dehydrogenase (PDH). All of the following inhibit Pyruvate Dehydrogenase activity except:
questions.solution:
Pyridoxal phosphate (active form of Vitamin B6) is a cofactor for aminotransferases and other enzymes involved in amino acid metabolism but does not play a role in PDH activity. It neither inhibits nor activates PDH.

Pyruvate Dehydrogenase (PDH) requires five essential cofactors for proper function:

  1. Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) - derived from thiamine (Vitamin B1)
  2. Lipoic acid
  3. Coenzyme A - derived from pantothenic acid
  4. FAD - derived from riboflavin (Vitamin B2)
  5. NAD+ - derived from niacin (Vitamin B3)

Inhibitory factors for PDH include:

  • Mercury and Arsenic inhibit PDH by binding to the -SH groups of lipoic acid, a crucial cofactor of PDH, thereby blocking its function. (Options A & B ruled out)
  • Thiamine deficiency impairs PDH activity because thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) is a necessary cofactor for PDH. Lack of thiamine causes pyruvate accumulation and lactic acidosis. (Option C ruled out)

Clinical relevance:

Patients with inherited PDH deficiency, caused by defects in one or more components of the enzyme complex, often develop lactic acidosis, especially following a glucose-rich meal. Since the brain relies heavily on glucose for energy, these metabolic abnormalities frequently lead to neurological symptoms.

choices.text: Generalised extension of the body is present
Occurs due to coagulation of muscle protein

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement about pugilistic attitude?
questions.solution:
• Pugilistic attitude/heat stiffening is due to coagulation of muscle proteins.
  • It is a condition simulating rigor mortis. It occurs when the body is exposed to temperatures above 65°C like in deaths from burning, high voltage electric shock, or from falling into hot liquid.
  • The mechanism is the coagulation of muscle protein. The flexors, being bulkier than the extensors, contract more and force the limbs into a position of general flexion, the so-called boxer's or pugilistic attitude. It could be due to antemortem or postmortem burns, especially when the body is extensively burnt and charred. Other conditions simulating rigor mortis are - cold stiffening, gas stiffening, cadaveric spasm/cataleptic rigidity.

Pugilistic attitude results from heat-induced coagulation of muscle proteins and can be seen in all forms of burns, including thermal, chemical, and electrical, making careful scene and histologic examination essential in any burn related fatality

questions.text: A patient presents with a lung mass, and the primary tumor site is unknown. Immunohistochemistry (IHC) staining reveals positivity for both CK7 and CK20. Which of the following is the most likely primary tumor site?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient with metastasis showing CK7 and CK20 positivity on immunohistochemistry points towards a diagnosis of urothelial (bladder) carcinoma.

  • Cytokeratins (CKs) are intermediate filaments of the epithelial cytoskeleton.
  • There are 20 subtypes, with CK7 and CK20 being most clinically useful.
  • Combined analysis of CK7 and CK20 is commonly used to assess the origin of metastatic cancers, especially when the primary site is unknown.

CK7 and CK20 Expression Pattern:

Reference:

  1. https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/35390310/
  2. https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11007036/
  3. https://diagnosticpathology.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/1746-1596-7-9

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient who underwent a heart transplant due to heart failure is monitored for cardiac responses during moderate exercise. Compared to normal individuals, which of the following parameters remains unchanged or changes minimally in this patient?
questions.solution:
• In heart transplant recipients, the donor heart is denervated (i.e., autonomic sympathetic and parasympathetic nerves are severed).
  • As a result, heart rate cannot increase significantly during exercise because there is no vagal withdrawal or sympathetic stimulation.
  • Resting heart rate is usually higher (~90-100 bpm) due to loss of vagal tone.
  • Any increase in cardiac output during exercise is achieved mainly through increased stroke volume and intrinsic mechanisms such as the Frank-Starling mechanism. (Options B & D ruled out)
  • Oxygen consumption still increases during exercise because of peripheral adaptations and improved stroke volume. (Option C ruled out)
  • Therefore, unlike normal individuals where heart rate rises sharply with exertion, heart rate remains relatively unchanged or changes minimally in heart transplant patients.

Reference: Exercise after heart transplantation: An overview - PMC.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presented to his physician complaining of dry mouth, constipation, and difficulty in urination. He also noticed an increase in appetite. The man had started therapy with cyproheptadine 2 weeks earlier to treat cold induced urticaria. Drug-induced blockade of which of the following pairs of receptors most likely mediated the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Cyproheptadine is a first-generation H1 antagonist.
  • Like other drugs of this class, it can also block muscarinic and serotonergic receptors (mainly 5-HT2).
  • The blockade of M3 receptors explains the dry mouth, constipation, and dysuria, while the increase in appetite was likely due to blockade of 5-HT2 receptors in the hypothalamus.
  • In fact, cyproheptadine has been used to treat anorexia, with mixed results.

Related important points and concepts:

  • Cyproheptadine
    • It primarily blocks 5-HT2A receptors and has additional
    • H1 antihistaminic
    • Anticholinergic
    • Sedative properties.
  • The anti 5-HT activity of cyproheptadine has been utilized in controlling intestinal manifestations of carcinoid and postgastrectomy dumping syndromes, as well as in antagonizing priapism/orgasmic delay caused by 5-HT uptake inhibitors like fluoxetine and trazodone.
  • Side effects:
    • Drowsiness
    • Dry mouth
    • Confusion
    • Ataxia
    • Weight gain

Key Takeaway

  • Cyproheptadine primarily blocks 5-HT2A receptors and has additional H1 antihistaminic, Anticholinergic and Sedative properties.

questions.text: What is the vertebral extent of the thoracic duct?
questions.solution:
The thoracic duct is the main lymphatic channel of the body. It drains lymph from approximately three-fourths of the body, including:

  • Both lower limbs
  • Pelvis
  • Abdomen
  • Left hemithorax
  • Left upper limb
  • Left side of the head and neck

Only the right upper quadrant is drained by the right lymphatic duct.

ANATOMICAL EXTENT & COURSE OF THORACIC DUCT (VERTEBRAL LANDMARKS)

1. Origin - Cisterna chyli (L1-L2 level):

  • The thoracic duct begins as a continuation of the cisterna chyli, which is a dilated lymphatic sac.
  • It lies anterior to the bodies of L1 and L2 vertebrae.
  • However, the thoracic duct itself officially begins at the lower border of T12.

Clinical Landmark: Cisterna chyli collects lymph from lumbar and intestinal trunks (i.e. lower limbs, pelvis, and intestines).

2. Enters thorax via the aortic hiatus (T12):

  • At the lower border of T12, the duct enters the thorax through the aortic hiatus of the diaphragm.
  • Accompanying structures in the aortic hiatus:
    • Aorta (on the left)
    • Thoracic duct (centrally)
    • Azygos vein (on the right)
  • Mnemonic from the video: "ATA" - Azygos vein, Thoracic duct, Aorta

3. Mid-thoracic Course (T12 to T5):

  • It ascends in the posterior mediastinum, anterior to the vertebral bodies, and between the aorta (left) and azygos vein (right).
  • From T12 to T5, it lies right of the midline.

4. Crosses to left side at T5:

  • At the level of the T5 vertebra, the thoracic duct crosses to the left, behind the esophagus.
  • This is a crucial turning point because its termination is on the left side of the neck.

5. Upper Thoracic and Cervical Course (T5 to C7):

  • The duct continues to ascend on the left side of the esophagus.
  • It reaches the root of the neck, arching laterally and anteriorly behind the carotid sheath.

6. Termination - Venous Angle (C7 level):

  • The duct typically terminates at the junction of the left subclavian and left internal jugular veins, known as the left venous angle, at the level of the C7 vertebra.
  • This junction forms the left brachiocephalic vein, which ultimately drains into the superior vena cava.

SUMMARY OF VERTEBRAL EXTENT:

questions.text: Select the corneal opacity through which details of iris can be seen:
questions.solution:
Corneal opacities are classified based on the depth of stromal involvement and density, which affects how much of the iris can be visualized through the cornea.

The three main types are:

Explanation of Other Options:

Keratoconus (Option A):

  • Keratoconus is a non-inflammatory, progressive disorder characterized by thinning and inferior steepening of the cornea, causing it to assume a conical shape.
  • Although it may lead to scarring in advanced stages, it is not categorized as a type of opacity based on this classification. If it causes scarring, that scarring can become leucomatous in nature, hence not permitting visibility of iris details.

Key Takeaway: Nebular opacity is the only one through which iris details are visible due to its superficial and faint nature.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man was admitted to the emergency department with the chief complaint of an excruciating pain in his left ankle. The pain had started the previous night and increased over several hours. The patient reported that he sprained his ankle 1 week ago. On physical examination, the ankle appeared warm and tender and the entire area was red and swollen. A synovial fluid analysis showed crystals engulfed by phagocytes. A diagnosis was made and pharmacotherapy was prescribed. Which of the following drugs would be most appropriate to treat the patient's pain?
questions.solution:
• The patient's signs and symptoms suggest that he is suffering from an acute gout attack.
  • Although the metatarsophalangeal joint of the great toe is the most common joint affected by gout attack, other joints can be involved.
  • The gout attack can be precipitated by over indulgence in purine-rich foods, alcohol, infection, or minor trauma, as in this case.
  • Systemic treatment of acute gout attacks include oral nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) or colchicine.
  • NSAIDs such as indomethacin are often preferred because of the frequent and sometimes serious adverse effects of colchicine.
  • Glucocorticoids administered intra-articularly after joint aspiration can be an effective and safe treatment for a gout attack.

Related important points and concepts:

  • Indomethacin
    • This indole acetic acid derivative is a potent anti-inflammatory drug with prompt antipyretic action.
    • Indomethacin relieves only inflammatory or tissue injury related pain.
    • It is a highly potent inhibitor of PG synthesis and suppresses neutrophil motility. In toxic doses it uncouples oxidative phosphorylation (like aspirin).
  • Uses of Indomethacin:
    • Because of prominent adverse effects, indomethacin is used as a reserve drug in conditions requiring potent anti-inflammatory action like
      • Ankylosing spondylitis,
      • Acute exacerbations of destructive arthropathies,
      • Psoriatic arthritis
      • Acute gout or rheumatoid arthritis that are not responding to better tolerated NSAIDs.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A: Codeine is a weak opioid analgesic devoid of anti-inflammatory properties and is of no value in gout attack.
  • Option C: Methotrexate and etanercept are effective in rheumatoid arthritis but are of no value in gouty arthritis.
  • Option D: NSAIDs other than indomethacin have been proved effective in the treatment of acute gouty arthritis. When given in small doses, aspirin can inhibit the excretion of uric acid by the kidney, so it should not be used for analgesia in patients with gout.

Key takeaways:

  • Indomethacin relieves only inflammatory or tissue injury related pain.
  • It is a highly potent inhibitor of PG synthesis and suppresses neutrophil motility. In toxic doses it uncouples oxidative phosphorylation (like aspirin).

questions.text: The marked structure opens into which of the following spaces?
questions.solution:
The given image is a sagittal section of the nasal cavity. The arrow is pointing towards the sphenoidal sinus opening, which is located posteriorly and superiorly in the nasal cavity - just above and posterior to the superior concha.

The sphenoidal sinus drains into the sphenoethmoidal recess, which lies:

  • Superior and posterior to the superior nasal concha
  • Anterior to the body of the sphenoid

Explanation of Other Options:

Superior meatus (Option B): Receives drainage from posterior ethmoidal air cells, not the sphenoidal sinus

Middle meatus (Option C): Receives from maxillary sinus, anterior ethmoidal and frontal sinuses (via hiatus semilunaris)

Inferior meatus (Option D): Receives only nasolacrimal duct opening

choices.text: Fibrous tissue replacing normal bone architecture
Bone marrow replacement by neoplastic plasma cells

questions.text: In a patient with fibrous dysplasia, which of the following is the most characteristic histologic finding?
questions.solution:
The most characteristic histologic feature of fibrous dysplasia is fibrous tissue replacing normal bone, with immature woven bone trabeculae embedded in fibroblastic stroma due to a GNAS1 mutation disrupting normal osteoblast differentiation.

Fibrous Dysplasia:

  • Benign tumor due to localized developmental arrest of bone.
  • All bone components are present, but are immature.
  • Caused by somatic gain-of-function mutations in GNAS1, leading to constitutive activation of Gsα protein.
  • Disrupts osteoblast differentiation; mutation timing determines the clinical pattern.
  • Morphology:
    • Intramedullary, lytic lesions cause bone expansion, bowing, and cortical thinning.
    • Gross: Tan-white, gritty tissue.
    • Microscopy:
      • Curvilinear trabeculae of woven bone in fibroblastic stroma.
      • No prominent osteoblastic rimming.
      • May contain cartilage nodules, cystic changes, hemorrhage, and foamy macrophages.
    • No periosteal reaction.

Explanation for other options:

Lamellar bone with collagen-rich matrix (Option A): Lamellar bone represents mature, well-organized bone. In fibrous dysplasia, the hallmark is immature woven bone, not lamellar.

Multiple osteoclasts in the marrow (Option C) is more typical of bone resorptive disorders (e.g., Paget disease, hyperparathyroidism).

Bone marrow replacement by neoplastic plasma cells (Option D) is the defining feature of multiple myeloma, not fibrous dysplasia.

Key Takeaways:

  • Fibrous dysplasia is characterized by fibrous tissue and immature woven bone trabeculae replacing normal bone architecture, embedded in a fibroblastic stroma.
  • This results from a GNAS1 mutation that disrupts normal osteoblast differentiation, leading to abnormal bone formation.

choices.text: Bags should have labels for bio-hazard symbol and cytotoxic hazard symbol.
Labels should be washable and prominently visible.
Triple layered bags should be used for collection of waste from COVID-19 isolation wards.
All of the following are correct.

questions.text: Which one of the following is correct about the bags used for biomedical waste management?
questions.solution:
• The biohazard symbol is mandatory for all infectious waste bags.
  • Additionally the cytotoxic symbol should be added on all bags containing cytotoxic waste (chemotherapy)
  • Bag labels must be non washable, prominently visible and securely attached. (Option B ruled out)
  • COVID-19 isolation waste should be double bagged and labelled "COVID-19 Waste" with secure sealing to prevent any leaks. (Option C ruled out)

Relevant Topics and Concepts:

  • Colour coding and symbols
    • Yellow bag: human anatomical, soiled, chemical, cytotoxic wastes (biohazard + cytotoxic symbols)
    • Red bag: contaminated recyclables (biohazard symbols)
    • White puncture proof container: sharps
    • Blue box: glassware

The lesions in such cases are usually solitary with well circumscribed margins.
Hypopyon, if present, is usually thick and immobile

questions.text: A 34-year-old male farmer presented to casualty with redness, pain, and discharge in the left eye for 1 week. He had a history of trauma to the left eye with a thorn 10 days ago. On examination, the visual acuity in the left eye was 6/60 with circumcorneal congestion. There was a whitish lesion on the cornea which was fluorescein stain positive. Which of the following statements is FALSE about the given condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation-redness, pain, discharge in the left eye following trauma with a thorn, along with a whitish fluorescein-positive corneal lesion and circumcorneal congestion-strongly suggests a fungal corneal ulcer (fungal keratitis).

Lesions are often not solitary and have feathery, ill-defined margins, unlike bacterial ulcers that are more circumscribed.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician because her parents noticed a white reflex in her left eye in family photos taken with a flash. On examination, the right eye is normal. The child has no significant past medical or family history. Fundus examination reveals a retinal mass with a cauliflower-like appearance and areas of calcification. Ocular ultrasound confirms intraocular calcification. What is the most likely chromosome involved in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of leukocoria, retinal mass with a cauliflower-like appearance, and intraocular calcification in a young child strongly suggests retinoblastoma.

  • Retinoblastoma is caused by mutations in the RB1 gene, which is located on chromosome 13 (13q14).
  • M/c inheritance: Autosomal dominant
  • It is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in children.

Clinical Features of Retinoblastoma:

  • Leukocoria (white pupillary reflex): Most common sign
  • Strabismus (commonly esotropia): 2nd M/c sign
  • Other signs: secondary glaucoma with buphthalmos, pseudouveitis, orbital inflammation, proptosis, cataract, retinal detachment

Growth patterns:

  • Endophytic (growing inwards into the vitreous causing seeding)
  • Exophytic (growing outwards causing detachments)
  • Diffuse infiltrating type (rare) - spreads throughout the retina without a discrete mass.

Investigations:

  • Red reflex test: Screening test for leukocoria
  • Ultrasound (B-scan): Detects tumor size and calcifications
  • CT scan (IOC): Detects calcification, extraocular extension, intracranial spread (e.g., pinealoblastoma)
  • MRI: Detects extraocular metastasis
  • Elevated LDH and NSE in aqueous humor
  • Optic nerve biopsy (Gold standard):
    • Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (highly specific)
    • Homer-Wright rosettes (Pseudorosettes)
    • Fleurettes


Related Concept:

Differential diagnosis for leukocoria (mnemonic: France TRIP to C DR):

  • Fungal endophthalmitis
  • Toxocariasis
  • Retinopathy of prematurity (ROP)
  • Inflammatory cyclitic membrane
  • Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV)
  • Congenital cataract, Coat's disease, Coloboma
  • Dysplasia of retina
  • Retinoblastoma

choices.text: It catalyzes the irreversible breakdown of prostaglandins.
It undergoes irreversible inactivation after catalyzing the conversion of arachidonic acid.
It inhibits its own expression through feedback inhibition.
It induces the formation of harmful free radicals during its action.

questions.text: Cyclooxygenase is a suicidal enzyme because of
questions.solution:
Cyclooxygenase (COX), also known as prostaglandin-endoperoxide synthase, catalyzes the conversion of arachidonic acid into prostaglandin H2 (PGH2), a precursor for various prostaglandins, thromboxanes, and prostacyclins involved in inflammation and vascular functions.

COX is termed a "suicide enzyme" because:

  • It becomes irreversibly inactivated, especially by suicide inhibitors like aspirin, which acetylates a serine residue in the active site of the enzyme.
  • This irreversible modification prevents further enzymatic activity, meaning new enzyme must be synthesized for continued function.
  • COX has two isoforms:
    • COX-1: Constitutively expressed; involved in homeostatic functions.
    • COX-2: Inducible during inflammation.

Mechanism of COX Action:

  1. Arachidonic acid is released from the cell membrane by phospholipase A2 (PLA2) and enters the active site of the COX enzyme.
  2. COX catalyzes the cyclization of arachidonic acid using molecular oxygen, forming prostaglandin G2 (PGG2) by inserting two oxygen molecules and creating a hydroperoxide intermediate.
  3. The peroxidase activity of COX then reduces the hydroperoxide group in PGG2 to form prostaglandin H2 (PGH2).
  4. PGH2 serves as a precursor for:
    • Prostaglandins (PGE2, PGF2α) → Role in inflammation, pain, fever
    • Thromboxane A2 → platelet aggregation
    • Prostacyclin (PGI2) → vasodilation, inhibits platelets

COX Inhibition:

  • Aspirin irreversibly inhibits COX by acetylating the enzyme, particularly COX-1.
  • This permanent inactivation renders COX incapable of further catalysis, classifying it as a "suicide enzyme".
  • Other NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen, naproxen) are reversible inhibitors and do not cause permanent inactivation.

Explanation of Other Options:

Option A: COX synthesizes prostaglandins, not breaks them down.

Option C: COX is not inactivated by feedback inhibition but by irreversible modification.

Option D: COX does not primarily function by producing harmful free radicals.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes Laryngeal cancer stage T1bN0M0?
questions.solution:
Laryngeal cancer staging is categorized by:

  • T = Tumor extent
  • N = Lymph node involvement
  • M = Metastasis

Staging of Glottic cancer:

T1bN0M0:

  • T1b: Both cords involved but mobile (NOT fixed)
  • N0: No lymph nodes
  • M0: No metastasis

Key Takeaway:

Vocal cord fixation is never T1. Once fixation occurs, it's T3 or more.

questions.text: All of the following structures are derived from the internal oblique muscle, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Structures derived from the internal oblique muscle:

  • Conjoint tendon
    • It is also known as falx inguinalis.
    • It is formed by the fusion of lower aponeurotic fibres of internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles.
  • Cremasteric muscle
    • Lower arched fibres of internal oblique muscle
  • Rectus sheath
    • Aponeurotic fibres of external oblique, internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles
  • Cremasteric fascia
    • Fibres of internal oblique muscle

Key Points:

questions.text: An 85-year-old farmer is diagnosed with Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (CJD). What method is effective for destroying its causative agent?
questions.solution:
Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease is caused by prions—abnormal, pathogenic proteins that are notoriously resistant to standard sterilization procedures. Common methods like autoclaving at typical temperatures (121°C for 15 minutes) or chemical disinfectants such as 5% formalin are insufficient to inactivate prions. (Option B ruled out)

Effective prion decontamination requires:

  • Autoclaving at 134°C for 1 to 1.5 hours (higher temperature and longer duration than standard autoclaving) (Option A ruled out)
  • Treatment with 1 N Sodium Hydroxide (NaOH) for at least 1 hour
  • Treatment with5% Sodium Hypochlorite (bleach) for at least 2 hours (Option D ruled out)

These aggressive conditions are necessary because prions are extremely resistant to heat and chemical agents. When prions adhere to stainless steel surfaces (e.g., surgical instruments), pre-treatment with acidic detergents improves inactivation efficiency before autoclaving.

Therefore, among the options given, Sodium hydroxide for 1 hour is the most effective method to destroy the prion agent causing Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.

questions.text: A 63-year old woman complained to her physician of recurrent wheezing that caused frequent nocturnal awakening. She also noted that wheezing occurred when she was anxious and tense. The woman had been suffering from allergic rhinitis for 4 years and from atrial fibrillation for 1 year. A diagnosis of mild allergic asthma was made. Which of the following drug treatments would be most appropriate for relief of her bronchospasm?
questions.solution:
• Accepted guidelines for the treatment of asthma indicate a short-acting β2 agonist as needed in all patients. In this case, however, the patient's atrial fibrillation contraindicates the use of β2 agonists.
  • In general, when drugs are given by inhalation, only 10 to 20% of the dose can reach the target site of action (lower airways); the rest is swallowed and can be absorbed by the intestine, causing systemic effects.
  • Ipratropium is an effective bronchodilator agent, and the swallowed dose is not absorbed by the intestine (the drug is a quaternary ammonium compound).
  • The nocturnal awakening indicates that the bronchospasm is triggered by a prevalence of the parasympathetic system (which is predominant during the night), so an antimuscarinic drug is appropriate.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A: Oral glucocorticoids are not bronchodilators and cannot be used for relief of bronchospasm.
  • Option B: Oral sustained-release theophylline is an effective bronchodilator, but it has the potential to cause more adverse effects, may interfere with sleep, and is less effective than ipratropium.
  • Option D: Inhaled salmeterol is a long-acting β2-agonist helpful for maintenance but contraindicated for acute relief in a patient with atrial fibrillation.

Key takeaway

  • Ipratropium is an effective inhaled bronchodilator agent, and the swallowed dose is not absorbed by the intestine (the drug is a quaternary ammonium compound). It can be used in conditions when short-acting β2 agonists are contraindicated.

choices.text: The mother is physically present but fails to provide care.
Permanent loss of maternal care. (eg: death)

questions.text: What do you mean by maternal deprivation syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Maternal deprivation syndrome refers to a condition that occurs when a child is separated for a prolonged period from the primary caregiver (usually the mother), particularly in the first five years of life, which are crucial for emotional and psychological development.
  • Early maternal loss increases the risk of failure to thrive, behavioural disorders and attachment disorders.
  • Clinical Features of Maternal Deprivation Syndrome:
    • Delayed physical growth (failure to thrive)
    • Emotional detachment, depression, or anxiety
    • Social withdrawal or aggression
    • Cognitive delay and learning difficulties
    • Feeding and sleep disturbances

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A: This scenario describes emotional neglect, not maternal deprivation as classically defined.
  • Option C: Short-term separation with adequate substitute care does not cause deprivation syndrome
  • Option D: Incorrect as (B) is correct

questions.text: To combat parasitic worm infections, government of India has declared 2 fixed days under school health programme under Ayushman Bharat programme as days to provide albendazole tablets for deworming school age children. Which are those days?
questions.solution:
• Under the National Deworming Day (NDD) initiative, 400 mg chewable Albendazole is administered twice a year:
    • 10th February - 1st round
    • 10th August - 2nd round
  • Target group: Preschool and school-aged children (1-19 years)
  • Administered in schools and anganwadi centers
  • Part of the School Health Component of Ayushman Bharat Programme.

questions.text: Minimum inhibitory concentration can be calculated by all of the following antibiotic sensitivity methods except:
questions.solution:
Discussion:

Minimum Inhibitory Concentration (MIC) is defined as the lowest concentration of an antimicrobial agent that will inhibit the visible growth of a microorganism after overnight incubation. MIC is crucial for determining the appropriate antibiotic dosage, particularly in serious infections where precise drug levels are necessary for efficacy.

Disk diffusion method is the only method among the given options that does not allow direct calculation of MIC.

  • While the disk diffusion method (such as the Kirby-Bauer test) gives a qualitative result-susceptible, intermediate, or resistant-based on the zone of inhibition, it does not yield an exact MIC value.
  • Instead, the zone diameter is compared with standardized interpretive charts from CLSI or EUCAST to categorize susceptibility.
  • The test involves placing antibiotic-impregnated paper disks on an agar plate inoculated with the test organism.
  • The antibiotic diffuses into the medium, and the diameter of the clear zone indicates effectiveness. However, since no gradient or serial dilution of the antibiotic is present, an exact MIC cannot be measured.

Explanation of Other Options:

Epsilometer test (E-test) (Option A):

  • It provides a quantitative measurement of MIC. It combines both diffusion and dilution principles using a plastic strip impregnated with a predefined gradient of antibiotic concentrations.
  • When placed on an agar plate inoculated with a lawn of the test organism, an elliptical zone of inhibition forms. The MIC is read at the point where the lower edge of the ellipse intersects the scale on the strip.

Agar dilution method (Option B):

  • It involves incorporating serial dilutions of antibiotics directly into agar plates, and spot inoculating each plate with a defined concentration of the test organism.
  • After incubation, the lowest drug concentration plate showing no visible growth is recorded as the MIC. This method allows testing of multiple strains simultaneously on the same plate.

Broth dilution method (Option D):

  • This method, performed in tubes (macro) or microtiter plates (micro), is a direct and standardized method for determining MIC.
  • Serial two-fold dilutions of the antimicrobial agent are made in broth, each inoculated with a standard concentration of the test organism.
  • After incubation, the tube or well that appears clear (no turbidity) represents the MIC.
  • This method also allows determination of minimum bactericidal concentration (MBC) by subculturing from clear tubes onto antibiotic-free agar.

Related Concept:

Minimum Bactericidal Concentration (MBC) is the lowest concentration of an antimicrobial agent required to kill a specific bacterium, typically defined as a 99.9% reduction in the original bacterial inoculum. It's determined by subculturing samples from broth dilution MIC tests onto antibiotic-free agar plates to observe bacterial regrowth.

questions.text: In radial nerve injury at the axilla, interphalangeal extension is still possible due to action of which of the following muscles inserted on dorsal digital expansion
questions.solution:
Radial Nerve Injury at Axilla:

When the radial nerve is damaged in the axilla, all muscles supplied by it are affected:

  • Triceps → Loss of elbow extension
  • Extensor carpi radialis/ulnaris → Loss of wrist extension → "Wrist drop"
  • Extensor digitorum → Loss of MCP extension

Interphalangeal (IP) extension is spared.

Role of the Extensor Hood / Dorsal Digital Expansion

Structure:

  • The dorsal digital expansion receives lumbrical and interosseous fibers, forming a web-like structure.
  • Central slip → Inserts on base of middle phalanx
  • Two lateral slips → Unite and insert on base of distal phalanx
  • These bands extend the PIP and DIP joints, even when extensor digitorum is nonfunctional.
  • Receives fibers from:
    • Extensor digitorum (radial nerve)
    • Lumbricals (median and ulnar nerves)
    • Dorsal and palmar interossei (ulnar nerve)

Actions:

  • Extensor digitorum → Extends MCP joints (lost in radial nerve palsy)
  • Lumbricals & interossei → Flex MCP and extend PIP/DIP (preserved)

Integration:

  • Radial nerve palsy at axilla → paralysis of all extensors
  • MCP extension lost, but IP extension preserved; lumbricals and interossei (not supplied by radial nerve) insert on the dorsal digital expansion and perform IP extension.
  • These muscles are innervated by median and ulnar nerves, which are intact in radial nerve injury.

Radial nerve- Course:

choices.text: When 2 or more vegetarian foods are eaten together their proteins supplement one another and provide a protein comparable to animal protein.
An example is dal rice combination.
It is the basis of counseling people to eat a mixed diet.

questions.text: It is possible for a vegetarian to obtain a high-grade protein by supplementary action of protein. Which of the following statements about supplementary action of protein are correct?
questions.solution:
• Protein complementation occurs when cereals (low in lysine, high in sulfur amino acids) and pulses (high in lysine, low in sulfur amino acids) are consumed together, yielding a balanced amino acid profile equivalent to animal protein.
  • This principle underlies dietary counseling to consume mixed diets of cereals, pulses, and vegetables to ensure high-grade protein intake at low cost.
  • Vegetarian diets can achieve complete protein quality through strategic food combinations.

questions.text: Dietary fibre is recommended to decrease problems of coronary heart disease by its action of binding to bile salts and prevention of resorption of bile salts, decreasing cholesterol. What is the recommended daily allowance for dietary fibres?
questions.solution:
• Aim for 30 g of dietary fiber per 2000 kcal daily to help prevent coronary heart disease
  • Soluble fiber (e.g., oats, barley, psyllium, pectin) is most effective at lowering LDL cholesterol
  • Insoluble fiber (e.g., wheat bran, vegetables) promotes regularity and colorectal health
  • 60 gm/2000 kcal exceeds practical dietary targets and may hinder micronutrient absorption.

questions.text:
Calculate the amount of cholesterol in low-density lipoproteins (LDL) in an individual whose fasting blood lipid panel shows:
1. Total cholesterol = 254 mg/dL
2. HDL cholesterol = 40 mg/dL
3.Triglycerides = 120 mg/dL
questions.solution:
The total cholesterol in fasting blood is the sum of cholesterol carried by LDL, HDL, and very-low-density lipoproteins (VLDL):

Total Cholesterol = LDL cholesterol + HDL cholesterol +VLDL cholesterol

VLDL cholesterol can be estimated by dividing triglycerides by 5 because cholesterol comprises approximately one-fifth of VLDL's mass in fasting conditions:

VLDL = 120/5 = 24

Rearranging to solve for LDL cholesterol:

LDL = Total cholesterol − HDL − VLDL

LDL = 254 - 40 - 24 = 190 mg/dL

questions.text: A male with chronic alcoholism and cirrhosis of the liver presents with low sexual desire, poor sexual functioning, and normal-sized testicles. Which one of the following best explains these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Chronic alcoholism and liver cirrhosis impair hepatic protein synthesis, including the production of sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG), a β-globulin that binds testosterone with high affinity. SHBG is essential for transporting testosterone (a lipophilic steroid hormone) in the bloodstream.

  • Low SHBG levels due to liver dysfunction result in decreased transport and bioavailability of testosterone, despite normal testicular production (as suggested by normal testicle size).
  • This reduced circulating testosterone leads to symptoms of hypogonadism, such as decreased libido and poor sexual performance.
  • Albumin (another liver-produced protein) also contributes to hormone transport, and hypoalbuminemia from protein malnutrition in chronic alcoholics further exacerbates the deficiency in hormone carriage.

Explanation of Other Options:

Increased MEOS (Option A): While MEOS (microsomal ethanol oxidizing system) is upregulated in chronic alcohol use to metabolize ethanol, it does not directly impact testosterone levels or SHBG production.

Decreased MEOS (Option B): Not typically seen in chronic alcoholism; also irrelevant to testosterone transport.

Normal thyroid hormone (Option C): Thyroid function is unrelated to testosterone transport or SHBG synthesis in this context.

Related Concept:

questions.text: A 44 year old man who has been receiving his first course of chemotherapy for a non-Hodgkin lymphoma still complains of recurrent nausea and vomiting despite antiemetic medication with ondansetron, dexamethasone and aprepitant. Which of the following drugs would be appropriate to add to the patient's antiemetic regimen at this time?
questions.solution:
• Dronabinol is a Δ 9-tetrahydrocannabinol (THC), the most active cannabinoid from cannabis.
  • Its mechanism of antiemetic action is still uncertain, but the drug likely activates specific cannabinoid receptors in the vomiting center.
  • Because of the availability of more effective agents, dronabinol is uncommonly used in patients receiving cancer chemotherapy, but can be a useful addition when other antiemetic medications are not effective, as in this case.
  • Its antiemetic action can be supplemented by dexamethasone.
  • Dronabinol is an appetite stimulant as well. It has been used in lower doses to improve feeding in cachectic/AIDS patients.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A & B: These drugs are devoid of antiemetic properties.
  • Option D: It would be illogical to add a glucocorticoid drug when dexamethasone was not effective.

Key takeaway

  • Dronabinol can be used as an alternative antiemetic for moderately emetogenic chemotherapy in patients who cannot tolerate other antiemetics or are unresponsive to them.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with scaling skin patches that have developed over the past month. Physical examination reveals 1-3 cm light pink plaques with silvery scales on her arms and torso, and a punch biopsy of a lesion shows retention of keratinocyte nuclei in the stratum corneum under microscopy. Which of the following terms most accurately describes this microscopic finding?
questions.solution:
The presence of nucleated keratinocytes in the stratum corneum is characteristic of parakeratosis, which occurs due to accelerated skin turnover as seen in psoriasis.

Nomenclature of Microscopic Skin Lesions:

Key Takeaways:

Parakeratosis = Psoriasis + Persistent Nuclei in the Cornified Layer

questions.text: Which of the following acts as a chemoattractant?
questions.solution:
C3a and C5a act as chemoattractants that recruit immune cells (like neutrophils and macrophages) to the site of infection.

The complement system is a crucial part of the immune response that combats pathogens through inflammation, opsonization, and direct cell lysis. Activation of complement proteins produces several by-products with specific roles:

  1. Chemoattractants (C3a and C5a):
    • Both are small peptides known as anaphylatoxins. They play dual roles by:
      1. Inducing anaphylaxis through mast cell degranulation, which increases vascular permeability and promotes inflammation.
      2. Acting as chemoattractants, guiding immune cells like neutrophils and macrophages to sites of infection or immune complex deposition. This chemotaxis is crucial for mounting an effective immune response. Therefore, C3a and C5a are key mediators of inflammatory recruitment.
  2. Opsonins (C3b and C4b):
    • C3b and C4b act as opsonins by binding covalently to the surface of pathogens or immune complexes. (Option B ruled out)
    • This tagging enhances phagocytosis by macrophages and neutrophils via complement receptors.
    • Opsonization facilitates efficient clearance of microbes and immune complexes.
  3. Membrane Attack Complex (C5b-C9):
    • Components C5b, C6, C7, C8, and C9 assemble to form the Membrane Attack Complex (MAC), which creates pores in target cell membranes, causing complement-dependent cytolysis. (Options C & D ruled out)
  4. Other complement fragments:
    • C2b acts similarly to kinins, increasing vascular permeability, but does not function as a chemoattractant.

Key Takeaway:

Complement By-products & Functions:

  • C3a, C5a: Chemoattractants, trigger inflammation
  • C3b, C4b: Opsonins, enhance phagocytosis
  • C5b-C9: MAC, causes cell lysis

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are TRUE regarding deep peroneal nerve injury
1. It leads to loss of dorsiflexion of the foot, causing foot drop
2. Sensory loss is seen over the dorsum of the foot, including all toes
3. Eversion of the foot is largely preserved in isolated deep peroneal nerve injury
4. Extensor digitorum brevis is paralyzed in deep peroneal nerve injury
questions.solution:
1. "It leads to loss of dorsiflexion of the foot, causing foot drop" - TRUE
    • Deep peroneal nerve supplies:
      • Tibialis anterior (main dorsiflexor)
      • Extensor hallucis longus
      • Extensor digitorum longus
      • Peroneus tertius
      • Injury → paralysis of dorsiflexors → foot drop (inability to clear toes during swing phase of gait)
  2. "Sensory loss is seen over the dorsum of the foot, including all toes" - FALSE
    • Deep peroneal nerve supplies only a small sensory area:
      • The first interdigital cleft (skin between 1st and 2nd toes)
      • The rest of the dorsum is supplied by the superficial peroneal nerve
  3. "Eversion of the foot is largely preserved in isolated deep peroneal nerve injury" - TRUE
    • Eversion is performed by:
      • Peroneus longus and brevis → supplied by the superficial peroneal nerve
      • Since only the deep peroneal nerve is injured, superficial peroneal nerve and its muscles remain intact → eversion is preserved
  4. "Extensor digitorum brevis is paralyzed in deep peroneal nerve injury" - TRUE
    • Extensor digitorum brevis is innervated by the lateral terminal branch of the deep peroneal nerve in the foot

Clinical Note:

In isolated deep peroneal nerve injury, the hallmark signs are:

  • Foot drop (due to dorsiflexor paralysis)
  • Sensory loss in 1st interdigital cleft
  • Preserved eversion
  • Weak toe extension due to extensor hallucis longus & digitorum paralysis

choices.text: Dorsal columns of the spinal cord

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with progressive difficulty in walking, along with numbness and tingling in both feet. Neurological examination reveals impaired joint position sense in the lower limbs. A 128 Hz tuning fork applied to the medial malleolus elicits a diminished response. Romberg sign is positive. Which of the following neural pathways is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms of impaired proprioception, reduced vibration sense, and positive Romberg sign (impaired proprioception) point to dysfunction of the dorsal columns of the spinal cord.

  • The dorsal column-medial lemniscus pathway is responsible for transmitting fine touch, conscious proprioception, two-point discrimination, and vibratory sensation (pallesthesia) from the periphery to the primary sensory cortex via the dorsal columns of the spinal cord and medial lemniscus of the brainstem.
  • Common conditions affecting the dorsal columns include vitamin B12 deficiency (subacute combined degeneration), tabes dorsalis, and diabetic neuropathy.

Explanation of Other Options:

Anterolateral spinothalamic tract (Option A): Carries pain and temperature sensation, as well as crude touch. Lesions cause loss of pain and temperature sense, but joint position and vibration sense are preserved.

Corticospinal tract (Option C): Responsible for voluntary motor control (especially fine movements). Lesions cause motor weakness, spasticity, and hyperreflexia but does not affect vibration or proprioception.

Spinocerebellar tract (Option D): Transmits unconscious proprioception to the cerebellum for coordination and balance. It does not mediate conscious perception like two-point discrimination, vibration, or stereognosis. Lesion causes causes ataxia, gait disturbances, and coordination issues, not sensory loss.

Key Takeaway:

choices.text: Glycogenesis of adipose tissue glycogen stores

questions.text: A patient with frequent sweating and tremors is diagnosed with "reactive hypoglycemia" and has been prescribed a small meal every 4 hours throughout the day. The patient most likely is impaired in carrying out which one of the following?
questions.solution:
• Reactive hypoglycemia is a condition characterized by a drop in blood glucose levels within a few hours after a meal.
  • Normally, the body compensates for this decrease by releasing glucose from its stores through glycogenolysis (breakdown of glycogen into glucose) and gluconeogenesis (synthesis of glucose from non-carbohydrate sources)
  • In patients with reactive hypoglycemia, these compensatory mechanisms, especially glycogenolysis in the liver, are impaired. This results in an insufficient release of glucose from liver glycogen stores when blood glucose levels fall, leading to symptoms such as sweating, tremors, and other signs of hypoglycemia.

Explanation of Other Options:

Glycogenesis of liver glycogen stores (Option A): Glycogenesis is the process of storing glucose as glycogen in the liver and muscles. In reactive hypoglycemia, the problem lies in the inability to release glucose from glycogen stores, not in storing it. Therefore, hepatic glycogenesis is unlikely to be impaired.

Glycogenolysis of muscle glycogen stores (Option B): Muscle glycogen is broken down locally within muscle cells for energy and does not contribute to blood glucose levels because muscle cells lack glucose-6-phosphatase, the enzyme required to convert glucose-6-phosphate into free glucose for release into the bloodstream.

Glycogenesis of adipose tissue glycogen stores (Option D): Adipose tissue stores fat (as triglycerides), not glycogen, and plays no significant role in blood glucose regulation.

questions.text: Which of the following health problems has been eliminated from India, according to a recent update from WHO?
questions.solution:
• In October 2024, the World Health Organization validated India as having eliminated trachoma as a public health problem, following years of implementing the SAFE strategy and national control programs.
  • SAFE strategy: Surgery for trichiasis, Antibiotics (azithromycin), Facial cleanliness, Environmental improvements.
  • Eliminating trachoma does not imply zero cases, but that prevalence of active trachoma and trichiasis falls below WHO-defined thresholds
  • Glaucoma and pterygium are still prevalent. (Options B & D ruled out)
  • Malaria is targeted for elimination by 2030, but India has not yet achieved this goal. (Option C ruled out)

Reference: Elimination of trachoma as a public health problem in India. WHO News Release, 8 October 2024

choices.text: The well should be located not less than 15 metre from likely sources of contamination.
The lining should be carried 100cm above the ground level.
The top of the well should not be covered by a cement concrete cover.
No user will have to carry water for more than 500 metres.

questions.text: A sanitary well is one which is properly located, well-constructed and protected against contamination. Which of the following points should be taken into consideration while constructing sanitary well?
questions.solution:
A sanitary well must be:

  • At least 15 meters away from potential sources of contamination (e.g. latrines, drains).
  • Lined above ground level by 60-90 cm, not 100 cm. (Option B ruled out)
  • Covered at the top with a cement concrete slab to prevent contaminants from entering. (Option C ruled out)
  • Accessibility (distance to user) is important for convenience, but not a defining structural criterion of a sanitary well. (Option D ruled out)
  • Lining of the well should be built of bricks or stones set in cement up to a depth of at least 6 metres.
  • There should be a parapet wall up to a height of at least 70-75 cm above the ground.
  • There should be a cement concrete platform round the well extending at least 1 metre in all directions.
  • There should be a pucca drain to carry off spilled water to a public drain or a soakage pit.
  • The well should be equipped with a hand-pump for lifting the water in a sanitary manner.

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution:
• Puppe's rule: Helps in determining the sequence of bullets hit the skull, when there are multiple bullet injuries to skull. The fracture line resulting from the later bullet will typically stop at the previously formed one.
  • Kennedy's phenomenon: Surgical intervention of a firearm wound leading to an artefact as the evaluation of wound as entry or exit wound and the range of firing etc., become difficult.
  • Rayalaseema phenomenon: Here a person is killed by stab injury and a bullet is implanted inside to mislead the investigation.
  • Ewing's postulates: Establishes a relationship between trauma and new growth.

questions.text: A 42 year old man recently diagnosed with generalized anxiety disorder had started a treatment with sertraline, but the drug caused some sexual dysfunction, and the psychiatrist decided to switch to a short course of alprazolam. Which of the following molecular actions on neuronal membranes most likely mediated the therapeutic effect of alprazolam in the patient's disorder?
questions.solution:
• Benzodiazepines bind to receptors located at the interface between α and γ subunits of the GABAA receptor−chloride ion channel macromolecular complex.
  • The binding increases the affinity of the GABAA receptor for GABA, which in turn causes an increased frequency of chloride channel opening.
  • This in turn will increase the negative charges inside the cell, causing hyperpolarization of the cell membrane.
  • Benzodiazepines act preferentially on midbrain ascending reticular formation (which maintains wakefulness) and on limbic system (thought and mental functions).
  • It is noteworthy that the BZDs do not themselves increase Cl¯ conductance; have only GABA facilitatory but no GABA mimetic action.

Explanation of other options:

  • "Option A, C & D": Benzodiazepines do not affect these currents. Moreover, all of these actions would cause depolarization, not hyperpolarization, of cell membranes.

Key takeaway:

  • BZDs act by enhancing presynaptic/postsynaptic inhibition through a specific BZD receptor which is an integral part of the GABAA receptor-Cl¯ channel complex.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used for the reversal of muscle relaxation caused by vecuronium?
questions.solution:
• Sugammadex is a novel reversing agent developed for terminating the action of nondepolarizing muscle relaxants rocuronium and vecuronium.
  • It is a modified γ-cyclodextrin with high affinity for rocuronium and vecuronium.
  • It encapsulates one molecule of the blocker within its molecule forming an inactive chelate which is excreted in urine with a t½ of ~ 2 hours.
  • As the plasma concentration of free rocuronium falls, it rapidly dissociates from the Nm receptor and neuromuscular transmission is restored.
  • Thus, the mechanism of reversal by sugammadex is entirely different from that of the currently used reversing agents neostigmine and edrophonium.
  • Its side effects are mild precordial pain, nausea, alteration of taste and rarely allergy.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A: Physostigmine is a tertiary amine cholinesterase inhibitor with central effects; not used for neuromuscular block reversal.
  • Option B: Rivastigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor used in Alzheimer's disease; no role in NMBA reversal.
  • Option D: Galantamine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor for dementia; not indicated for reversing neuromuscular blockade.

Key takeaway:

  • Sugammadex is the agent of choice for rapid, specific reversal of vecuronium- and rocuronium-induced block without cholinergic adverse effects.

questions.text:
Regarding the cutaneous innervation of the external acoustic meatus and canal, which of the following statements are correct?
1. The anterior wall and roof of the external acoustic meatus are supplied by the auriculotemporal nerve
2. The posterior wall and floor are innervated exclusively by the glossopharyngeal nerve
3. The auricular branch of the vagus nerve supplies the posterior and inferior canal
4. The facial nerve may contribute via its communication with the auricular branch of the vagus nerve
questions.solution:
Statement 1: Anterior wall and roof are supplied by the auriculotemporal nerve: TRUE

  • The auriculotemporal nerve (branch of mandibular nerve, V3) provides:
    • Sensory innervation to the anterior wall, roof, and part of the external ear and anterior canal.

Statement 2: Posterior wall and floor are innervated exclusively by the glossopharyngeal nerve: FALSE

  • The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) supplies the middle ear cavity and tympanic membrane (internal surface), not the external acoustic meatus.
  • The posterior wall and floor of the external canal are mainly supplied by the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (Arnold's nerve).

Statement 3: Auricular branch of the vagus supplies the posterior and inferior canal: TRUE

  • The auricular branch of the vagus nerve (Arnold's nerve) enters the mastoid canaliculus, joins the facial canal, and supplies:
    • Posterior wall, floor of EAM
    • External surface of the tympanic membrane
  • Clinical correlation: Stimulating this nerve can cause coughing or gagging - "ear-cough reflex."

Statement 4: Facial nerve may contribute via communication with the auricular branch of the vagus

TRUE

  • The facial nerve (CN VII) has communicating branches with the auricular branch of the vagus, supplying part of the external acoustic meatus.
  • This contribution is variable, but documented in anatomic studies and in Gray's.

Clinical Relevance:

  • Arnold's reflex (ear-cough reflex): Stimulation of the vagus nerve in the EAM can cause coughing or gagging.
  • Otalgia (ear pain) can be referred pain from vagus or mandibular nerve distribution.

choices.text: Increased gamma neuron activity increases spindle sensitivity to stretch
Gamma motor neurons directly cause muscle contraction by innervating extrafusal muscle fibers.
Gamma motor neurons inhibit alpha motor neurons to reduce muscle tone.
Gamma motor neurons are primarily responsible for initiating voluntary movements.

questions.text: A 43-year-old office worker visits the clinic complaining of difficulty maintaining posture and poor coordination during fine motor tasks. Neurological examination reveals decreased muscle tone and impaired stretch reflexes. Further testing suggests reduced activity of gamma motor neurons. Which of the following best explains the role of gamma motor neurons in this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Gamma motor neurons innervate the intrafusal fibers of muscle spindles (not extrafusal fibers).
  • They play a key role in maintaining muscle tone and posture by:
    • Keeping the muscle spindle taut, even when the muscle is relaxed
    • Increasing the sensitivity of the spindle to stretch
    • Facilitating proper stretch reflexes through enhanced feedback to alpha motor neurons
  • Reduced gamma activity leads to hypotonia and diminished stretch reflexes, as seen in this patient.

Explanation of Other Options:

Option B: Alpha motor neurons (not gamma) innervate extrafusal fibers responsible for voluntary and reflexive contractions.

Option C: Gamma motor neurons do not inhibit alpha motor neurons. Instead, they enhance the sensitivity of muscle spindles, indirectly supporting alpha motor neuron activity.

Option D: Voluntary movements are initiated by upper motor neurons (from the cortex) activating alpha motor neurons, not by gamma motor neurons.

Related Concept:

questions.text: A 40-year-old man has a vital capacity (VC) of 4.8 L, a tidal volume (VT) of 0.6 L, an inspiratory capacity (IC) of 3.2 L, and a functional residual capacity (FRC) of 2.8 L. What is his expiratory reserve volume (ERV)?
questions.solution:
Vital capacity (VC) = Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV) + Tidal volume (TV) + Expiratory reserve volume (ERV)

Given:

  • VC = 4.8 L
  • TV = 0.6 L
  • Inspiratory capacity (IC) = 3.2 L
    • IC = IRV + TV
    • 2 = IRV + 0.6
    • IRV = 3.2 - 0.6 = 2.6 L

Substitute IRV in VC equation:

VC = IRV + TV + ERV

4.8 = 2.6 + 0.6 + ERV

4.8 = 3.2 + ERV

ERV = 4.8 - 3.2 = 1.6 L

questions.text: Zones of adrenal cortex (Column A) are matched with their characteristic features or secretions (Column B). Which of the following is the CORRECT match
questions.solution:
1. Zona glomerulosa → C. Produces aldosterone under control of the renin-angiotensin system: Correct

  • Function: Secretes mineralocorticoids (primarily aldosterone)
  • Regulation: Controlled by the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS), not ACTH
  • Location: Outer layer of adrenal cortex

"The zona glomerulosa secretes aldosterone, regulated primarily by angiotensin II and serum potassium levels."

2. Zona fasciculata → A. Contains spongiocytic cells, secretes cortisol: Correct

  • Function: Secretes glucocorticoids (primarily cortisol)
  • Histology: Contains spongiocytes-cells with lipid-rich vacuoles giving a "foamy" appearance
  • Regulation: ACTH from pituitary

3. Zona reticularis → B. Secretes androgens, acidophilic cytoplasm: Correct

  • Function: Produces androgens like dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) and androstenedione
  • Histology: Contains acidophilic cells with compact cytoplasm and more lipofuscin
  • Regulation: Weakly by ACTH

4. Medulla → D. Derived from neural crest, secretes catecholamines: Correct

  • Origin: Derived from neural crest cells (same as sympathetic ganglia)
  • Function: Secretes catecholamines-epinephrine and norepinephrine
  • Histology: Chromaffin cells stain brown with chromate salts due to stored catecholamines

questions.text: A 33-year-old man presents to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. He complains of severe chest pain and difficulty breathing. Examination reveals decreased breath sounds, tenderness over the lower rib cage and significantly reduced tidal volume. Which of the following muscles is least likely to be affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Inspiration is an active process involving:
    • Diaphragm (main muscle)
    • External intercostal muscles (elevate ribs)
    • Accessory muscles like
      • Scalene muscles (elevate the first and second ribs)
      • Sternocleidomastoid muscle (rises the sternum).
  • Internal intercostal muscles, on the other hand, are primarily involved in forced expiration, not inspiration.
  • Since the patient has a significantly reduced tidal volume, impairment likely involves the inspiratory muscles (diaphragm, external intercostals, scalenes). (Options A, B & D ruled out)
  • Therefore, the internal intercostal muscle, being non-essential for inspiration, is least likely affected in this scenario.

Related concept:

Muscles of active expiration:

  • Internal intercostal muscles
  • Subcostal muscles
  • Abdominal muscles
    • Rectus abdominis muscles
    • External and internal oblique muscles
    • Transversus abdominis muscles

choices.text: Facial nucleus, medial lemniscus, medial longitudinal fasciculus; occlusion of basilar artery
Facial nucleus, spinal trigeminal tract, vestibular nuclei, middle cerebellar peduncle; occlusion of anterior inferior cerebellar artery
Nucleus ambiguus, inferior cerebellar peduncle, sympathetic fibers; occlusion of posterior inferior cerebellar artery
Hypoglossal nucleus, corticospinal tract, medial lemniscus; occlusion of anterior spinal artery

questions.text:
A 62-year-old hypertensive male presents with sudden-onset vertigo, nausea, left-sided facial weakness, dry eye, and decreased lacrimation. He also reports hearing loss and unsteady gait. Neurological examination reveals:
1.Ipsilateral facial paralysis with loss of corneal reflex
2.Ipsilateral sensorineural hearing loss
3.Ipsilateral limb ataxia
4.Contralateral loss of pain and temperature over the body
5.Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature over the face
Which of the following combinations best describes the structures involved and the most likely vascular territory affected?
questions.solution:
• Ipsilateral facial paralysis + loss of corneal reflex → CN VII involvement
  • Ipsilateral sensorineural hearing loss → CN VIII involvement
  • Ipsilateral limb ataxia → Cerebellar peduncle involvement
  • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature over the body → Spinothalamic tract
  • Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature over face → Spinal nucleus and tract of CN V
  • Vertigo, nausea → Vestibular nuclei involvement

These signs localize the lesion to the lateral caudal pons, affecting structures supplied by the Anterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (AICA).

Structures involved:

All the signs can be explained by an infarct in the AICA territory, which supplies:

  • Lateral inferior pons
  • Middle cerebellar peduncle
  • Facial and vestibulocochlear nerves/nuclei
  • Spinal trigeminal nucleus
  • Spinothalamic tract (lateral medulla/pontine continuation)

Other options:

A. Facial nucleus, medial lemniscus, MLF; basilar artery occlusion

  • Would expect contralateral weakness and vibration loss - not seen in this case
  • Involves medial pons → but no corticospinal or medial lemniscus signs here

C. Nucleus ambiguus, inferior cerebellar peduncle, sympathetic fibers; PICA occlusion

It causes Lateral Medullary Syndrome (Wallenberg):

  • Nucleus ambiguus not involved here → hence not medulla
  • But no hoarseness/dysphagia (CN IX/X)

D. Hypoglossal nucleus, corticospinal tract, medial lemniscus; anterior spinal artery

  • Medial medullary syndrome
  • Contralateral hemiparesis, tongue deviation, vibration loss would be seen- not matching this case

choices.text: HbF contains δ chains that enhance oxygen transport
HbF has a decreased oxygen-binding capacity compared to HbA
HbF binds 2,3-diphosphoglycerate (2,3-DPG) more tightly than HbA.
HbF contains γ chains instead of β chains, which reduces its binding to 2,3-DPG.

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant woman visits her obstetrician for a routine checkup. The physician explains that fetal hemoglobin (HbF) in her baby has a higher oxygen affinity compared to her adult hemoglobin (HbA). This facilitates oxygen transfer from the mother to the fetus. What is the primary reason for the increased oxygen affinity of HbF?
questions.solution:
Fetal hemoglobin (HbF) is composed of two alpha and two gamma chains (α2γ2), in contrast to adult hemoglobin (HbA), which consists of two alpha and two beta chains (α2β2).

  • The γ chains in HbF bind 2,3-diphosphoglycerate (2,3-DPG) less effectively than the β chains in HbA. (Option C ruled out)
  • 2,3-DPG decreases hemoglobin's oxygen affinity by stabilizing the deoxygenated (T) form of hemoglobin.
  • Since HbF has reduced binding to 2,3-DPG, it remains in the oxygenated (R) state more readily, leading to higher oxygen affinity. This adaptation allows the fetus to effectively extract oxygen from maternal blood via the placenta.

Explanation of Other Options:

Option A: δ chains are found in HbA2 (α2δ2), a minor adult hemoglobin, not in HbF.

Option B: HbF does not have a decreased oxygen-binding capacity; in fact, it has a similar or slightly higher capacity than HbA.

choices.text: They are indicative of a malignant tumor
They are indicative of a benign tumor
They are diagnostic of a Leydig cell tumor
They have no significance in the diagnosis or prognosis of the tumor

questions.text: A 50-year-old man undergoes orchiectomy for a testicular mass, and histopathological examination identifies a Leydig cell tumor with characteristic Reinke crystalloids. Which of the following statements most accurately describes the significance of Reinke's crystalloids in this case?
questions.solution:
Reinke crystalloids are rod-shaped cytoplasmic inclusions found in about 25% of Leydig cell tumors. They are pathognomonic (gold standard) for diagnosing Leydig cell tumors. Their presence confirms the diagnosis but does not indicate malignancy or benign behavior.

Leydig Cell Tumors:

  • Often produce androgens, and sometimes estrogens and corticosteroids.
  • Occur in children or adults.
  • Most common presentation is testicular swelling.
  • In children, sexual precocity caused by hormone effects is a dominant feature.
  • Associated conditions include:
    • Klinefelter syndrome
    • Cryptorchidism
    • Hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell carcinoma syndrome
  • About 10% of adult Leydig cell tumors are malignant and can metastasize.
  • Morphology:
    • Gross appearance: circumscribed nodules, usually less than 5 cm.
    • Cut surface is golden brown and homogeneous.
    • Histology:
      • Tumor cells resemble normal Leydig cells.
      • Cells are large, with round or polygonal
      • Abundant granular eosinophilic cytoplasm.
      • Central round nucleus.
      • Cytoplasm may contain lipid droplets, vacuoles, or lipofuscin pigment.
      • Presence of rod-shaped Reinke crystalloids in about 25% of tumors.
    • Reinke crystals are pathognomonic and considered the gold standard for diagnosing Leydig cell tumors.

Key Takeaways:

  • Reinke crystalloids are pathognomonic (gold standard) for diagnosing Leydig cell tumors.
  • Their presence confirms the diagnosis but does not indicate malignancy or benign behavior.

Reference:

  1. https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/andr.13201

questions.text: The pedigree below depicts a hereditary disorder. Based on the pattern shown, which of the following conditions is most likely?
questions.solution:
The pedigree's pattern of affected males and unaffected females indicates an X-linked recessive inheritance, which is characteristic of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome.

X-linked Recessive Disorders:

Explanation of other options:

Wilson's disease (Option B) is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, so it affects males and females equally and does not show the characteristic X-linked pattern.

Alport syndrome (Option C) is inherited mostly in an X-linked dominant manner, so it affects both males and females but with different severity

Achondroplasia (Option D) is inherited in an autosomal dominant way, showing vertical transmission across generations and no sex bias.

Key Takeaways:

X-linked Recessive Disorders:
