questions.text: According to new guidelines from NMC every MBBS student has to adopt 3 families in the community. You being a MBBS student have adopted families. One of the families you visited doesn't have proper ventilation. All of the following are criteria for proper ventilation except?
questions.solution:
• Living rooms require only 2-3 air changes per hour to maintain comfort and air quality; 4-5 changes is excessive.
  • 50-100 sq. ft per person provides adequate personal space and ventilation volume.(Option B ruled out)
  • Higher air-change rates required in spaces with heavy occupancy or activity. (Option C ruled out)
  • Cubic air space: Minimum 1000 cu. ft. per person in sleeping rooms, but fresh air requirements can go up to 3000 cu. ft. per hour per person for good ventilation. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text:
Teachers often face failure to communicate with students due to certain barriers of communication. Of the following, what all can be barriers of communication?
i. Difficulties in hearing and expression.
ii. Emotional disturbances.
iii. Neurosis
iv. Noise
v. Literacy
vi. High level of knowledge and understanding
vii. Congestion
questions.solution:
Barriers of communication can be:

  • Physical: Like noise and congestion
  • Physiological: Such as hearing and speech difficulties
  • Psychological: Emotional disturbances and neurosis

In this question:

  • Option (i) - Difficulties in hearing and expression → Barrier
  • Option (ii) - Emotional disturbances → Barrier
  • Option (iii) - Neurosis → Barrier
  • Option (iv) - Noise → Barrier
  • Option (v) - Literacy → Not a direct communication barrier.
  • Option (vi) - High knowledge → Not a barrier; can be helpful if simplified.
  • Option (vii) - Congestion → Barrier

Hence, the correct answer is (D) i, ii, iii, iv, vii.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman visits a crowded subway during flu season. She inhales airborne influenza viruses, which infect her respiratory epithelial cells. The virus causes a decrease in MHC class I molecule expression on the surface of these infected cells. Which immune cell type is most likely to quickly recognize and kill these infected cells?
questions.solution:
Natural killer (NK) cells are most likely to kill the infected respiratory epithelial cells because they recognize and target cells with reduced MHC class I expression, a hallmark of many viral infections like influenza.

Natural Killer (NK) Cells:

  • Function: NK cells destroy stressed, virus-infected, or tumor cells.
  • Proportion: They constitute about 5-10% of peripheral blood lymphocytes.
  • Surface Marker: Express CD16, which binds IgG Fc regions, enabling antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC).
  • Activation/Inhibition:
    • Activating receptors recognize stress-induced molecules (e.g., due to infection, DNA damage).
    • Inhibitory receptors recognize self-class I MHC molecules on healthy cells to prevent inappropriate killing.
    • In infected or tumor cells, class I MHC is often downregulated while activating ligands are upregulated, tipping the balance toward killing.
  • Cytokine Secretion: NK cells secrete interferon-gamma (IFN-γ), which activates macrophages to kill ingested microbes.
  • Cytokine Regulation:
    • IL-2 and IL-15: Stimulate NK cell proliferation.
    • IL-12: Stimulates NK cell cytotoxic activity and IFN-γ secretion.
  • Role: Provide early innate immune defense, especially against intracellular infections and tumors.

Explanation of other options:

CD4+ cells (Option A) are helper T cells that require antigen presentation via MHC class II, which is typically found on antigen-presenting cells, not infected epithelial cells. They coordinate immune responses but do not directly kill infected cells.

Dendritic cells (Option B) are antigen-presenting cells that process and present viral antigens to T cells to initiate adaptive immunity. They do not have a primary role in directly recognizing or killing virally infected epithelial cells.

Macrophages (Option C) engulf pathogens and infected cells but are not specialized for detecting cells with reduced MHC class I expression; their role is more in phagocytosis and antigen presentation.

Key Takeaways:

  • Natural killer (NK) cells provide early defense by destroying virus-infected cells that have reduced MHC class I

questions.text: A 39-year-old man, a resident in a psychiatric unit because of disorganized schizophrenia, presented with profound lack of motivation, remarkably blunted affect, paucity of speech and psychomotor retardation. He had been hospitalized three times since his diagnosis, and had been treated with haloperidol, chlorpromazine, and risperidone but had only a partial response to each medication. Which of the following psychotropic drugs would be most appropriate to try at this stage?
questions.solution:
• The poor response to several neuroleptic drugs and the prevalence of negative symptoms of schizophrenia indicate that the patient is a candidate for clozapine therapy.
  • Clozapine is the neuroleptic approved for the treatment of resistant schizophrenia.
  • Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic drug having weak D2 blocking action. It mainly acts by blocking 5-HT2, an adrenergics and D4 receptors.It suppresses both positive as well as negative symptoms (First FDA approved drug for antisuicide indication) of schizophrenia. Clozapine is the most effective drug in refractory schizophrenia, i.e. patients not responding to typical neuroleptics may respond to it.
  • It is used only as a reserve drug due to the risk of precipitation of seizures(even in non-epileptics) and agranulocytosis.
  • The most common adverse effect of clozapine is sedation.
  • Risk of extrapyramidal symptoms is least with the use of this drug.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A & B: Because the response to previous therapy was inadequate, It is not useful to try other neuroleptics with activity spectra similar to that of chlorpromazine (i.e., thioridazine) or haloperidol (i.e., uphenazine).
  • Option C: Fluoxetine is not effective in treating schizophrenia.

Key takeaway:

  • Clozapine is the most effective drug in refractory schizophrenia, i.e. patients not responding to typical neuroleptics may respond to it.

choices.text: Preformed mediators including histamine, serotonin, and heparin released from mast cells
Lipid-derived mediators such as prostaglandin D2 and leukotriene C4
Eosinophil chemotactic factor released during mast cell degranulation
C-reactive protein synthesized in response to IL-6 following mast cell activation

questions.text: A 35-year-old farmer develops sudden shortness of breath, low blood pressure, and wheezing after a bee sting. He is diagnosed with anaphylaxis (a type I hypersensitivity reaction). Which of the following is NOT directly involved in causing this reaction?
questions.solution:
C-reactive protein (CRP) is an acute-phase reactant produced by the liver in response to interleukin-6 (IL-6) during systemic inflammation. It functions as a marker of inflammation and does not act as a direct mediator in hypersensitivity or anaphylaxis reactions. Therefore, CRP has no direct role in the pathogenesis of anaphylaxis.

Anaphylaxis is a life-threatening Type I hypersensitivity reaction characterized by rapid systemic release of mediators from mast cells and basophils, typically triggered by allergens like insect stings, drugs, or foods.

These mediators are classified into:

Primary (Preformed) Mediators

  • Histamine: Released from mast cells, basophils, and platelets; causes vasodilation, increased vascular permeability (edema), itching, and bronchoconstriction.
  • Serotonin: Found in platelets; causes vasoconstriction, increased permeability, and smooth muscle contraction.
  • Heparin: Acts as an anticoagulant. (Option A ruled out)
  • Eosinophil & Neutrophil Chemotactic Factors: Attract eosinophils and neutrophils to the site of inflammation. (Option C ruled out)
  • Proteases & Hydrolases: Cause tissue degradation and amplify inflammation.

Secondary (Newly Synthesized) Mediators:

  • Leukotrienes (LTC4, LTD4, LTE4): Cause sustained bronchoconstriction and increased vascular permeability.
  • Prostaglandins (PGD2, PGF2α): Promote vasodilation, bronchoconstriction, platelet aggregation, and pain sensitization. (Option B ruled out)
  • Thromboxane A2: Induces bronchoconstriction and platelet aggregation.
  • Platelet Activating Factor (PAF): Causes platelet aggregation, bronchoconstriction, and increased permeability.
  • Cytokines (e.g., IL-1, TNF-α): Mediate late-phase inflammation.

Other Mediators Involved in Anaphylaxis:

  • Anaphylatoxins (C3a, C5a): Produced during complement activation; Cause mast cell degranulation, chemotaxis, and increased vascular permeability.
  • Bradykinin and Other Kinins: Formed from plasma kininogens via activation of the kinin system; Contribute to vasodilation, pain, and increased permeability.

choices.text: Lungs are likely to show multiple thin-walled cavitatory lesions
Might often be associated with recurrent URTI
Associated with perforation in both cartilaginous and bony nasal septum

questions.text: A patient presents with recurrent nosebleeds, nasal crusting, and external nasal deformity (see image below). Biopsy from the nasal lesion reveals necrotizing granulomatous inflammation. Otoscopy is performed (shown in the image). Which of the following statements regarding the patient's condition is incorrect ?
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation- recurrent nosebleeds, nasal crusting, external nasal deformity (saddle nose), otitis media on otoscopy, and necrotizing granulomatous inflammation on biopsy - strongly suggests Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA), formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis. GPA shows c-ANCA positivity most commonly (not p-ANCA).

GPA is an autoimmune necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis affecting small- to medium-sized vessels.

ENT Manifestations (Most commonly at disease onset):

  • Sino-nasal involvement in ~89%:
    • Chronic sinusitis not responding to standard therapy (M/c initial symptom).
    • Bloody nasal discharge, crusting, and nasal obstruction.
    • Saddle nose deformity from septal cartilage and bony destruction.
    • Septal perforation (commonly posterior).
    • Granulation tissue, mucosal ulceration, friability, crusting seen on nasal endoscopy.
  • Oral cavity: Strawberry gingivitis (purplish hyperplastic gingiva), loose teeth.
  • Ear involvement:
    • Otitis media (due to Eustachian tube dysfunction)
    • Hearing loss (conductive, sensorineural, or mixed).
    • Facial nerve palsy due to vasculitis of the neural vasa vasorum.
  • Laryngeal involvement: Subglottic stenosis (10-20% of cases), leading to stridor or dyspnea.

Other system involvement:

  • Lung: Nodules with or without cavitation.
  • Kidney: Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis.

Investigations:

  • Nasal endoscopy: Mucosal crusting, ulceration, granulation.
  • Biopsy: Necrotizing granulomatous inflammation with vasculitis and necrosis
  • Urinalysis: Hematuria and/or significant proteinuria
  • ANCA testing:
    • c-ANCA (PR3-ANCA) is positive in 70% of systemic GPA.
    • Less sensitive in localized (ENT-limited) disease (~60% positive).

Treatment: Systemic steroids and Immunosuppressants (methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, rituximab, azathioprine).

Key Takeaway:

Pointers for Wegener's granulomatosis:

  • Granulomatous inflammation on biopsy
  • PR3 ANCA or C-ANCA staining
  • Nasal sinus inflammation
  • Subglottic, tracheal, or endobronchial stenosis
  • Abnormal chest x ray or CT
  • Abnormal urinalysis

Reference:

(PDF) ENT manifestations of Granulomatosis with polyangiitis

choices.text: Mostly occurs in thin built individuals
Autopsy shows food lodged in the larynx only
Death is due to respiratory arrest
Death is often is due to parasympathetic overactivity

questions.text: A 56-year-old man collapsed suddenly during dinner with his friends. They brought him to the ER but he was already dead. On asking further history, they revealed that they were drinking before having food. There were no signs of asphyxia, but on autopsy, a bolus of food lodging in the larynx was found. Which of the following statements about this syndrome is true?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is most likely suggestive of cafe coronary syndrome. Death in cafe coronary syndrome occurs due to parasympathetic overactivity. It is sudden and unexpected and happens rapidly.

'CAFE CORONARY SYNDROME':

  • A popular term 'cafe coronary' was coined by Dr. Roger Haugen, Medical Examiner of Broward County, Florida for such impaction of food in the respiratory passage.
  • The victim may be observed slumping over the dining table or collapsing suddenly while walking across the room after having meals, with no signs of respiratory distressor any of the 'classic signs of asphyxia'.
  • The original series of deaths involved well-nourished businessmen dying suddenly and unexpectedly in restaurants and cafes, while sitting or shortly after sitting in their chairs, as if they died of heart attack. Hence, the name 'cafe coronary'.
  • However, autopsy usually reveals a bolus of food in the pharynx or larynx.Many cases have been reported where the victim was merely seen dead while sitting or just after sitting in a chair, the mode of death probably being cardiac arrest due to overactivity of parasympathetic nervous system through the stimulation of branches of vagus nerve supplying the laryngeal and/or pharyngeal mucosa.
  • Fairly high level of alcoholhas been found in most cases of cafe coronary deaths. The suppression of gag reflex due to alcohol or drugs makes the individual susceptible to this calamity.
  • Senile persons in retirement homes and mentally retarded children in institutions are also vulnerable.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman with a BMI of 22 undergoes testing that reveals a fasting plasma glucose level of 130 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows mild glucosuria without ketonuria or proteinuria. She tests negative for insulin autoantibodies. Her father had similar findings starting at age 20. She is most likely to have a mutation in a gene encoding which of the following?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a young woman with mild hyperglycemia, absence of autoantibodies, no ketonuria, a normal BMI, and an affected first-degree relative points toward Maturity-Onset Diabetes of the Young (MODY), most commonly caused by a glucokinase (GCK) gene mutation.

Maturity-Onset Diabetes of the Young (MODY):

  • MODY is a form of monogenic diabetes due to primary defects in ß-cell function.
  • It resembles type 2 diabetes clinically but occurs in younger patients.
  • Caused by germline loss-of-function mutations in one of six genes.
  • The most common mutation is in the glucokinase (GCK) gene.
    • Glucokinase acts as a rate-limiting enzyme in oxidative glucose metabolism.
    • This glucose metabolism is coupled to insulin secretion in pancreatic ß-cells.

Key Takeaways:

  • MODY is a young-onset monogenic diabetes caused by mutations in genes affecting beta-cell function, most commonly glucokinase, which regulates glucose sensing and insulin secretion.

questions.text: Which of the following is the 'least common' complication of measles?
questions.solution:
• Diarrhea, pneumonia, and otitis media are common complications of measles, especially in children under 5. (Option A,B,C ruled out)
  • SSPE (Subacute Sclerosing Pan Encephalitis) is a rare complication of measles (1 per 100,000 cases), typically occurring years after the initial infection.

Relevant Important points and concepts:

  • Measles
    • Incubation Period: 10-14 days; rash around day 14
    • Causative agent: RNA paramyxovirus
    • Seasonality and endemicity: Peak incidence January-April in India
    • Period of Communicability: 4 days before and 5 days after the appearance of rash
    • Routine immunization: MCV1 at 9 months; MCV2 at 15-18 months (minimum interval 4 weeks); aim ≥ 95% coverage
    • Vitamin A prophylaxis: 100 000 IU for infants 6-11 months and 200 000 IU for children ≥ 12 months at diagnosis and next day to reduce mortality
    • Surveillance: Case-based reporting with laboratory confirmation (IgM/RT-PCR) to monitor elimination targets

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a major clinical type of diphtheria?
questions.solution:
• Diphtheria is classified by the primary site of membrane formation:
    • Faucial diphtheria: affects tonsil and pharynx
    • Laryngeal diphtheria: causes airway obstruction and hoarseness.
    • Anterior nasal diphtheria: more common in infants and young children, with serosanguinous nasal discharge
  • Intestinal diphtheria is not recognized as a major clinical type. It is not included in standard classifications used by WHO or IAP guidelines.

questions.text: Degradation of Complex Macromolecule occurs in
questions.solution:
Lysosomes are membrane-bound organelles containing hydrolytic enzymes that degrade complex macromolecules such as proteins, nucleic acids, lipids, and carbohydrates. These enzymes work optimally at acidic pH.

Explanation of Other Options:

Cytosol (Option A): Mainly involved in metabolic pathways (like glycolysis and glycogenolysis) and protein degradation through proteasomes, which degrade individual proteins tagged with ubiquitin, but not bulk degradation of macromolecules.

Ribosome (Option B): Responsible for protein synthesis (translation), not degradation.

Mitochondria (Option C): Primarily involved in energy production (TCA cycle, oxidative phosphorylation), β-oxidation of fatty acids, and some mitochondrial protein turnover but not general degradation of complex macromolecules.

Related Important Concepts:

Lysosomes - The Cell - NCBI Bookshelf.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male marathon runner collapses during a race on a hot, humid day. On arrival at the emergency department, he is unconscious, his skin is hot and dry to the touch, and his body temperature is 41°C (105.8°F). His pulse is rapid and thready, and his blood pressure is low. Bystanders report he had been running continuously for over 2 hours without adequate hydration. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Heat stroke occurs when the body is exposed to high temperature with high humidity
  • The term 'thermic fever' or 'sun stroke' is used when there has been direct exposure to the sun

Treatment:

  • Remove the patient to a cooler environment
  • Remove the clothes
  • Reduce the body temperature by ice water sponging
  • Monitor heart rate and respiratory rate
  • V. diazepam in case of convulsion
  • I.V. fluids and electrolytes

It is a traction diverticulum occurring between the sternocleidomastoid and mylohyoid muscles

It is a traction diverticulum occurring between the cricopharyngeus and thyropharyngeus muscles

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with complaints of progressive dysphagia, halitosis, and occasional regurgitation of undigested food, especially hours after eating. He also notes a gurgling sound in his throat and occasional coughing during meals. A barium swallow study is performed. Based on the clinical history and radiologic findings, which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the condition depicted?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is typical of Zenker's diverticulum, a pulsion (false) diverticulum caused by mucosal herniation through Killian's dehiscence-a weak spot between the cricopharyngeus and thyropharyngeus muscles.

Note:

Killian's Dehiscence: Triangular area in the pharyngeal wall between the thyropharyngeal and cricopharyngeal muscles.

Laimer's Dehiscence: Triangular area between the circular fibers of the cricopharyngeus and the longitudinal fibers of the esophagus.

Related concept:

questions.text: While doing an autopsy on a victim of strangulation, you are examining his brain. Which of the following areas of the brain is the most likely to show evidence of hypoxic damage in this victim?
questions.solution:
• From the given options, the hippocampus is most likely to show evidence of damage in the case of a hypoxic brain injury like strangulation. However, third and fourth cortical layers are best for displaying the histological changes of hypoxia.
  • The parts of the brain most suitable for seeking evidence of hypoxic damage are:
    • Hippocampus (especially CA1 sector = Sommer's area and subiculum)
    • Cerebellar folia
    • Globus pallidus in the basal ganglia
    • Boundary zones of the cerebral cortex where the grey matter is most vulnerable because it lies at the terminal reaches of the arterial supply (for example, parasagittally at the middle frontal gyrus where the watershed between middle and anterior cerebral arteries lies). The third and fourth cortical layers are best for displaying the histological changes of hypoxia.

questions.text:
Which of the following are features of superior semicircular canal dehiscence (SSCD)?
1.Positive Romberg's sign
2.Positive Tullio phenomenon
3.Positive Hennebert's sign
4.Oscillopsia
5.Positive Dix-Hallpike manoeuvre
questions.solution:
Superior semicircular canal dehiscence (SSCD) is a rare condition where the bone between the superior semicircular canal and middle cranial fossa is thin or absent, forming a "third mobile window" in the inner ear.

Pathophysiology:

The dehiscent canal acts as a third mobile window, altering pressure transmission in the inner ear.

Sound or pressure causes abnormal endolymph movement → stimulates vestibular receptors → vertigo and auditory symptoms.

Clinical Features:

  1. Vestibular Symptoms:
    • Tullio phenomenon: Vertigo induced by loud sounds.
    • Hennebert's sign: Vertigo induced by pressure changes (e.g. tragal compression).
    • Oscillopsia: Visual field appears to oscillate with head movement due to disturbed vestibulo-ocular reflex.
    • Vertigo worsens with intracranial pressure changes (e.g. Valsalva, jugular compression).
  2. Cochlear Symptoms:
    • Low-frequency conductive hearing loss
    • Autophonia: Exaggerated perception of own voice, footsteps, etc.
    • Increased bone-conducted sound sensitivity
    • Preserved stapedial reflex (differentiates from ossicular pathology)

Diagnosis: Confirmed by HRCT of temporal bone.

Treatment:

  • Conservative: Avoid triggering stimuli (loud noise, pressure).
  • Surgical repair if symptoms persist

Explanation of Incorrect Statements:

Romberg's and Dix-Hallpike signs are not features of SSCD. (Statements 1 and 2 ruled out)

  • Positive Romberg's sign reflects proprioceptive or posterior column dysfunction.
  • Dix-Hallpike manoeuvre is classic for diagnosing Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV), where brief vertigo and nystagmus are triggered by positional changes due to otolith displacement.

Key Takeaway:

Presence of conductive hearing loss + preserved stapedius reflex → strongly suggests SSCD.

questions.text: A pedestrian hit by a car hurls up on the windshield following which his head strikes the road. How is the head injury described?
questions.solution:
• In this case, a pedestrian hit by a car (Primary impact injury) hurls up on the windshield (Secondary impact injury) following which his head strikes the road (Secondary injury).
  • Injuries to pedestrians:
    • Primary impact injuriesare the injuries sustained by a pedestrian by the initial impact with the vehicle. (Option A ruled out)
    • Secondary impact injuries are the injuries sustained by a pedestrian by falling over the vehicle. (Option B ruled out)
    • Secondary injuriesare the injuries sustained by a pedestrian by falling over the ground after being hit by the vehicle.
  • Common driver vs. passenger injuries in vehicle impacts:
    • Drivers:
      • Windshield glass injury from striking or ejection through the windshield
      • Whiplash injury from rapid deceleration, often cervical hyperextension-flexion
      • Seat-belt injuries (e.g., "belt sign," sternal fractures, mesenteric tears)
  • Passengers:
    • Tailgating injuries in rear-end collisions leading to neck injury and low-back trauma
    • Side-impact intrusions causing chest and pelvic fractures
    • Windshield contact if unrestrained or during rollovers

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents with burning pain and tingling in his hands and feet, worsened by heat. He also reports decreased sweating and has characteristic skin lesions on his lower trunk (as shown in the image). Eye exam reveals lenticular corneal opacities. Laboratory tests show proteinuria and declining renal function. Electron microscopy of a kidney biopsy reveals concentric lamellar "zebra bodies." Accumulation of which of the following substrates is responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation-burning pain and tingling in the hands and feet worsened by heat (acroparesthesias), decreased sweating (hypohidrosis), characteristic angiokeratomas on the lower trunk, lenticular corneal opacities, proteinuria, and declining renal function-along with electron microscopy findings of "zebra bodies" (concentric, lamellated lipid-containing deposits within lysosomes.) in kidney biopsy, is classic for Fabry disease.

Fabry disease is an X-linked recessive lysosomal storage disorder caused by deficiency of the enzyme α-galactosidase A. This leads to accumulation of globotriaosylceramide (ceramide trihexoside) in various tissues.

choices.text: Optimum temperature for toxin production is 37° C
Intradietic toxin is responsible for intestinal symptoms
Toxin can be destroyed by boiling for 30 minutes

questions.text: Twenty children attended a birthday party where they consumed pastries and sandwiches. Approximately four hours later, all of them developed symptoms of acute gastroenteritis, including nausea and vomiting. Which of the following statements regarding the likely cause of illness is false?
questions.solution:
The illness is due to staphylococcal food poisoning, caused by ingestion of preformed staphylococcal enterotoxin produced by Staphylococcus aureus growing in contaminated food. Enterotoxins are heat-stable toxins that resist boiling at 100°C for 10 to 40 mins depending on concentration and medium.

Staphylococcal Enterotoxin & Food Poisoning:

  • Source: Most commonly from food handlers who are asymptomatic carriers of aureus. Improper storage (leaving food out after cooking) allows bacteria to multiply and produce toxins.
  • Nature of the Toxin:
    • Enterotoxin is preformed - secreted before ingestion.
    • It is heat-stable, resisting boiling at 100°C for 10-40 minutes depending on the medium.
    • Resistant to gastric juice, explaining how it survives the stomach to cause illness.
  • Optimum growth temperature: S. aureus grows and produces toxin optimally at 37°C (normal body temperature). (Option A ruled out)
  • Toxin typing:
    • Multiple antigenic types: A, B, C1-3, D, E, and H.
    • Type A is most commonly associated with food poisoning.
  • Incubation period: Because the toxin is preformed, symptoms occur rapidly - within 1 to 6 hours after ingestion. (Option D ruled out)
  • Site & Mechanism of action:
    • Acts on the vagus nerve and vomiting center of the brain.
    • Also increases intestinal peristalsis, leading to nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.
    • Intradietic toxin is responsible for intestinal symptom (Option B ruled out)
  • Clinical Features:
    • Acute onset of nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, and occasional diarrhea.
    • No fever.
    • Self-limiting: Recovery usually within 8-10 hours.
    • No secondary spread, as it is toxin-mediated, not an active infection.
  • Common foods involved: Ham, poultry, pastries, mayonnaise, salads, dairy products.

questions.text: A 2-day-old neonate is brought to the NICU with poor feeding, lethargy, and hypothermia. Blood cultures are sent. The Gram stain of the blood culture is shown below. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this neonate's condition?
questions.solution:
Based on the scenario and the Gram stain showing gram-positive cocci in chains, the most likely organism is Group B Streptococcus (GBS), also known as Streptococcus agalactiae.

GBS is the most common cause of early-onset neonatal sepsis, which typically presents within the first 7 days of life. It is acquired perinatally during childbirth from mothers colonized with GBS in the genital or gastrointestinal tract.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with a breast lump. Immunohistochemistry (IHC) shows a 2+ result for HER2/neu expression. To confirm HER2 status, FISH is performed, and the image below shows the FISH pattern. What is the interpretation of this FISH result?
questions.solution:
The patient has a breast tumor with IHC 2+ for HER2/neu, which is considered equivocal. Therefore, FISH (Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization) testing was done to determine the HER2 gene amplification status.

FISH Image Interpretation:

  • Red signals = HER2 gene copies
  • Green signals = CEP17 (centromere of chromosome 17)
  • The image shows 2 red (HER2) and 2 green (CEP17) signals per nucleus in most tumor cells.
  • This results in a HER2/CEP17 ratio ≈0 and an average HER2 copy number per cell ≈ 2.0.

According to the 2018 ASCO/CAP guidelines:

  • If the HER2/CEP17 ratio is<2.0 and
  • The average HER2 copy number is <4.0, → The HER2 status is classified as negative (not amplified).

Interpretation of HER2/neu Status:

  • Positive if HER2/CEP17 ratio ≥ 2.0, or if ratio < 2.0 but average HER2 copies ≥ 6.0.
  • Negative if ratio < 2.0 and average HER2 copies < 4.0.
  • Equivocal if ratio < 2.0 and average HER2 copies between 4.0 and 6.0; then IHC results guide classification (positive if IHC3+, negative if IHC0, 1+, or 2+ per 2018 guidelines).

Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7318106/

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with a one-week history of headache, ataxia, and sudden vomiting, progressing to coma. Cerebrospinal fluid cytology shows anaplastic cells with dark blue nuclei and scant cytoplasm. Brain MRI is most likely to reveal a mass in which location?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation (headache, ataxia, vomiting, and progression to coma in a 5-year-old) combined with cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) cytology showing anaplastic cells with dark blue nuclei and scant cytoplasm strongly suggests medulloblastoma. Medulloblastomas typically arise in the cerebellar vermis in young children.

Medulloblastoma:

  • A malignant embryonal tumor that occurs predominantly in children and arises mainly from the cerebellar vermis, and occurs exclusively in the cerebellum.
  • Clinical Presentation: Rapid growth may block cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) flow, causing hydrocephalus.
  • Spread:
    • Propensity to disseminate in subarachnoid space via CSF.
    • Can produce "icing-like" leptomeningeal spread or "drop metastases" to cauda equina.
  • Histological Variants:
    • Classic: Small blue cells with Homer Wright rosettes, high Ki-67 positivity, express neuronal markers (e.g., synaptophysin).
    • Desmoplastic/nodular: Shows pale islands, desmoplasia, and greater neuronal differentiation.
    • Large cell/anaplastic: Features large nuclei, prominent nucleoli, cell wrapping, and high mitotic/apoptotic index.

Key Takeaways:

  • Medulloblastoma is a malignant pediatric tumor that typically arises from the cerebellar vermis.

Reference:https://radiopaedia.org/articles/medulloblastoma

questions.text: All of the following are contraindications to the use of topical beta blockers in the eye, except:
questions.solution:
Diabetes Mellitus is not a contraindication to use topical beta blockers.

Topical beta-blockers (e.g., timolol, levobunolol, betaxolol) are commonly used antiglaucoma drugs that lower intraocular pressure (IOP) by inhibiting aqueous humor production via beta-receptor blockade in the ciliary epithelium.

While beta-blockers can mask symptoms of hypoglycemia (such as tachycardia), they are not absolutely contraindicated in diabetic patients.

Caution is advised, but they can still be used when benefits outweigh risks.

Side Effects Mnemonic for Beta Blockers: (Mnemonic: A to I)

  • Arrest (cardiac arrest risk in conduction defects)
  • Bradycardia
  • Bronchospasm - C/I in Asthma, emphysema, COPD(Option C ruled out)
  • Conduction defects (AV block) (Option B ruled out)
  • Dry eye
  • Exercise intolerance
  • Fatigue
  • Glycemic symptoms masked (hypoglycemia symptoms hidden)
  • Hypotension
  • Worsening of Heart failure (Option D ruled out)
  • Impotence

Note: Betaxolol is the beta blocker of choice in patients at risk for pulmonary diseases

choices.text: The initiative aims to reduce avoidable blindness by the year 2020, targeting diseases such as cataract, refractive error, childhood blindness, and glaucoma.
The plan includes human resource development and infrastructure development at various levels of the health system, with a proposed four-tier structure.
The initiative focuses on developing a single-tier structure consisting only of centers of excellence.
The target diseases include cataract, refractive errors, childhood blindness, corneal blindness, glaucoma, and diabetic retinopathy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is NOT a key feature of the Vision 2020: The Right to Sight initiative in India?
questions.solution:
• VISION 2020: The Right to Sight - India is a joint initiative by the Government of India and WHO to eliminate avoidable blindness by 2020.
  • It emphasizes:
    • Four-tier healthcare delivery structure:
      1. Primary eye care centers (vision centers)
      2. Secondary centers (district hospitals)
      3. Tertiary centers (medical colleges)
      4. Centers of excellence
    • Human resource development, infrastructure, and disease control.
    • Target diseases: cataract, refractive errors, childhood blindness, corneal blindness, glaucoma, diabetic retinopathy, and more.

Hence, Option C is incorrect and is the right choice for this "NOT" question.

questions.text: A 35 year old male diabetic came with headache since many months and eyestrain. He has a family history of glaucoma with his father a diabetic and glaucomatous. On examination AC is mild shallow. IOP is 18 mmHg. His refraction is plus +2.5. What could be most probable reason of his eye stain and headache
questions.solution:
• The patient's refraction of +2.5 D indicates hypermetropia (farsightedness), which commonly causes eyestrain during near work and frontal headaches when uncorrected.
  • Hypermetropic eyes often have a shallow anterior chamber, increasing future risk of angle-closure glaucoma, but currently, the patient's normal IOP and absence of acute symptoms (redness, pain, halos or vomiting) exclude an acute angle-closure glaucoma. (Option B ruled out)

Explanation of Other Options:

Open-angle glaucoma(Option A): It is unlikely because his IOP is within normal limits, and there is no mention of optic disc cupping or visual field defects, which are typical findings in glaucoma.

Diabetic retinopathy(Option D): It does not typically present with eyestrain or headache. There is no mention of retinal changes, such as hemorrhages or macular edema, and his vision complaints are more consistent with refractive error than with retinal pathology.

questions.text:
Match the following diseases with their key characteristics:
1. Neuroletharism
2. Epidemic Dropsy
3. Endemic Ascites
4. Ergotism
BOAA toxin, Paralysis stages
Sanguinarine toxin, Bilateral oedema
Pyrrolizidine alkaloids, Hepatotoxicity
Clavine alkaloids, Gangrene
questions.solution:
• Neurolethargism: Caused by BOAA (Beta Oxalyl Amino-Alanine) toxin found in Lathyrus sativus (kesari dal), leads to spastic paralysis.
  • Epidemic Dropsy: Due to Sanguinarine toxin from Argemone mexicana seeds mixed with mustard oil, causes bilateral pitting edema.
  • Endemic Ascites: Due to Pyrrolizidine alkaloids from Crotalaria seeds, leads to chronic hepatotoxicity and ascites.
  • Ergotism: Due to Clavine alkaloids from Claviceps purpurea contaminating grains, leads to vasoconstriction, gangrene, and convulsions.
  • Aflatoxicosis: Caused by Aflatoxins (potent hepatotoxins) produced by Aspergillus flavus and A parasiticus that infest grains.

questions.text: A 34 year old woman at 30 weeks of gestation is diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment option?
questions.solution:
• Heparin does not cross the blood-brain barrier or placenta (it is the anticoagulant of choice during pregnancy).
  • Indications of LMW heparins are:
    • Prophylaxis of deep vein thrombosis (dVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE) in high-risk patients undergoing surgery; stroke or other immobilized patients.
    • Treatment of established DVT.
    • Unstable angina (UA) and MI: they have largely replaced continuous infusion of UFH.
    • To maintain patency of cannulae and shunts in dialysis patients.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A: Warfarin is teratogenic (bone/cartilage abnormalities) and fetal bleeding risk.
  • Option C: DOACs cross placenta; not recommended in pregnancy.
  • Option D:Fondaparinux is not first-line; reserved for heparin-induced thrombocytopenia or LMWH intolerance.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with newly diagnosed atrial fibrillation is prescribed amiodarone. After 4 months, he develops dry cough and dyspnea. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
• Amiodarone's high lipophilicity leads to lung accumulation and dose-independent pulmonary toxicity, most often manifesting as interstitial pneumonitis/fibrosis.
  • Onset typically 2-6 months after initiation; presents with nonproductive cough, progressive dyspnea, and restrictive lung function changes.
  • Diagnosis:
  • Management: Stop drug + steroids.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A: Drug-induced bronchospasm is uncommon with amiodarone; presents with wheezing, not interstitial changes.
  • Option C: Congestive heart failure would show fluid overload signs (edema, pulmonary venous congestion)
  • Option D: Opportunistic infection - consider immunosuppression or neutropenia; imaging shows focal infiltrates or consolidation.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman undergoes routine laboratory testing. Her complete blood count reveals a hemoglobin level of 10.2 g/dL and a mean corpuscular volume (MCV) of 106 fL. White blood cell and platelet counts are within normal limits. She reports no alcohol use or gastrointestinal symptoms. Further evaluation shows a normal methylmalonic acid level (160 nmol/L) and an elevated homocysteine level (4.5 mg/L). Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen on her peripheral blood smear?
questions.solution:
• This patient has macrocytic anemia (MCV > 100 fL) with an elevated homocysteine and normal methylmalonic acid, a pattern consistent with folate deficiency.
  • Folate deficiency impairs DNA synthesis, leading to megaloblastic anemia, which is characterized by nuclear-cytoplasmic asynchrony in hematopoietic cells. A hallmark feature on peripheral smear is the presence of hypersegmented neutrophils (neutrophils with ≥5 nuclear lobes).
  • The normal methylmalonic acid level helps distinguish folate deficiency from vitamin B12 deficiency, which typically elevates both homocysteine and methylmalonic acid.

Explanation of other options:

Related Concept:

questions.text: Match the following oncogenes with their most commonly associated cancers:

A 10-year-old child presents with fever and cervical lymphadenopathy. Oral examination shows a grey membrane on the right tonsil extending to the anterior pillar. Which of the following medium will be ideal for the culture of the throat swab for a rapid isolation & identification of the pathogen?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture (fever, cervical lymphadenopathy, grey membrane on tonsil) is classic for diphtheria, caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

Corynebacterium diphtheriae is a fastidious, facultative anaerobic bacterium that requires enriched media for optimal growth because it grows poorly on ordinary culture media. Among the commonly used media, Loffler's serum slope is the ideal medium for the rapid isolation and identification of C. diphtheriae from throat swabs.

Loffler's Serum Slope (Ideal for Rapid Isolation):

  • This medium contains serum and supports the growth of the organism within 6 to 8 hours, allowing early visualization of small, glistening white colonies with a yellowish tint.
  • It also aids in the demonstration of metachromatic granules (volutin granules), which are characteristic of diphtheriae.
  • However, if incubation extends beyond 8 hours, other throat commensals may grow, reducing the selectivity of the medium.

Explanation of Other Options:

Potassium Tellurite Agar (Option A):

  • Potassium Tellurite Agar/Tinsdale media is a selective medium containing potassium tellurite, which inhibits the growth of most normal flora, allowing the isolation of diphtheriae colonies that reduce tellurite to metallic tellurium, producing distinctive grey to black colonies.
  • While useful for isolating the organism from carriers or convalescent cases, growth on this medium is slower, requiring at least 48 hours, making it less suitable for rapid diagnosis.

Blood Agar (Option B):

  • It is an enriched medium with 5-10% sheep blood.
  • It supports the growth of many organisms. including diphtheriae, which forms small, white or grey colonies that may be hemolytic (especially mitis biotype).
  • Although useful for differentiating diphtheria from other causes of pharyngitis such as streptococci and staphylococci, blood agar does not allow for rapid or selective isolation of diphtheriae.

Lowenstein-Jensen Medium (Option D):

  • It is a selective medium designed specifically for the isolation of Mycobacterium tuberculosis and is not suitable for culturing diphtheriae or other throat pathogens.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic male is started on levofloxacin for UTI. Two days later, he presents with confusion, myoclonus, and jerks. EEG shows triphasic waves. Which mechanism is responsible?
questions.solution:
• Fluoroquinolones can cause neurotoxicity, especially in elderly or CKD patients, by inhibiting GABA-A receptors.
  • Presents with encephalopathy, myoclonus, tremors, and seizures, especially in the elderly or those with renal impairment
  • Risk factors: Advanced age, renal dysfunction (reduced drug clearance), and concomitant NSAID use (further GABA-A inhibition)
  • Prevention: Dose adjustment in renal impairment; avoid in patients with seizure disorders

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A: NMDA receptor activation - some neurotoxins act this way, but fluoroquinolones primarily affect GABA-A.
  • Option C: Dopamine receptor blockade - typical of antipsychotics causing extrapyramidal symptoms, not fluoroquinolones.
  • Option D: Glycine receptor stimulation - implicated in strychnine toxicity, not in fluoroquinolone effects.

questions.text: A 2-month-old baby girl presents with cataracts and inability to track objects. Her urine is positive for Benedict's test but negative on Glucostix testing. The rest of her examination is normal. Which enzyme is most likely deficient?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is characteristic of galactokinase deficiency, a disorder in galactose metabolism.

  • The positive Benedict's test with a negative glucose test (Glucostix) indicates the presence of a reducing sugar other than glucose-specifically, galactose-in the urine.
  • Cataracts due to accumulation of galactitol in the lens.
  • Absence of systemic symptoms such as developmental delay or hepatomegaly suggests a mild form of galactose metabolism disorder, distinguishing it from classic galactosemia.

Pathophysiology:

Galactokinase deficiency results in impaired phosphorylation of galactose to galactose-1-phosphate. This leads to increased galactose in blood and urine. Excess galactose is converted to galactitol by aldose reductase, and galactitol accumulation in the lens causes cataracts. Unlike classic galactosemia, toxic galactose-1-phosphate does not accumulate, so systemic symptoms are absent.

Explanation of Other Options:

Galactose 1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GALT) deficiency (Option A): Causes classic galactosemia, characterized by cataracts, hepatomegaly, developmental delay, and vomiting after milk ingestion. Systemic symptoms are typically present, which are absent here.

Fructokinase deficiency (Option C): Causes essential fructosuria, a benign condition with fructose accumulation in urine but no cataracts or galactose-related symptoms.

Aldolase B deficiency (Option D): Causes hereditary fructose intolerance, presenting with hypoglycemia, vomiting, and liver dysfunction after fructose ingestion; unrelated to cataracts or galactose metabolism.

Key Takeaway:

Unlike classic galactosemia, galactokinase deficiency usually presents with isolated cataracts without systemic symptoms such as developmental delay, hepatomegaly, or vomiting.

questions.text: Which antibodies are most commonly associated with Shrinking Lung Syndrome in a patient with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)?
questions.solution:
Explanation of correct answer:

Anti-Ro antibodies are most commonly associated with shrinking lung syndrome in SLE.

Shrinking Lung Syndrome (SLS):

  • SLS is a rare complication of systemic autoimmune diseases, most commonly seen in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
  • Other Associations: Has also been reported in systemic sclerosis, Sjogren's syndrome, and rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Exertional shortness of breath
    • Pleuritic chest pain (may or may not be present)
    • Reduced lung volumes on imaging
  • Pulmonary Function Tests (PFTs):
    • Restrictive ventilatory defect
    • Reduced total lung capacity
  • Radiographic findings: unilateral or bilateral elevation of hemidiaphragm(s)
  • Diagnosis:
    • Diagnosis of exclusion
    • CT chest is often done to rule out other causes of dyspnea and lung volume loss
  • Serological Findings:
    • Anti-Ro/SSA antibodies (50-70%)
    • Anti-RNP antibodies (20-50%)
  • Treatment:
    • Initial treatment typically involves oral corticosteroids (30-60 mg/day)
    • In refractory cases, immunosuppressive agents like Mycophenolate Mofetil (MMF) may be used.

Explanation of other options:

Anti-dsDNA (Option A) antibodies are highly specific for SLE and strongly associated with disease activity, particularly lupus nephritis and systemic inflammation. However, they are not specifically linked to SLS.

Anti-U1 RNP (Option B) antibodies are associated with mixed connective tissue disease (MCTD) and some SLE patients. Present in ~50% of SLS cases, but less frequent than anti-Ro (50-70%).

Anti-ribosomal P (Option C) antibodies are associated with neuropsychiatric lupus (e.g., psychosis, depression). Not commonly found in shrinking lung syndrome.

Key Takeaways:

  • Anti-Ro/SSA antibodies are the most commonly associated with Shrinking Lung Syndrome in SLE, seen in 50-70% of cases.

Reference:

  1. https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0003496724592378
  2. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK568683/#

questions.text: NPU (Net Protein Utilization) value for egg is?
questions.solution:
• Egg has the highest NPU among natural foods.
  • It serves as the reference standard for protein quality due to its high digestibility and amino acid profile.

NPU (Net Protein Utilization) of Egg

  • NPU is a measure of how efficiently the body uses the protein from food.
  • It combines:
    • Digestibility (how well the protein is absorbed)
    • Biological value (BV) (how well the absorbed protein is used for growth/maintenance)

Nutritional Value of One Large Hen's Egg (approx. 50g):

  • Eggs are also rich in choline, selenium, riboflavin, and have all essential amino acids making them a reference protein for quality.
