questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about this ocular condition where calcium is accumulated?
questions.solution:
• The given image shows band shaped keratopathy (BSK).
  • The calcium deposition in BSK occurs in the Bowman's membrane, the most superficial part of the stroma, and deeper layers of the epithelium-not in the endothelium, which lies much deeper.

choices.text: It is a virus that infects bacteria
It helps in transduction of bacteria

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about bacteriophage except:
questions.solution:
• A bacteriophage is a virus that infects bacteria and can multiply inside them. (Option A ruled out)
  • It mediates transduction, which is the transfer of DNA from one bacterium to another via the phage. This DNA can be part of the bacterial chromosome, plasmids, or episomes.
  • Transduction occurs during phage life cycles: (Option B ruled out)
    • Lytic cycle: Phage multiplies, causing bacterial cell lysis and sometimes mistakenly packages bacterial DNA into new phage particles (generalized transduction).
    • Lysogenic cycle: Phage DNA integrates into bacterial chromosome (prophage) and can carry adjacent bacterial genes upon excision (specialized transduction).
  • Transduction can transfer any bacterial DNA segment (generalized) or specific adjacent segments (specialized), so it is not limited to only chromosomal genes.
  • Some bacteriophages can also impart toxigenicity to bacteria by carrying toxin genes, e.g., Corynebacterium diphtheriae acquiring diphtheria toxin gene via lysogenic conversion. (Option C ruled out)
  • Hence, the false statement is that bacteriophages transfer only chromosomal genes.

Medical application of transduction:

  1. Imparts toxigenicity to the bacteria: Phage DNA may code for various toxins abbreviated as ABCDE: A and C of Streptococcus pyrogenic exotoxin (SPE), Botulinum toxin C and D, Cholera toxin, Diphtheria toxin and E. coli (Verocytotoxin).
  2. MRSA: Transfer the mecA gene in S aureus.

choices.text: Hemoglobin A (HbA) decreases sickling by inhibiting HbS polymerization
Coexistent thalassemia with sickle cell anemia increases the frequency of acute sickling crises
Hemoglobin S (HbS) concentration is the most important factor affecting sickling

questions.text: Which of the following statements about sickling in sickle cell anemia is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation of correct answer:

Coexistent thalassemia (especially α-thalassemia) typically reduces sickling severity in sickle cell anemia by lowering intracellular HbS concentration, thus decreasing polymerization.

Sickle Cell Disease:

  • Sickle cell disease is a hereditary hemoglobinopathy due to a point mutation in the β-globin gene.
  • Mutation causes valine (hydrophobic) to replace glutamate (charged) in β-globin.
  • Results in polymerization of deoxygenated HbS, causing:
    • Red cell distortion
    • Hemolytic anemia
    • Microvascular obstruction
    • Ischemic tissue damage
  • Effect of Other Hemoglobins:
  • HbA inhibits sickling (trait = ~40% HbS). (Option B)
  • HbF strongly inhibits sickling (infants are protected; persistent HbF = milder disease). (Option C)
  • HbC + HbS (HbSC disease): ~50% HbS, milder than HbSS.

Explanation of other options:

HbA decreases sickling by inhibiting HbS polymerization (Option A): HbA interferes with the ability of HbS molecules to polymerize when deoxygenated, reducing sickling, especially in sickle cell trait where HbA is present.

HbF decreases sickling (Option B): Fetal hemoglobin (HbF) strongly inhibits the polymerization of HbS, which is why infants with sickle cell anemia have fewer symptoms until HbF levels fall after birth.

Hemoglobin S (HbS) concentration is the most important factor affecting sickling (Option D): The intracellular concentration of HbS directly influences how much polymerization and sickling occurs; higher HbS concentration leads to increased sickling.

Key Takeaways:

Coexistent thalassemia reduces sickling severity in sickle cell anemia by lowering intracellular HbS concentration, so it does not increase acute sickling crisis.

Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/3893275/

choices.text: E. coli is a facultative anaerobe
E. coli is motile by peritrichous flagella
Proteus causes deamination of phenylalanine to phenylpyruvic acid

questions.text: All of the following are true except:
questions.solution:
Proteus species cause urinary tract infections and are associated with struvite stone formation, not uric acid stones. Struvite stones form in alkaline urine due to urease enzyme activity that converts urea to ammonia, raising pH and causing precipitation of magnesium ammonium phosphate (struvite).

Phenylalanine Deaminase (PPA) test is a biochemical test used to identify Proteus from other Enterobacteriaceae. It detects the ability of an organism to deaminate phenylalanine to phenylpyruvic acid (PPA) (Option D ruled out). A positive PPA test is indicated by a green color when a ferric chloride solution is added. A positive test is indicated by a green color upon adding ferric chloride.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with SLE on hydroxychloroquine presents with vision problems. Which part of the eye is affected?
questions.solution:
• Hydroxychloroquine retinopathy manifests as bull’s-eye maculopathy, with damage to the macular retinal pigment epithelium and photoreceptors
  • Toxicity risk rises at daily doses> 5 mg/kg and cumulative doses > 1000 g; early changes are detected on OCT and visual field testing
  • Screening guidelines: Baseline fundus exam + OCT within first year; annual screening after 5 years of therapy or sooner if high-risk

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A: Lens - cataract formation is not a feature of hydroxychloroquine toxicity
  • Option C: Cornea - may show benign vortex keratopathy, not sight-threatening
  • Option D: Optic nerve - optic neuropathy is rare and not the classic presentation

questions.text: A 39-year-old man has had numerous bouts of pneumonia caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Burkholderia cepacia. He now has diarrhea of mild-to-moderate volume. On physical examination, he has decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion in both lungs. His stool guaiac test is negative. Laboratory studies show the ΔF508 mutation. His quantitative stool fat is 7.5 g/day. Which of the following pathologic findings is most likely to be present in the pancreas of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has cystic fibrosis, an autosomal recessive condition that results from an abnormal cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene.

  • CFTR dysfunction in ΔF508 cystic fibrosis leads to thick, inspissated secretions that obstruct the small pancreatic ducts, blocking the flow of digestive enzymes.
  • Chronic obstruction induces progressive acinar cell loss, with replacement by fibrous tissue and adipose("fibrofatty replacement"), the hallmark of acinar atrophy in CF
  • Resulting exocrine insufficiency produces steatorrhea (stool fat >7 g/day) and fat-soluble vitamin malabsorption

Pathologic findings in CF pancreas:

  • Gross: The pancreas is small, firm, and nodular; main and intralobular ducts are dilated or plugged with thick concretions.
  • Histology: Complete or patchy loss of acinar cells, extensive peri-ductal fibrosis, fatty infiltration of lobules, relative preservation of islets early in disease, and occasional ductular proliferation. Over time, islets are lost and CF-related diabetes may ensue.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A: Acute inflammation shows neutrophils and edema, characteristic of acute pancreatitis, not chronic CF change.
  • Option B: Pseudocyst is a sequel of acute necrotizing pancreatitis, uncommon in CF without acute episodes.
  • Option C: Amyloidosis is a systemic protein deposition unrelated to CF pathology.

References:

https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Acinar-atrophy-of-the-exocrine-pancreas-Pancreas-slide-from-a-78-years-old-male-patient_fig2_333025385

choices.text: Perform bilamellar tarsal rotation for trichiasis

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with chronic itching, ocular discharge, and progressive vision loss over several years. On examination, the cornea is vascularized with macular opacities, follicles are seen on the upper limbus, and there is tylosis with trichiatic eyelashes. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

This is a classic case of cicatricial trachoma, a chronic sequela of Chlamydia trachomatis infection.

Clinical clues pointing to chronic trachoma:

  • Itching + discharge + decreased vision → long-standing conjunctival inflammation
  • Vascularized cornea + macular opacities → scarring and pannus
  • Tylosis + trichiasis → lid margin thickening and lashes rubbing cornea
  • Follicles at upper limbus →Herbert's pits(pathognomonic for trachoma)

These are part of the scarring stage of trachoma, and the management at this point is surgical, not medical.

According to the SAFE strategy recommended by the WHO for trachoma control:

S = Surgery for trichiasis (entropion or inward turning of the eyelid)

A = Antibiotics for active infection

F = Facial cleanliness

E = Environmental improvement

The surgical procedure for trichiasis is:

  • Bilamellar tarsal rotation, which corrects the lid margin and prevents eyelashes from rubbing the cornea and worsening scarring or causing corneal ulceration.

Explanation of Other Options:

Azithromycin (Option A): Used in active trachoma (TF or TI stage with papillae and follicles), not useful in chronic cicatricial stage with scarring.

Remove the trichiatic eyelash(Option B): Temporary measures like epilation doesn't solve the root problem (entropion or misdirected lashes). Lashes may grow back again in the wrong direction.

Penetrating keratoplasty (Option D): A corneal transplant may eventually be needed after stabilizing the eyelid condition. If done before correcting trichiasis, the graft will likely fail due to persistent trauma and inflammation.

Related Important Concept:



Key Takeaway:

In a patient with chronic trachoma sequelae like trichiasis and corneal opacification, the next best step is to surgically correct the eyelid malposition using bilamellar tarsal rotation. This protects the cornea and prevents further damage.

questions.text: A 45-year-old cirrhotic patient is started on spironolactone for ascites. After 1 week, he develops vomiting and generalized weakness. Serum K+ = 6.8 mmol/L. What is the mechanism?
questions.solution:
• Spironolactone is an aldosterone receptor antagonist in the distal nephron and collecting duct.
  • By blocking aldosterone's action, spironolactone reduces Na+ reabsorption and decreases K+ and H+ secretion, leading to hyperkalemia and metabolic acidosis
  • Indications: Ascites in cirrhosis, heart failure, primary hyperaldosteronism
  • Onset of effect: 2-3 days for peak diuretic and electrolyte effects
  • Monitoring: Serum electrolytes and renal function, especially in patients with renal impairment or those on other K+-sparing agents

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A: Inhibition of sodium channels - mechanism of amiloride and triamterene, not spironolactone
  • Option B: Inhibition of Na+/K+-ATPase - mechanism of cardiac glycosides (e.g., digoxin)
  • Option D: Blockade of aquaporin channels - mechanism of vasopressin antagonists, unrelated to K+ excretion

questions.text: Which anatomic variant is seen in the given CT?
questions.solution:
• Anatomical Background
    • In normal anatomy, the right subclavian artery arises from the brachiocephalic trunk.
    • In ARSA (Aberrant Right Subclavian Artery), the artery originates directly from the aortic arch, distal to the left subclavian artery.
    • It then passes posterior to the esophagus (most common course), potentially compressing it.

CT Angiography Findings:

CT angiography (with contrast) is the modality of choice. Here’s what to look for:

  1. Aberrant Origin of Right Subclavian Artery
    1. Arises as the fourth branch of the aortic arch, after the left subclavian.
    2. The typical branching pattern becomes:
      1. Left common carotid
      2. Left subclavian
      3. Aberrant right subclavian artery (ARSA)
  2. Posterior Course of ARSA
    1. The artery courses posterior to the esophagus (in ~80% of cases).
    2. On axial CT, you’ll see the artery looping behind the esophagus, possibly indenting it.
  3. Esophageal Compression
    1. Narrowing or flattening of the posterior esophageal wall.
    2. May cause an impression visible on barium swallow, but CT directly visualizes the artery causing it.
    3. Sometimes associated with esophageal dilation proximally due to obstruction.
  4. Diverticulum of Kommerell (if present)
    1. This is a bulbous dilation at the origin of the ARSA.
    2. Best seen on sagittal or 3D reconstructions
    3. Can worsen compression or be a site for aneurysm formation.
  5. Tracheal Compression (less common)
    1. If the ARSA or associated diverticulum is large enough, it can also compress the posterior tracheal wall.

CT Views to Evaluate

  • Axial: Show relationship between ARSA and esophagus.
  • Coronal/Sagittal: Confirm vertical course and compression.
  • 3D Volume Rendering: Excellent for surgical planning.

Reference: https://radiopaedia.org/articles/aberrant-right-subclavian-artery

questions.text: A young drug abuser is admitted in emergency. He is agitated, shouting and complains that whenever anyone's mobile phone rings, he starts seeing some vibrating radiations in front of his eyes. This is called as:
questions.solution:
• Reflex Hallucination
    • The patient hears a real sound (ringtone).
    • This triggers a visual hallucination (seeing radiation).
    • Hence, a stimulus in one sensory modality (auditory) results in hallucination in another (visual) → textbook definition of reflex hallucination.

Hallucinations - Quick Revision Chart

Key Takeaways:

  • MC hallucination overall in psychiatry: Auditory
  • MC hallucination in organic disorders (delirium, dementia): Visual
  • Olfactory & gustatory hallucinations: Think temporal lobe pathology (e.g., epilepsy, tumors)
  • Tactile hallucinations (e.g., formication): Cocaine intoxication is classic

choices.text: Weakness of flexor digitorum profundus to the index finger

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after falling on an outstretched hand. Examination reveals swelling and deformity around the left elbow. An X-ray is taken and shown below. After initial stabilization, a neurovascular examination is performed. The child is unable to flex the distal phalanx of the thumb and the index finger. No sensory loss is noted in the hand. Which of the following signs is not expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a child with swelling and deformity around the elbow following a fall on an outstretched hand, along with the X-ray finding, suggests a supracondylar fracture of the humerus. In such cases, the anterior interosseous nerve (AIN), a motor branch of the median nerve, is the most commonly involved. The AIN carries no sensory fibers, so numbness over the thenar eminence is not seen in this case.

Supracondylar Fractures in Children:

  • These are among the most common fractures in children.
  • Involve the distal humerus, often displaced and/or tilted.
  • Types of Displacement:
    • Posterior displacement and tilt (95% cases):
      • Due to hyperextension injury (fall on outstretched hand).
    • Anterior displacement:
      • Rare.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Follows a fall.
    • Painful and swollen elbow.
    • Posteriorly displaced fracture shows “S” deformity.
  • Modified Gartland Classification:

Complications:

  1. Vascular Injury:
    • Brachial artery is at risk.
    • May present with a white, pulseless hand (forearm ischaemia).
  2. Compartment Syndrome:
    • Early signs:
      • Increasing pain despite splint.
      • Pain on passive finger extension.
    • Late signs:
      • Reduced capillary return.
      • Blunted sensation.
  3. Nerve Injury:
    • Anterior interosseous nerve (branch of median nerve):
      • Most commonly injured.
      • Presents with paralysis of flexor pollicis longus (Option A), flexor digitorum profundus to index finger (Option B), and pronator quadratus.
      • Diagnosed by inability to make "OK sign". (Option D)
      • Usually temporary, recovery in 3-4 months.
    • Ulnar nerve:
      • Risk during K-wire placement.
  4. Malunion:
    • Cubitus varus or posterior translation is common.
  5. Elbow Stiffness:
    • Full range of motion takes months.

Key Takeaways:

  • Supracondylar humerus fractures commonly injure the anterior interosseous nerve (AIN).
  • AIN injury causes weakness of flexor pollicis longus and flexor digitorum profundus to the index finger.
  • Patients are unable to perform the "OK" sign.
  • No sensory loss or numbness over the thenar eminence occurs.

Reference: 

  1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK560933/#
  2. https://thejns.org/view/journals/j-neurosurg/90/6/article-p1053.xml#

questions.text: The wife of a truck driver presents with vaginal discharge and on examination, cervical erosions were seen. Which of the following shall be prescribed?
questions.solution:
• Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by Trichomonas vaginalis. It often presents with greenish frothy vaginal discharge and cervical erosions, which may show punctate red spots (strawberry cervix or colpitis maculae) on examination.
  • The infection is acquired by direct sexual contact and affects both women and men. In women, it causes vaginal discharge and cervical erosions, while in men, it may result in nongonococcal urethritis.
  • The green kit is used in syndromic management for trichomoniasis as per CDC 2021 STI treatment guidelines, which recommend a seven-day course of 500 mg metronidazole twice daily for treatment.
  • Diagnostic confirmation is typically done via wet prep microscopy, where motile trichomonads can be observed under the microscope.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option B: Grey kit: This is used for the management of bacterial vaginosis or vaginal candidiasis, not for trichomoniasis.
  • Option C: Yellow kit: This is typically used for the management of gonorrhea and chlamydia infections.
  • Option D: Red kit: This is used for managing syphilis.

Key Takeaway:

  • Trichomoniasis is managed with the green kit in syndromic management, and treatment typically involves metronidazole as per the CDC 2021 guidelines.

Reference: CDC 2021 guidelines, NATA Syndromic approach guidelines

choices.text: William Morton's public demonstration of diethyl ether

questions.text: The world anesthesia day is celebrated on October 16, this signifies
questions.solution:
• World Anesthesia Day (also known as Ether Day) is celebrated on October 16 every year. This day marks a historic public demonstration of surgical anesthesia by Dr. William T.G. Morton, an American dentist, who successfully administered diethyl ether to a patient undergoing surgical excision of a neck tumor at Massachusetts General Hospital in 1846.
  • This event is considered a major breakthrough in the history of medicine because it was the first successful public demonstration of surgical anesthesia, showing that surgery could be performed without pain.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A: First use of chloroform
    • Chloroform was introduced as an anesthetic after ether.
    • Date: November 4, 1847
    • By: Dr. James Young Simpson, a Scottish obstetrician
    • He experimented with various chemicals for painless childbirth and found chloroform effective.
  • Option C: Discovery of Nitrous Oxide
    • Nitrous oxide (N2O) was discovered by Joseph Priestley in 1772, and its euphoric effects were later explored by Humphry Davy.
    • Horace Wells, a dentist, used nitrous oxide in 1844 for tooth extraction.
    • However, his public demonstration failed, so it did not lead to widespread adoption at that time.
  • Option D: First spinal anesthesia
    • Date: August 16, 1898
    • By: Dr. August Bier, a German surgeon
    • He performed the first documented spinal anesthetic using cocaine.

questions.text:
A 28-week preterm neonate is admitted with signs of respiratory distress. The attending physician is using the Downes score to assess the severity. Which of the following findings would contribute to the total Downes score in this neonate's evaluation?
1. Nasal flaring
2. Grunting
3. Retractions
4. Respiratory rate
5. Air entry
questions.solution:
Nasal flaring is not included in the Downes score, although it is a sign of respiratory distress. It is, however, part of the Silverman-Anderson score.

The severity of respiratory distress is assessed by both the Silverman-Anderson score and Downes' score.

  • Silverman-Anderson Scoring system: Specifically for preterm neonates with HMD
  • Downes' score: Can be used for both preterm and term neonates.

Downe's score:

Silverman Anderson Score:

Interpretation of these scores:

  • 0: No distress
  • 1-3: Mild respiratory distress
  • 4-6: Moderate respiratory distress
  • ≥7: Severe distress or impending respiratory failure.

Reference:

https://iapindia.org/standard-treatment-guidelines/

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with a history of molar pregnancy followed by persistent elevated hCG. She is diagnosed with low-risk choriocarcinoma with no metastases. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Methotrexate (MTX) is commonly used in the treatment of choriocarcinoma, particularly in cases that are low-risk or have a limited extent of disease.

Role of Methotrexate in Choriocarcinoma:

  • First-Line Treatment: MTX, often in combination with other drugs like dactinomycin or cyclophosphamide, is used as a first-line treatment for low-risk choriocarcinoma.
  • MTX is given as 1 mg/kg IM on alternate days with folinic acid (leucovorin) rescue on the in-between days to reduce toxicity, This is called the single-agent, multiple-dose regimen.
  • Low-Risk Choriocarcinoma: This includes cases with no distant metastases, a low number of metastatic sites, and a normal or slightly elevated human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) level.
  • High-Risk Choriocarcinoma: MTX may still be used but is typically combined with more aggressive regimens such as EMA-CO (etoposide, methotrexate, actinomycin-D, cyclophosphamide, and vincristine).

Mechanism of Action:

  • Folate Antagonist: MTX works by inhibiting dihydrofolate reductase, which leads to the inhibition of DNA synthesis and cellular replication. This is particularly effective in rapidly dividing cells like trophoblastic cells in choriocarcinoma.

Methotrexate Dosing:

  • Single-Agent Therapy: MTX is often given as a weekly dose for low-risk choriocarcinoma, but the exact dosing may vary depending on the treatment protocol.
  • Combination Therapy: MTX may be combined with dactinomycin or cyclophosphamide in some regimens for better efficacy, particularly in intermediate-risk cases.

Indications for Methotrexate in Choriocarcinoma:

  • Low-Risk Disease: Primarily used for non-metastatic choriocarcinoma or cases with minimal spread.
  • Post-Surgical Management: After surgical resection of the tumor, MTX can be used to manage any remaining trophoblastic tissue.

Response Monitoring:

  • hCG Monitoring: After initiation of therapy, serum hCG levels are regularly monitored to assess the response to treatment. A fall in hCG levels indicates a positive response.
  • If hCG levels plateau or rise, additional chemotherapy or more aggressive regimens may be required.

choices.text: As an adjunct in pulmonary embolectomy

questions.text: What is an alternative use of cardiopulmonary bypass?

A 59-year-old woman presents with poly-symptomatology. On examination she has prominent fasciculations over the palmer thenar of right hand. From which of the following conditions is she unlikely to suffer?
questions.solution:
• Fasciculations suggest lower motor neuron involvement. They are usually seen in conditions affecting the anterior horn cells of the spinal cord and may also occur in diseases of the nerve roots or peripheral nerves. However, they are absent in disorders of the muscle or neuromuscular junction.
  • Cervical spondylosis affects the spinal cord as well as the nerve roots. So it can cause fasciculations. (Option A ruled out)
  • Motor neurone disease (eg: ALS) is the prototype illness that presents with fasciculations. (Option B ruled out)
  • Spinal muscular atrophy is an LMN type of MND and hence causes fasciculations. (Option D ruled out)
  • Multiple Sclerosis is a disease causing demyelination of the white matter of the central nervous system and presents predominantly with UMN symptoms and can have sensory symptoms as well, fasciculations are not a feature, hence MS is the less likely cause.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a positive pregnancy test presents with acute abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. Her beta-hCG level is 4,500 mIU/mL, and transvaginal ultrasound shows an empty uterus and a mass in the right adnexa. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Given the presence of an adnexal mass and beta-hCG levels above the threshold, laparoscopy is the most definitive diagnostic and therapeutic approach to managing a suspected tubal ectopic pregnancy.

Laparoscopy is the most appropriate step in this patient with suspected tubal ectopic pregnancy. It helps to both diagnose and treat the condition by allowing direct visualization and intervention, including possible surgical removal of the ectopic pregnancy.

A) Methotrexate therapy:

While methotrexate is the first-line treatment for an unruptured, stable ectopic pregnancy, the patient in this scenario has acute symptoms (abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding) and requires urgent evaluation. Methotrexate is usually considered when the pregnancy is not ruptured and the patient is stable.

Criteria for medical management:

  • Patient is stable, unruptured ectopic
  • Size of ectopic is <4 cm
  • No fetal cardiac activity
  • HCG <5000 IU
  • Patient should be compliant for long term follow up

questions.text: All of the following are criteria for DCS except
questions.solution:
Urine output >1 ml/kg/hour is one of the criteria for early total care (ETC), not damage control surgery (DCS).

DCS and ETC are two practices that have become the gold standard for polytrauma patients. The specific criteria are as follows:

Note- Stages of damage control surgery:

  1. Resuscitation.
  2. Hemorrhage control.
  3. Decompression.
  4. Decontamination.
  5. Fracture splintage.

choices.text: Aspirin 325 mg once daily, continued indefinitely
Clopidogrel 300 mg loading dose followed by 75 mg daily + aspirin 75-100 mg daily for 21 days, then clopidogrel monotherapy
Ticagrelor 90 mg twice daily + aspirin 75 mg daily for 90 days
Warfarin adjusted to an INR of 2-3

questions.text: A 66-year-old man arrives 6 h after a high-risk TIA (resolved weakness), no atrial fibrillation. Which antithrombotic regimen gives the best stroke protection in the first 21 days?
questions.solution:
• Dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) with clopidogrel + aspirin started within 24 h of a high-risk TIA or minor ischemic stroke reduces early recurrent stroke compared with aspirin alone
  • The benefit is greatest in the first 21 days; beyond that, bleeding risk outweighs benefit, so therapy is stepped down to single-agent clopidogrel.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A: Aspirin monotherapy is effective but not as protective as short-course DAPT in the first 3 weeks.
  • Option C: Ticagrelor-based DAPT has inconsistent data and is not standard first-line; 90-day dual therapy extends bleeding risk.
  • Option D: Warfarin is reserved for cardioembolic sources (e.g., atrial fibrillation), not for atherosclerotic TIA.

Key Takeaways:

  • Initiate clopidogrel + aspirin within 24 h of TIA/minor stroke and continue for 21 days, then switch to single antiplatelet.
  • Early aggressive platelet inhibition lowers recurrent stroke risk by ~25-30 % without excess major hemorrhage when limited to this short window.

questions.text: A neonate presented with jaundice. No other findings were present. On doing an USG, a cystic lesion was found adjacent to the common bile duct. The image is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The question describes a neonate with jaundice, and the ultrasound shows a cystic lesion adjacent to the common bile duct (CBD). Based on the image and clinical context, the correct diagnosis is B. Choledochal cyst, specifically Type II.
  • Choledochal cysts are congenital cystic dilations of the biliary tree. The Todani classification is used to categorize them:
    • Type I: Fusiform dilation of the extrahepatic bile duct (most common).
    • Type II: A true diverticulum of the CBD.
    • Type III: Choledochocele (dilation within the duodenal wall).
    • Type IV: Multiple dilations of intra- and extrahepatic bile ducts.
    • Type V: Caroli's disease (intrahepatic ductal dilation).

Why Type II fits this case:

  • Location: The cyst is adjacent to the common bile duct, not within the liver or pancreas.
  • Shape: Appears as a small, saccular outpouching-classic for a diverticulum.
  • Presentation: Neonatal jaundice is a typical presentation.
  • Imaging: The USG shows a cystic lesion projecting from the CBD (pointed by arrows), which is consistent with Type II choledochal cyst.

Reference: https://radiopaedia.org/articles/choledochal-cyst

questions.text: A young man appears irritable, shouts at others, and sometimes experiences episodes of sadness. His predominant mood can best be described as:
questions.solution:
• The patient's emotional state isn't pure sadness (i.e., not just depression).
  • He shows irritability, agitation, verbal aggression, and sadness, which collectively point to dysphoria.
  • Dysphoria is a term often used in mood disorders, substance use, and personality disorders to describe unease, anger, and low mood

Explanation of other options:

choices.text: It is primarily a systemic autoimmune disorder affecting synovial membranes.
It commonly presents with uniform calcification of all loose bodies on imaging.
It is characterized by metaplastic transformation of synovium into cartilage nodules.
Malignant transformation to chondrosarcoma is a frequent complication.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with gradually worsening pain, swelling, and decreased range of motion in his right knee over several months. He denies any history of trauma. On examination, there is joint effusion with crepitus on movement. An X-ray is taken and shown below. Which of the following statements about the likely diagnosis is True?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of gradual knee pain, swelling, decreased range of motion, and X-ray showing multiple intra-articular loose bodies strongly suggest synovial chondromatosis. It is characterized by metaplastic transformation of the synovium into cartilaginous nodules.

Synovial Chondromatosis:

  • A rare synovial proliferative disorder characterized by the formation of multiple loose bodies within a joint. (Option A)
  • Appearance: The loose bodies often form pearly clumps resembling sago ("snowstorm knee")
  • In synovial chondromatosis, the number of loose bodies can exceed 50-60.
  • Primary symptom:
    • Sudden locking of the joint.
    • The patient may be able to feel the loose body within the joint.
    • Joint swelling and pain
    • Restriction of movements.
  • Pathogenesis:
    • Tiny fronds in the synovium undergo cartilage metaplasia at their tips.
    • These tips then break off and may eventually ossify.
  • Radiological Findings:
    • X-ray:
      • Shows multiple loose bodies in the joint.
      • Most loose bodies are radiopaque and visible on plain X-rays.

Explanation of other options:

It commonly presents with uniform calcification of all loose bodies on imaging (Option B): In synovial chondromatosis, the loose bodies often show variable calcification; not all are uniformly calcified, especially in early stages.

Malignant transformation to chondrosarcoma is a frequent complication (Option D): Malignant transformation is rare, not frequent. Though possible, it occurs in a small percentage of long-standing or recurrent cases.

Key Takeaways:

  • Synovial chondromatosis is a rare synovial proliferative disorder marked by cartilage metaplasia of the synovium, leading to the formation of multiple intra-articular loose bodies, often seen as radiopaque densities on X-ray.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old obese woman presents with refractory acne, hirsutism, and a history of acne not responding to isotretinoin and antibiotics. The acne is predominantly located over the lower face and jawline.
What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
The patient's obesity + hirsutism + treatment-resistant acne (especially on the lower face) strongly points to hormonal acne, most commonly due to hyperandrogenism.

  • The patient's acne is not responding to standard treatments (e.g., isotretinoin and antibiotics), which is a sign that the acne might be hormonally driven.
  • The presence of hirsutism, obesity, and acne predominantly on the lower face (U-shape) strongly suggests hormonal acne, which is commonly associated with hyperandrogenism.
  • Hyperandrogenism can be evaluated by testing for elevated levels of androgens such as testosterone, dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (DHEAS), and dihydrotestosterone (DHT), all of which stimulate sebaceous gland activity and sebum production, contributing to acne.
  • Other signs of hyperandrogenism include hirsutism, seborrhea, alopecia, menstrual irregularities, and infertility. Conditions that lead to hyperandrogenism include polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), late-onset congenital adrenal hyperplasia, or, rarely, tumors in the ovaries, adrenal glands, or pituitary.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A. Look for antibiotic resistance: This step is unnecessary given that the acne appears to be hormonally driven and not due to bacterial infection, which would respond to antibiotics.
  • Option B. Look for triggering drugs: Although drug-induced acne can occur, this patient's clinical picture (obesity, hirsutism, lower face acne) points more strongly to a hormonal cause.
  • Option C. Look for dietary triggers: While diet may influence acne, the clinical signs of hirsutism, obesity, and lower face acne suggest a hormonal cause rather than dietary triggers.

Key Takeaway:

  • In cases of acne that do not respond to typical treatments, especially with accompanying signs of hirsutism and obesity, it is important to evaluate for hyperandrogenism.

Common causes of hyperandrogenism in women:

  • Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) - most common
  • Non-classic congenital adrenal hyperplasia
  • Androgen-secreting tumors
  • Cushing's syndrome

questions.text: What is the method of administration of fluid through non compressible venous channels of the body called?
questions.solution:
• Intraosseous fluid administration: Infusion of fluids through a metal cannula into the bone marrow and thence, via a system of non-collapsible veins, into the general circulation. Used in emergencies when intravenous access is not readily available.
  • The upper tibia (anteromedial surface 1-3 cm below the tibial tuberosity) and proximal humerus are the most common sites chosen.
  • A manual needle and trocar kit may be used to pierce the thin bony cortex, advancement continuing until a loss of resistance is felt. Alternatively, a battery-powered drill may be used. Easy injection of saline without obvious subcutaneous infiltration suggests correct placement.
  • Aspiration of marrow is not always possible, but if successful, samples can be used for cross-matching. All standard drugs may be given by this route; they should be flushed through with 5-10 ml saline to ensure they reach the circulation.
  • Complications and limitations: Fluids should be given under pressure to overcome venous resistance. Osteomyelitis is the major complication and can be minimised by sterile technique and by reverting to conventional venous cannulation following resuscitation. Compartment syndrome has been reported.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A: Dialysis is extracorporeal solute clearance, not a vascular access route for resuscitation.
  • Option B: Inhalational anesthetics is the delivery of anesthetic gases via lungs.
  • Option D: Intra-arterial infusion is used for monitoring or specific drug delivery, not for fluid resuscitation.

questions.text: A Pediatric 8 yr old patient presented with GTCS convulsions lasting >45 minutes. What shall be the appropriate management for the patient?
questions.solution:
The child is presenting with status epilepticus, which is defined as any seizure lasting > 30 mins, or multiple seizures occurring without regaining consciousness between episodes.

According to the Indian Academy of Pediatrics (IAP) 2022 guidelines, the first-line treatment for SE is a benzodiazepine, typically Lorazepam, administered immediately to stop the seizure.

If seizures persist, second-line antiepileptic drugs such as Levetiracetam, Phenytoin, or Valproate are given to maintain seizure control.

Management of any child presenting with status epilepticus (IAP 2022 Guidelines) is as follows:

choices.text: As soon as it is diagnosed
Only when malignancy develops in it

questions.text: A 15-year-old phenotypic female presents with amenorrhea. She has poorly developed breast; pubic and axillary hair is normal. Her karyotype is 46, XY, and intra-abdominal testes are identified on imaging. At what point is gonadectomy indicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has a 46 XY karyotype, phenotypic female appearance, primary amenorrhea, poor breast development, normal pubic and axillary hair, and intra-abdominal testes - all features consistent with Swyer syndrome (i.e., 46 XY Complete Gonadal Dysgenesis).

Unlike Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS), where the testes can be retained until after puberty due to low malignancy risk, Swyer syndrome involves non-functional streak gonads, which have a high risk of malignant transformation, especially into gonadoblastoma or dysgerminoma.

In Swyer syndrome, gonads are dysgenetic (streak gonads) and non-hormonally active, hence no estrogen (→ poor breast development) but normal pubic/axillary hair (androgens from adrenals intact).

Because of the high risk of malignancy (15-35%), gonadectomy is indicated as soon as the diagnosis is made.

questions.text: The 'snowman' appearance of the heart on chest x-ray is seen in which congenital heart disease?

questions.text: A mother delivered a 31 weeks old preterm baby, via normal vaginal delivery. He is admitted to NICU with no complications at present. What is the preferred method of feeding this neonate?
questions.solution: Orogastric or nasogastric tube feeding is the preferred method for stable preterm neonates born between 28-31 weeks gestation due to their immature feeding reflexes.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, G2P1, presents to the labor and delivery unit at 39 weeks of gestation in active labor. After spontaneous rupture of membranes, she suddenly develops severe shortness of breath, hypotension, and tachycardia. The fetal heart rate is noted to be decelerating, and the patient becomes unresponsive. Immediate resuscitation is started, and a diagnosis of amniotic fluid embolism (AFE) is suspected. Which of the following laboratory findings is most likely to be elevated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Amniotic fluid embolism (AFE) is a life-threatening obstetric emergency typically occurring during labor or after delivery. It is characterized by the sudden onset of cardiovascular collapse, hypoxia, and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). The clinical signs are often dramatic and may include sudden dyspnea, hypotension, tachycardia, and altered mental status, as seen in this case.

In AFE, the most significant laboratory finding is an elevated D-dimer. This is due to disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), a hallmark of AFE. DIC leads to the widespread activation of coagulation and fibrinolysis, which results in the release of fibrin degradation products, including D-dimer.

Reference: ACOG Practice Bulletin No. 202: Obstetric Care Consensus: Amniotic Fluid Embolism

questions.text: Which one of the following signs differentiates simple pneumothorax from tension pneumothorax?
questions.solution:
Hypotension (hemodynamic instability) is most often seen in tension pneumothorax.

Tension pneumothorax:

  • During inspiration, air is pumped into the pleural cavity through a valvular opening in the visceral pleura and underlying injured lung.
  • Lung collapses first, and as air continuously collects in the pleural cavity, mediastinum shifts towards the opposite side, further decreasing the volume of the functioning lung.
  • Further increase in the pleural pressure, reduces the venous return, atrial filling, and ventricular filling and so cardiac output and cardiac function.
  • Signs and symptoms:
    • Tachypnoea and tachycardia
    • Decreased/absent breath sounds
    • Resonant on percussion with severe mediastinal/tracheal shift
    • Cyanosis and hypotension
    • Chest pain, distended neck veins
  • Management:
    • A wide bore needle is immediately placed in the second intercostal space in the midclavicular line, and a sterile glove is kept on the hub (blunt) end of the needle to create a valve so as to prevent inward sucking of air from outside-thoracocentesis.
    • Nasal oxygen.
    • Intercostal tube is passed (ICT placement).
    • Antibiotic, analgesics are given.
    • In severe cases ventilator support with IPPV is required.

Simple vs tension pneumothorax:

choices.text: Delivery at 37 weeks via cesarean section
Elective cesarean section for both twins
Vaginal delivery with monitoring for second twin after first twin delivery

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents at 37 weeks gestation with a twin pregnancy. The first twin is in cephalic presentation, and the second twin is in breech presentation. What is the best management approach for delivery?
questions.solution:
In a twin pregnancy with the first twin in cephalic presentation, a vaginal delivery can be attempted, and the second twin can be managed after the first twin's birth, even if it is in breech presentation. Close monitoring is required, and delivery is adjusted according to the position of the second twin. If there are signs of fetal distress or complications, cesarean section can be considered.

In a twin pregnancy, the management of delivery largely depends on the presentation of the first twin. In this case:

  • First twin in cephalic presentation: Vaginal delivery is the preferred method of delivery for the first twin.
  • Second twin in breech presentation: While breech presentation may be a concern, it does not necessarily mandate cesarean delivery, especially if the first twin is in cephalic position. Vaginal delivery can proceed with close monitoring of the second twin's position and well-being after the first twin is delivered.

Following the delivery of the first twin, various interventions can be considered, including manual rotation or cesarean section, if necessary, based on the clinical condition of the second twin.

questions.text: Optimal ratio for PRC: FFP: PRP for massive transfusion protocol
questions.solution:
• Severely injured hypovolemic patients should be resuscitated with blood and blood products, not crystalloid/colloid fluids.
  • These must be warmed.
  • All hospitals managing severe trauma should have a massive transfusion protocol which aims to provide blood and blood products in a ratio of 1 packed red cells : 1 fresh frozen plasma : 1 platelet.
  • Massive transfusion involves administering 10 or more units of whole blood or packed red blood cells (PRBCs) within 24 hours.
  • Complications of massive blood transfusion:
    • Hypothermia.
    • Coagulopathy.
    • Acidosis/alkalosis.
    • Hyperkalemia/hypokalemia.
    • Hypocalcemia.
    • Impaired O2- carrying capacity of hemoglobin.
    • Volume overload.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK499929/

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is brought to ER with severe acute chest pain radiating to the back. He is pale and anxious.On examination the blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg and bilateral radial pulses are unequal and he was noted to have blue sclerae. Which of the following conditions has predisposed to this complication?
questions.solution:
• Marfan's syndrome is one of the causes of blue sclerae. The clinical diagnosis is aortic dissection.
  • Disorders predisposing to aortic dissection are: essential hypertension, atherosclerosis, bicuspid aortic valve, connective tissue disorders, Marfan's syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, Adult Polycystic Kidney Disease.
  • Marfan's syndrome is an autosomal dominant connective tissue disorder caused by a defect in the fibrillin-1 gene on chromosome 15.
  • Ghent's Criteria for Marfan's Syndrome:
  • Aortic root dilation (Z-score ≥ 2) and Ectopia lentis (major criteria)
  • Fibrillin-1 mutation or family history (genetic criteria)
  • Systemic score ≥ 7 (features include):
    • Tall stature with arm span to height ratio > 1.05
    • Upper to lower body ratio is decreased (head to symphysis pubis: symphysis pubis to toes).
    • High-arched palate
    • Arachnodactyly
    • Pectus carinatum or excavatum
    • Pes planus
    • Scoliosis of > 20 degrees or spondylolisthesis
    • Dural ectasia (ballooning of the dural sac at the lumbosacral level) - seen in 60% of patients. It may cause lower back pain associated with neurological problems such as bladder and bowel dysfunction like incontinence.
    • Heart - Dilatation of the aortic sinuses (seen in 90%) which may lead to aortic regurgitation, aortic aneurysm, aortic dissection, and mitral valve prolapse (75%) which causes systolic murmur at mitral area.
    • Lungs: repeated pneumothoraxes
    • Eyes: Upwards lens dislocation (supertemporal ectopia lentis), blue sclera, retinal detachment and myopia.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A: Coarctation of the aorta causes upper-limb hypertension with diminished lower-limb pulses, not acute dissection in youth
  • Option B: Ischaemic heart disease predisposes to myocardial infarction, not aortic wall fragility
  • Option C: Rheumatic fever leads to valvular scarring, not medial degeneration of the aorta

questions.text: What is the name of the instrument in the following image?
questions.solution:
• TLD = Thermoluminescent Dosimeter
    • It is a passive radiation monitoring device that measures cumulative exposure to ionizing radiation (like X-rays, gamma rays, and beta particles).
  • How It Works:
    • Contains Thermoluminescent crystals (e.g., Lithium Fluoride, LiF)
    • Radiation exposure traps electrons in the crystal lattice
    • When heated in a TLD reader, these electrons release light proportional to the radiation dose absorbed.


Reference: https://radiopaedia.org/articles/thermoluminescent-dosimeter

questions.text: A patient of schizophrenia was started on an antipsychotic drug. After that he is not able to sit at one place. He keeps on walking and fidgeting his legs while sitting. Which drug can be least associated with these symptoms?
questions.solution:
• A patient with schizophrenia develops inability to sit still, restlessness, and leg fidgeting after starting an antipsychotic.
  • This is classic for akathisia, an extrapyramidal symptom (EPS).
  • Akathisia is a subjective sense of inner restlessness with an objective inability to stay still.
  • Onset: Within days to weeks of starting or increasing dose of antipsychotic.
  • Cause of Akathisia:
    • Dopamine D2 receptor blockade in the nigrostriatal pathway by antipsychotics.
    • Higher risk with high-potency typical antipsychotics.
  • Treatment:
    • First-line: Propranolol (a beta-blocker)
    • Others: Benzodiazepines (e.g., lorazepam); Anticholinergics (less effective for akathisia)

Explanation of other options:

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman, 8 weeks post-total knee replacement (TKR) for severe osteoarthritis, presents with sudden inability to actively extend her right knee following an aggressive physiotherapy session involving forced flexion. X-ray of the knee is taken and is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely complication in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient who recently underwent total knee replacement and now presents with sudden inability to extend the knee following forceful physiotherapy, along with an X-ray showing a high-riding patella (patella alta) and avulsion fragments from the inferior pole, indicates a diagnosis of patellar tendon rupture.

Complications of Total Knee Replacement:

  • Infection:
    • In uncontrolled cases, prosthesis removal and joint fusion may be necessary.
  • Deep Venous Thrombosis (DVT):
    • Occurs due to immobility.
  • Nerve Palsy:
    • Common peroneal nerve palsy may occur, especially with lateral dissection.
    • Most cases recover spontaneously.
  • Fractures:
    • Intraoperative Fractures: Occur during surgery, particularly in osteoporotic bones of rheumatoid patients.
    • Postoperative Fractures: Can occur near the prosthesis due to stress concentration.
  • Extensor Mechanism Complications:
    • May occur due to patellar tendon avulsion or inadvertent cutting during surgery.
    • Intraoperative cause: Injury to patellar tendon fibers during bone cuts.
    • Postoperative causes: Trauma, soft tissue weakening from comorbidities, or infection.
  • Knee Stiffness
    • The patient may have limited range of motion.
    • Causes include heterotopic ossification or intra-articular adhesions.

Explanation of other options:

Prosthetic joint infection (Option B) is unlikely since infections usually present with fever, persistent pain, swelling, redness, and warmth, none of which are described here. Infection rarely causes sudden loss of active knee extension.

Periprosthetic fracture (Option C) does not fit because fractures near the prosthesis typically follow trauma and would be visible on X-ray as fracture lines around the implant. The X-ray here shows patella alta and avulsion fragments rather than a periprosthetic fracture.

Knee stiffness (Option D) generally develops gradually due to fibrosis or adhesions and leads to limited range of motion over time, not a sudden inability to extend the knee. Also, stiffness does not cause the radiological findings seen in this case.

Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6114200/

questions.text: A 35 year old lady with a history of hair dye application presents with the following clinical picture. What is the cause?
questions.solution:
• Hair dye dermatitis is commonly caused by allergic contact dermatitis, often triggered by the ingredients in the hair dye.
  • The most commonly implicated allergen in hair dye-related dermatitis is paraphenylenediamine (PPD), which is a chemical used in many permanent hair dyes. It typically causes contact sensitivity.
  • Symptoms of hair dye dermatitis include erythema, oozing, and ulceration at the scalp margins, ears, face, and neck-areas that come into direct contact with the dye. Other areas may be affected in individuals who do not wear gloves while applying the dye.
  • PPD can cause allergic reactions, ranging from mild to moderate, and is known to be the most common cause of contact sensitivity to hair dyes.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A. Balsam of Peru: This is another allergen associated with contact dermatitis, but it is not the most common cause of hair dye dermatitis.
  • Option C. Pollen: Pollen is a common allergen, but it is not associated with hair dye dermatitis.
  • Option D. Drug intake: While some drugs can cause contact dermatitis, this patient's clinical picture points to a reaction due to the use of hair dye, not drugs.

Key Takeaway:

  • Paraphenylenediamine (PPD) is the primary cause of allergic contact dermatitis related to hair dye use, and it frequently causes reactions at sites of direct contact like the scalp, ears, neck, and face.

questions.text: Local anaesthetics act by blocking sodium channels. Which of the following local anaesthetic has highest cardiotoxicity?
questions.solution:
• Local anesthetics (LAs) act by blocking voltage-gated sodium (NA+) channels, preventing the initiation and propagation of action potentials in neurons. While this is beneficial at the nerve site for pain control, systemic absorption of these drugs can result in toxicity - especially in the CNS and cardiovascular system, both of which also rely on sodium channels.
  • Bupivacaine is the most cardiotoxic among commonly used local anesthetics due to:
    • High lipid solubility and potency, increasing its affinity for cardiac sodium channels
    • Causes ventricular arrhythmias, bradycardia, hypotension, and can even lead to cardiac arrest, especially with inadvertent intravascular injection.
    • It dissociates slowly from cardiac NaNA+ channels, leading to persistent inhibition and arrhythmogenicity.
  • Ropivacaine is a safer alternative, developed to reduce cardiotoxicity. (Option D ruled out)
  • It is the S(-) enantiomer of bupivacaine, offering similar efficacy with less cardiac and CNS toxicity.
  • Lignocaine has low cardiotoxicity and is used therapeutically for ventricular arrhythmias. (Option A ruled out)
  • Prilocaine carries minimal cardiac risk; main toxicity is methemoglobinemia at high doses (Option B ruled out)

choices.text: ORS through cup whatever amount child takes
Fruit juice as child is not accepting ORS

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presented with multiple episodes of loose stools and vomiting since morning. He is thirsty and irritable but does not drink water/ORS and cries when forced to drink water. He has no altered sensorium & passed urine last before 4 hours. Best treatment from the following options is?
questions.solution:
The child shows signs of some dehydration, characterized by thirst and irritability without altered sensorium.

  • According to WHO and IAP guidelines, the management of some dehydration involves oral rehydration therapy using ORS.
  • However, in this case, the child is refusing oral intake, and there is persistent vomiting or poor acceptance of fluids.
  • Therefore, the appropriate route for ORS administration is via nasogastric (NG) tube, which is a safe and effective alternative to maintain hydration when oral intake fails.

Explanation of Other Options:

I.V fluids only (Option A):

  • Reserved for severe dehydration or inability to tolerate oral/NG feeding after a trial.
  • Not the first choice in "some dehydration" unless deterioration occurs.
  • In this case, there is no altered sensorium, which rules out severe dehydration.

ORS through cup whatever amount child takes (Option B):

  • Ideal if the child is willing to drink, but in this case, the child is refusing fluids, making this approach ineffective.

Fruit juice as child is not accepting ORS (Option C):

  • Not recommended. Fruit juices are hyperosmolar and can worsen dehydration by causing osmotic diarrhea.

Key Takeaway:

In a child with some dehydration who refuses to drink ORS, administering ORS via an NG tube is the best next step to prevent progression to severe dehydration.

Reference: IMNCI guidelines for Dehydration

questions.text: A 35-year-old pregnant woman at 39 weeks of gestation presents with severe abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. On examination, the uterus is tender, and fetal heart rate monitoring shows late decelerations. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Abdominal pain + vaginal bleeding after 20 weeks = Antepartum hemorrhage.
  • It can be associated with:
    • Pain
    • Hypertension
    • Tense and tender uterus
    • Increased uterine tone
    • Fetal parts not easily palpable
    • Signs of fetal distress (e.g., late decelerations)

Differential Diagnosis:

  • Placenta previa: ruled out due to the presence of pain and uterine tenderness.
  • Cord prolapse: presents with sudden fetal bradycardia or variable decelerations, not uterine tenderness.
  • Uterine rupture: also causes pain and fetal distress, but typically in a woman with a previous uterine scar. It's also associated with loss of fetal station and easily palpable fetal parts (due to rupture of the uterine wall), which are not mentioned here.

Management:

  • If fetal distress is present: proceed with an emergency cesarean section to save the fetus.
  • If intrauterine fetal demise has occurred:
    • Opt for vaginal delivery.
    • Begin with early artificial rupture of membranes (ARM), followed by oxytocin infusion to induce/augment labor.
    • This is one of the rare cases where early ARM is done despite IUFD, due to the urgency of delivery in abruption.

choices.text: Torsion of testis must be relieved within 6-8 hours of onset of symptoms
At operation, viability of testis is assessed before de rotation
If salvageable, three-point fixation of both testes with absorbable suture is performed

questions.text: All of the following statements are incorrect regarding Torsion of testis except?
questions.solution:
Option A: Testicular torsion is most common in adolescents, but may occur at any age and is usually inside the tunica vaginalis.

Perinatal torsion differs and is usually extravaginal.

Option C: At operation, viability of the testis is assessed after de rotation.

Option D: If salvageable, three-point fixation of both testes with non-absorbable sutures is performed.

choices.text: Assume rifampicin resistance coexisting with isoniazid and start the DOTS plus regimen.
Substitute isoniazid with levofloxacin in category I treatment for 6 months

questions.text: A patient had pulmonary TB and was started on isoniazid, rifampicin, ethambutol and pyrazinamide. A few days later, his DST report showed Isoniazid resistance. Which of the following is the right treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
• For the treatment of patients with isoniazid-resistant disease, the H-mono/poly DR-TB regimen should be commenced. Isoniazid should be replaced by Levofloxacin.
  • The treatment regimen for this patient would be 6 months Lfx, R, E, Z regimen.
  • In patients with extensive disease, extrapulmonary TB or a positive smear at the end of 4th month, treatment is extended for a further 3 months (9 months).

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A: Assuming rifampicin resistance without evidence leads to unnecessary use of second-line agents; the DOTS-Plus MDR regimen is indicated only for confirmed rifampicin- or multidrug-resistant TB.
  • Option B: Continuing a regimen that includes isoniazid despite documented resistance increases the risk of treatment failure and further resistance development.
  • Option D: Failing to modify therapy in the face of isoniazid resistance compromises regimen efficacy and endangers both patient outcomes and public health.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with hirsutism and irregular periods. What is the first-line treatment for managing hirsutism in this patient?
questions.solution:
In women with PCOS, oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are commonly used to treat hirsutism and irregular periods.

OCPs help to regulate menstrual cycles, suppress excessive ovarian androgen production, and reduce adrenal androgen secretion. This leads to improvement in hirsutism and other androgenic symptoms, such as acne. OCPs are particularly useful as they provide both contraceptive benefits and hormonal regulation.

Spironolactone is an anti-androgen that can be used in conjunction with OCPs if additional control of hirsutism is needed.

Finasteride is a 5-alpha reductase inhibitor used for hirsutism, but it is not typically the first-line treatment in this scenario.

GnRH agonists are not the first choice for non-classic CAH. They are usually used in conditions involving central precocious puberty or endometriosis.

questions.text: In patient with ___ % TBSA, inflammatory reaction causes fluid loss in vessels remote from the burn injury
questions.solution:
• The overall effect of these changes is to produce a net flow of water, solutes and proteins from the intravascular to the extravascular space.
  • This flow occurs over the first 36 hours after the injury, but does not include red blood cells.
  • In a small burn, this reaction is small and localised but, as the burn size approaches 10-15% of total body surface area (TBSA), the loss of intravascular fluid can cause a level of circulatory shock.
  • Furthermore, once the area increases to 25% of TBSA, the inflammatory reaction causes fluid loss in vessels remote from the burn injury. This is why such importance is attached to measuring the TBSA involved in any burn.
  • It dictates the size of the inflammatory reaction and therefore the amount of fluid needed to control shock.

Reference: https://journals.lww.com/cmii/fulltext/2021/19020/fluid_resuscitation_in_adult_burns.7.aspx?utm_source

https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1743919108000290?utm_source

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3038406/?utm_source

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman presents with severe, stabbing pain in the right maxillary region, triggered by activities such as chewing and brushing her teeth. The pain is episodic, lasts a few seconds, and is described as electric shock-like. Neurological examination is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate first-line treatment?
questions.solution:
• Carbamazepine is the drug of choice for Trigeminal Neuralgia (). Alternatives for refractory cases include oxcarbazepine, baclofen or surgical microvascular decompression for drug resistant cases.
  • Benztropine - anticholinergic used in parkinsonism/dystonia, not indicated for neuropathic facial pain (Option A ruled out)
  • Diclofenac - NSAID, helps musculoskeletal or inflammatory pain, ineffective for TN. (Option B ruled out)
  • Propranolol - first line in migraine prophylaxis, no role in trigeminal neuralgia. (Option C ruled out)

Key takeaway: Episodic shock like facial pain triggered by chewing/brushing is suggestive of Trigeminal Neuralgia. Carbamazepine is the DOC.

questions.text: A 30-year-old HIV-positive male presents with progressive fatigue and pallor. His hemoglobin is 6.8 g/dL with a very low reticulocyte count. White cell and platelet counts are normal. Bone marrow biopsy shows giant proerythroblasts with intranuclear viral inclusions. Which of the following is the most likely etiological agent?
questions.solution:
Parvovirus B19 infects erythroid precursors and causes pure red cell aplasia, particularly in immunocompromised patients (e.g., HIV, transplant recipients).

  • Patients have persistent anemia with reticulocytopenia
  • Low or absent B19V IgG
  • High serum titers of B19V DNA
  • Bone marrow - scattered giant pronormoblasts
  • Transient neutropenia, lymphopenia, thrombocytopenia, including ITP like presentation.
  • Rarely develops hemophagocytic syndrome

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A: EBV causes infectious mononucleosis; not associated with pure red cell aplasia
  • Option C: CMV affects multiple hematopoietic lineages leading to pancytopenia
  • Option D: HHV 6 - causes roseola infantum; does not target erythroid precursors.

questions.text: Which sinus drainage is blocked in the given image?
questions.solution:
• The maxillary sinuses (inferolateral black cavities) are completely opacified with mucosal thickening/fluid and show a blocked osteomeatal complex-the normal air column in the infundibulum/hiatus semilunaris is absent.
  • Frontal, sphenoid, and ethmoid drainage pathways are aerated on this slice, making their obstruction unlikely. (Option B, C, D ruled out)
  • Maxillary sinus drains through the infundibulum into the middle meatus; obstruction here is the commonest cause of acute sinusitis.
  • CT criteria: soft-tissue density in sinus ± air-fluid level + loss of aerated channel at the ostium.

Reference: https://radiopaedia.org/articles/ostiomeatal-complex

Physiological > Safety > Esteem > Love > Self actualization

questions.text: What is the correct sequence of achieving the needs in humans as per Maslow hierarchy of needs?
questions.solution:
Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs is a psychological theory proposed by Abraham Maslow in 1943, which categorizes human needs into five levels, arranged from the most basic to the most advanced. According to this model, a person must fulfill lower-level needs before progressing to higher-level growth needs.

Here is the correct sequence:

  1. Physiological needs - Basic survival needs such as air, water, food, sleep.
  2. Safety needs - Protection from harm, security, stability.
  3. Love and belongingness needs - Friendship, intimacy, affection, and connection.
  4. Esteem needs - Respect, self-esteem, status, recognition.
  5. Self-actualization - Achieving one's full potential and creative activities.

questions.text: What is the long term complication of this condition?
questions.solution:
• Congenital melanocytic nevus (CMN) is a type of skin lesion present at birth, characterized by benign proliferation of nevomelanocytes (pigment-producing cells).
  • These nevi are generally well-defined, round or ovoid lesions with smooth surfaces, and they appear as brown or black in color. In larger CMNs, there may be irregular borders, variable pigmentation, and nodular or rugous (wrinkled) textures. They may also exhibit pigmented hair growth (hypertrichosis).
  • The long-term complication of giant CMNs (those greater than 20 cm in diameter) is an increased risk of malignant melanoma, a type of skin cancer. This risk is higher compared to smaller CMNs, particularly in the case of giant nevi.

Incorrect Answers:

  • Option B. Cataract: Cataracts refer to clouding of the lens in the eye, and they are not a known complication of CMN.
  • Option C. Glaucoma: Glaucoma is a group of eye conditions that damage the optic nerve, often due to increased pressure in the eye. It is not associated with congenital melanocytic nevi.
  • Option D. Blindness: Blindness can result from various conditions, but it is not a direct long-term complication of congenital melanocytic nevi.

Key Takeaway:

  • Giant congenital melanocytic nevi have a significant long-term risk of developing malignant melanoma, especially when they are large, and require careful monitoring.

questions.text: With reference to sevoflurane, what is the anticipated complication?
questions.solution:
• Sevoflurane undergoes chemical degradation in CO2 absorbents containing strong bases (soda lime, Baralyme), generating Compound A (fluoromethyl-difluoro-trifluoromethyl vinyl ether)
  • Causes renal cortical necrosis at cumulative exposures ≥150 ppm-hours. It is lethal at ≥1000 ppm-hours
  • Preventive measures:
    • Maintain fresh-gas flow ≥2 L/min during sevoflurane anesthesia
    • Replace CO2 absorbent regularly to limit strong-base content.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A: Bone marrow depression is not associated with sevoflurane (seen with chloramphenicol, not inhalational agents)
  • Option C: Hepatitis is linked to older agents (halothane), not to sevoflurane.
  • Option D: Methemoglobinemia is a classic risk with agents like prilocaine and benzocaine, but not with sevoflurane.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with swelling and pain in the left knee joint following a trivial fall. Examination reveals hemarthrosis. There is no history of petechiae or mucosal bleeding. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation is consistent with Hemophilia A (Factor VIII deficiency).

  • Symptoms such as easy bruising, intramuscular hematomas, and hemarthroses begin when the child starts to become more mobile.
  • Bleeding from minor traumatic lacerations of the mouth (a torn frenulum) may persist for hours or days and may cause the parents to seek medical evaluation.
  • Hemarthrosis (bleeding into joints) is the hallmark of hemophilia and often follows minor trauma or can occur spontaneously. The earliest joint bleeds commonly affect the ankles, and in older children, knees and elbows are frequently involved.

Explanation of other options:

Von Willebrand deficiency (Option A):

  • Typically causes mucocutaneous bleeding: epistaxis, gum bleeding, and menorrhagia.
  • Hemarthrosis is not typical of vWD unless it coexists with severe Factor VIII deficiency.

Vitamin K deficiency (Option B):

  • Leads to deficiency of factors II, VII, IX, X (all vitamin K-dependent).
  • Presents more commonly in neonates or children with fat malabsorption, liver disease, or antibiotic use.
  • Hemarthrosis is uncommon.

Thrombocytopenia (Option D):

  • Results in superficial bleeding: petechiae, purpura, and mucosal bleeding.
  • Joint bleeding is not a feature of platelet disorders.

Key Takeaway:

Hemarthrosis (bleeding into joints) after minor trauma is characteristic of hemophilia A, caused by Factor VIII deficiency.

choices.text: Perform amnioinfusion to relieve the cord compression

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents with a diagnosis of cord prolapse after rupture of membranes. The fetal heart rate monitor shows prolonged variable decelerations with bradycardia. What is the most appropriate intervention at this stage?
questions.solution:
Cesarean delivery is the definitive treatment for cord prolapse with fetal distress. It allows for the rapid delivery of the fetus, which relieves pressure on the umbilical cord and improves fetal oxygenation. This is the most appropriate step in this case to prevent fetal hypoxia and potential brain damage.


A) Forceps delivery is not appropriate in the case of cord prolapse, especially with fetal distress. The primary issue is the compression of the umbilical cord, and forceps do not address this problem. A cesarean delivery is required to deliver the fetus quickly and relieve cord compression.

B) Tocolytics (medications used to suppress contractions) are typically used to delay preterm labor, but they are not the solution to cord prolapse with fetal distress. In the setting of fetal bradycardia and prolonged decelerations due to cord compression, cesarean delivery is the most appropriate and urgent intervention.

D) Amnioinfusion involves infusing sterile fluid into the amniotic sac to relieve cord compression by increasing the amount of amniotic fluid. However, this is not a definitive solution for cord prolapse, especially when there is fetal bradycardia and prolonged variable decelerations. Amnioinfusion can be considered in cases of umbilical cord compression with normal fetal heart rate, but in the presence of fetal distress, cesarean delivery is necessary.

Reference: Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists (RCOG) Green-top Guideline No. 56 - "Management of Cord Prolapse"

questions.text: Which strain of the human papillomavirus is responsible for head and neck cancer?
questions.solution:
• The principal aetiological agents are tobacco and alcohol.
  • In Europe and North America this is mainly through cigarette smoking combined with alcohol abuse.
  • Synergism between alcohol abuse and tobacco use in the development of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the head and neck is well established.
  • While the human papillomavirus (HPV; specifically HPV16) is playing a significant role in the increasing incidence of oropharyngeal cancer in resource-rich nations, its role in the oral cavity appears to be limited (<5% of incident tumours being HPV positive) and without clear relevance to outcomes.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female complains of bone pain, The Xray shows presence of Cotton wool skull as shown below, Identify the condition based on the skull radiograph?
questions.solution:
• Paget's Disease of Bone (Osteitis Deformans) is a chronic disorder characterized by disorganized bone remodeling. It commonly affects the skull, spine, pelvis, and long bones. It usually occurs in individuals over 50 years of age.
  • Radiologic Feature: "Cotton Wool Skull"
    • The "cotton wool appearance" on skull X-rays is highly characteristic of Paget's disease.
    • It results from a mixture of lytic and sclerotic lesions due to the abnormal bone remodeling process.
    • These sclerotic patches resemble clumps of cotton, hence the name.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A: Multiple Myeloma - Typically shows punched-out lytic lesions in the skull with no surrounding sclerosis; not a cotton wool pattern.
  • Option C: Hyperparathyroidism - Causes subperiosteal bone resorption, especially in phalanges, and a salt-and-pepper skull on X-ray, not cotton wool.
  • Option D: Craniosynostosis - Refers to premature fusion of cranial sutures in infants/children, leading to abnormal head shapes, not relevant in a 50-year-old adult.

Reference: https://radiopaedia.org/cases/paget-disease-cotton-wool-skull

questions.text: A 38-year-old man with major depression on long-term antidepressants presents with palpitations, blurred vision, urinary hesitancy, and an ECG showing a prolonged PR interval after a suspected overdose. Which antidepressant is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with:

  • Anticholinergic symptoms: blurred vision, urinary retention, palpitations (suggestive of tachycardia or arrhythmia).
  • ECG abnormality: prolonged PR interval.
  • History of overdose: known depression, took multiple pills.
  • These features strongly suggest tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) toxicity.
  • Amoxapine is a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) with additional dopamine-blocking properties (also has antipsychotic effects).
  • TCA overdose classically causes:
    • Anticholinergic symptoms: dry mouth, blurred vision, urinary retention, tachycardia.
    • Cardiotoxicity: ECG changes such as prolonged PR, QRS, and QT intervals; can lead to arrhythmias.
    • CNS effects: seizures, delirium, coma.

Explanation of other options:

  • Sertraline: an SSRI, relatively safe in overdose; rarely causes significant cardiotoxicity.
  • Venlafaxine: SNRI; can cause hypertension and seizures in overdose but less likely to cause anticholinergic or significant ECG changes like TCAs.
  • Bupropion: atypical antidepressant; overdose can cause seizures, but not significant anticholinergic effects or ECG PR prolongation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with chronic knee pain and swelling. Imaging shows a lytic, expansile lesion located in the epiphysis of the distal femur extending to the articular surface, without calcification. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for correct answer:

The clinical presentation of a lytic, expansile lesion in the epiphysis of a long bone, especially around the knee in a young adult, without calcification strongly suggests a giant cell tumor.


Bone Tumor Based on their Location:


Explanation of other options:

Osteosarcoma (Option A) is unlikely because it typically arises in the metaphysis of long bones, not the epiphysis. It usually affects adolescents and shows a mixed lytic-sclerotic appearance with aggressive periosteal reactions like a sunburst pattern or Codman triangle.


Chondrosarcoma (Option B) usually affects older adults, commonly involving the metaphysis or diaphysis. Radiologically, it often shows calcified matrix with ring-and-arc patterns. The lesion in this patient lacks these calcifications and is located in the epiphysis, which is uncharacteristic of chondrosarcoma.


https://radiologyassistant.nl/musculoskeletal/bone-tumors/differential-diagnosis

questions.text:
A 29-year-old male presents with persistent hypertension that remains uncontrolled despite treatment with three different antihypertensive drugs. Laboratory investigations reveal hyperkalemia, mild metabolic acidosis, and suppressed plasma renin and aldosterone levels.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Gordon's syndrome (pseudohypoaldosteronism II) is characterized by:
    • Hypertension
    • Hyperkalemia
    • Mild non-anion gap metabolic acidosis
    • Low plasma renin and aldosterone.

It results from defects in WNK kinases → increased NaCl reabsorption in the distal nephron and reduced K+/H+ secretion.

Explanation of other options:

  • Bartter's syndrome - hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, and elevated renin/aldosterone.
  • Addison's disease - hypotension, high renin and low aldosterone.
  • Conn's syndrome - hypertension, hypokalemia, suppressed renin but elevated aldosterone.

Gordon's syndrome is the only hereditary low-renin hypertension with hyperkalemia and acidosis.

INHERITED RENAL TUBULAR DEFECTS

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with postpartum amenorrhea, an inability to breastfeed, and generalized weakness. Her TSH, prolactin, and cortisol levels are low. Which of the following is the best initial treatment?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests Sheehan syndrome, caused due to ischemic necrosis of pituitary gland, following severe postpartum hemorrhage.

Sheehan syndrome:

  • Precipitating factors: PPH, hypotension, DIC, shock, multiple blood transfusions.
  • Pathophysiology: Increase in anterior pituitary size due to estrogen-induced hyperplasia of lactotrophs → increase in demand of blood supply → massive postpartum hemorrhage → hypoperfusion and infarction of the anterior pituitary.
  • Hormonal profile:
    • Prolactin → low
    • ACTH → low cortisol
    • TSH → secondary hypothyroidism
    • FSH/LH → amenorrhea
    • GH → fatigue, poor quality of life
  • Diagnosis:
    • Clinical suspicion in a postpartum woman with PPH history and typical symptoms.
    • Confirmed by low pituitary hormone levels with corresponding low end-organ hormones.
    • MRI may show an empty sella or atrophied pituitary gland.
  • Management:
    • Acute phase: Prioritize glucocorticoid replacement (e.g., hydrocortisone) to manage adrenal insufficiency.
    • Chronic phase: Lifelong hormone replacement tailored to individual deficiencies (e.g., levothyroxine, estrogen-progesterone, growth hormone).
