questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with chest pain and is thrombolysed for an acute myocardial infarction. His blood pressure was 85/40 for several hours on admission. Two days later his blood tests showed a urea of 140 mg/dl and creatinine of 3 mg/dl (Urea and Electrolytes were normal on admission. What would a renal biopsy show?
questions.solution:
• Diagnosis: Ischemic acute tubular necrosis (ATN)
  • Hypotension-induced ischemia targets the outer medulla (S3 segment of proximal tubule) due to its high metabolic demand.
  • ATN histology shows patchy necrosis and loss of tubular epithelial cells with sloughing into the lumen.
  • Muddy brown granular casts on urine microscopy and rising BUN/Cr 24-48 h post-insult.

Explanation of other options:

Option A) Antibodies against fibrinogen - not involved in ischemic injury

Option B) Thickened glomerular capillary loops - features of membranous nephropathy

Option D) IgG deposition in glomerular capillary loops - characteristic of membranous glomerulopathy


Image: https://webpath.med.utah.edu/RENAHTML/RENAL157.html

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, G2P1, is scheduled for an elective cesarean section due to a history of a previous cesarean delivery. She has a known allergy to penicillin, which causes a severe rash. In light of her allergy, what is the most appropriate antibiotic to administer as prophylaxis for this surgery?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient has a penicillin allergy, which precludes the use of penicillin or cephalosporins for prophylaxis during cesarean delivery. Clindamycin is the recommended alternative, as it provides excellent coverage against Gram-positive cocci (including Streptococcus agalactiae, a common cause of infection in cesarean sections), which are the primary pathogens involved in post-cesarean infections.

A) Metronidazole: While metronidazole is effective against anaerobes, it does not cover the common Gram-positive organisms responsible for cesarean infections, such as Streptococcus and Staphylococcus.

C) Ciprofloxacin: Although ciprofloxacin is a broad-spectrum antibiotic, it is not typically used for prophylaxis in cesarean sections because it has limited activity against Gram-positive organisms. It is more commonly used for urinary tract infections or in cases of suspected resistant Gram-negative organisms.

D) Azithromycin: While azithromycin is an effective antibiotic against a range of organisms, it is not the preferred choice for surgical prophylaxis in cesarean sections, particularly because it does not cover Gram-positive cocci as effectively as clindamycin.

choices.text: DKA increases risk of rhinocerebral mucormycosis.
A high index of suspicion of mucormycosis must be maintained, even in the absence of a known history of diabetes, if hyperglycemia is present.
Hyperglycemia enhances expression of mucorale specific protein mediating cell invasion.
Patients receiving antifungal prophylaxis with either itraconazole or voriconazole may not be at increased risk of mucormycosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true for mucormycosis?
questions.solution:
• Mucormycosis is an acute, angioinvasive infection caused by fungi of the order Mucorales, occurring primarily in immunocompromised or diabetic patients and characterized by rapid tissue necrosis.
    • Itraconazole and voriconazole lack reliable activity against Mucorales; prophylaxis can lead to breakthrough and even disseminated mucormycosis
    • Neither agent chelates iron or corrects acidosis, which remain key drivers of fungal proliferation
  • DKA raises serum iron and acidosis enhances fungal growth - major risk for rhinocerebral disease. (Option A ruled out)
  • Maintain suspicion in any hyperglycemic patient, even without known diabetes. (Option B ruled out)
  • Hyperglycemia upregulates GRP78 on host cells, facilitating Mucorales invasion. (Option C ruled out)

Mucormycosis has also emerged as an important superinfection in COVID-19 patients. This may be attributed to glucocorticoid use in COVID. But even during COVID 19 most of the cases of Mucor in India were unrelated to COVID 19 indicating the high base line cases.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with involuntary leakage of urine when sneezing or coughing. She denies any urgency, nocturia, or dysuria. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Stress urinary incontinence (SUI) is caused by the failure of the urethral sphincter to prevent urine leakage when intra-abdominal pressure increases. This commonly occurs during activities like coughing, sneezing, laughing, or physical exertion. It is typically not associated with urgency, nocturia, or dysuria, distinguishing it from other types of incontinence.

  • First line treatment is pelvic floor muscle training(PFMT) also known as Kegel exercise which is recommended for 3 months under supervision
  • Surgical management is Mid urethral sling procedures like Tension free vaginal tape (TVT), Transobturator Tape (TOT)

questions.text: Egg on side appearance is seen in:
questions.solution:
• The "egg on side" or "egg on a string" appearance on chest X-ray is a classic radiologic sign of Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA) — particularly uncorrected TGA.
  • Radiological Features:
    • The "egg on side" represents a globular, enlarged cardiac silhouette resembling an egg lying on its side.
    • The "string" refers to a narrow superior mediastinum, due to:
      • The anteroposterior alignment of the great vessels.
      • Hypoplasia of the thymus and other mediastinal structures.
  • Why It Occurs in TGA:
    • In TGA, the aorta arises from the right ventricle, and the pulmonary artery arises from the left ventricle (ventriculoarterial discordance).
    • This unusual configuration leads to the narrow mediastinum and ovoid heart shape, due to the transposed and parallel orientation of the great vessels.

TGA - Egg on string/egg on side

Tetralogy of Fallot - Boot shaped heart

Ebstein’s anomaly - Box-shaped Heart

Constrictive pericarditis - Pericardial calcification

TAPVC - Figure of 8/Snowman appearance

Pericardial effusion - Moneybag/leather bottle appearance

Reference: https://radiopaedia.org/articles/egg-on-a-string-sign-heart

questions.text: The drug flibanserin is FDA approved for hypoactive sexual desire disorder in female. It should not be combined with alcohol as it causes:
questions.solution:
Flibanserin is a centrally acting serotonergic agonist/antagonist approved by the FDA for treating hypoactive sexual desire disorder (HSDD) in premenopausal women.

It acts primarily as:

  • 5-HT1A receptor agonist
  • 5-HT2A receptor antagonist
  • Flibanserin must not be used with alcohol because the combination can cause severe hypotension and syncope (fainting) due to its central nervous system and cardiovascular effects.
  • Mechanism behind hypotension:
    • Flibanserin alters central norepinephrine and dopamine tone, and alcohol can potentiate its hypotensive effect by:
      • Vasodilation
      • CNS depression
      • Impaired baroreflex response

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A: Hypertension is opposite of the observed effect.
  • Option B: Severe myalgia is not a known interaction or side effect.
  • Option D: QT prolongation is not a risk with Flibanserin.

questions.text: A 75 year old patient presents with this lesion over face. Histopathology shows peripheral palisading cells. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
• Basal cell carcinoma is the most common skin cancer and develops directly without any precancerous lesion.
  • Histologically, it features nests of basaloid cells, peripheral palisading nuclei, and retraction clefts between tumor nests and stroma
  • Clinical features:
    • Slow growing, often over years
    • Locally aggressive with destruction growth
    • Metastasis is rare (<1%), typically to regional lymph nodes.

Related important points and concepts:

  • Molecular pathogenesis: Aberrant Hedgehog pathway (e.g., PTCH1 mutations in Gorlin syndrome)
  • Treatment options: Surgical excision, Mohs micrographic surgery, topical 5-FU or imiquimod, and Hedgehog inhibitors (vismodegib, sonidegib)

Explanation of other options:

questions.text:
6-year-old child presents with chronic diarrhea, abdominal distension, poor weight gain, and fatigue. On examination, he has pallor and wasting. PEDIATRICS 6 Blood tests show:
1.Hemoglobin: 8.5 g/dL
2.MCV: 70 fL
3.Serum ferritin: Low
4.Anti-tTG IgA: Strongly positive
5.Anti-Endomysial Antibodies: Positive
The physician advises dietary modification to manage the condition.
Which of the following foods should be avoided to prevent worsening of the child's symptoms?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation-chronic diarrhea, abdominal distension, poor weight gain, fatigue, and microcytic anemia with low serum ferritin-along with strongly positive anti-tTG IgA and anti-endomysial antibodies, is diagnostic of Celiac Disease.

Celiac disease is a chronic autoimmune condition triggered by the ingestion of gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye. Gluten ingestion in affected individuals leads to small intestinal mucosal damage and subsequent malabsorption.

Semolina (Suji) is made from wheat and contains gluten, which must be avoided to prevent intestinal damage and symptom exacerbation.

  • Grains unsafe to eat in Celiac Disease- Contain gluten. (Mnemonic is BROW)
    • Barley
    • Rye
    • Oats
    • Wheat, including whole wheat & semolina (suji/rava)
  • Grains safe to eat in Celiac Disease- Do not contain gluten. Includes
    • Rice, including Puffed Rice like Poha (Option D ruled out)
    • Maize
    • Quinoa (Option A ruled out)
    • Sorghum (Option B ruled out)
    • Chia Seeds
    • Flax Seeds
    • Tapioca

GCS= 8.

Left pupil: 6 mm and non-reactive → Unreactive = 1 point

Right pupil: 3 mm and reactive → Reactive = 0 points

GCS-P score = 8-1 =7.

Pupils unreactive to light:

  • Both pupils: Score 2
  • One pupil: Score 1
  • Neither: 0

Secretion is stimulated by low 1,25-hydroxyvitamin D and inhibited by high levels of 1,25-hydroxyvitamin D

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding parathyroid hormone (PTH)?
questions.solution:
PTH, an 84-amino-acid peptide synthesized and secreted by the parathyroid gland, is a potent regulator of the serum calcium level.

  • Vitamin D (1,25-hydroxyvitamin D):
    • Elevated 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D affects PTH synthesis and secretion by directly inhibiting the parathyroid gland and indirectly via hypercalcemia. Low levels of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D have the opposite effect.
  • Calcium: (Option A ruled out)
    • Hypocalcemia - strongest acute stimulus for PTH release.
    • Hypercalcemia - inhibits PTH secretion
  • Phosphate: (Option B ruled out)
    • Elevated serum phosphate indirectly stimulates PTH (by lowering free Ca2+ and via direct effects on parathyroid cells).
    • Hypophosphatemia does not significantly drive PTH secretion.
  • Magnesium: (Option C ruled out)
    • Hypomagnesemia - inhibits PTH secretion so its effects are not the same as calcium.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with primary amenorrhea and absent secondary sexual characteristics despite having a normal karyotype (46, XY). Physical examination reveals a short vagina and absence of a uterus. Serum testosterone levels are elevated, and she has normal external female genitalia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The most likely diagnosis is Complete Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (CAIS). It is caused by mutations in the androgen receptor (AR) gene, leading to complete resistance to androgens like testosterone.
  • Individuals have a 46, XY karyotype with testes (often undescended) that produce testosterone and anti-Mullerian hormone, causing regression of the uterus and fallopian tubes and resulting in a short vagina. Despite elevated testosterone, the body cannot respond (d/t defective AR), so they develop normal external female genitalia, primary amenorrhea, and absent secondary sexual characteristics.

Explanation of Other Options:

Turner Syndrome (option B): Characterized by short stature, streak ovaries, and a 45, XO karyotype with features such as webbed neck and cardiac abnormalities.

5-alpha-reductase deficiency (option D): Characterized by a partial inability to convert testosterone into dihydrotestosterone (DHT), which results in ambiguous genitalia at birth, but affected individuals will often have some degree of masculinization, unlike CAIS. The affected individuals are genetically male (46, XY) with a normal male internal reproductive tract.

questions.text: What is the type of choledochal cyst shown in the image below as per Todani classification?
questions.solution:
• Choledochal cysts are cystic dilations of the CBD.
  • They have an incidence of 1 in 100,000 to 150,000 live births, with a 3 to 4 : 1 female-to-male preponderance.
  • They are classified on the basis of location, and their frequency varies.
    • Type I (50%-80%) is a simple cyst that can involve any portion of the CBD.
    • Type II (2%) describes a diverticulum arising off the CBD.
    • Choledochoceles represent type III cysts (1.4%-4.5%) and consist of dilation confined to the distal intrapancreatic portion of the CBD.
    • Type IV (15%-35%) involves intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts.
    • Type V (20%) is limited to the intrahepatic ducts only.
  • Choledochal cysts can be associated with other congenital anomalies, including
    • Duodenal and colonic atresia
    • Imperforate anus
    • Pancreatic arteriovenous malformation.
    • Pancreatic divisum.
  • Choledochal cysts are considered premalignant lesions.

Todani classification of choledochal cysts:

choices.text: He had primary hyperparathyroidism, cured by surgery
Urinary calcium excretion is typically elevated
The condition follows autosomal dominant inheritance
Acute pancreatitis is a frequent complication

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man is found to have hypercalcemia with serum calcium of 12.5 mg/dL. His 24-hour urinary calcium excretion is 12 mg. He is asymptomatic and has no history of nephrolithiasis, fractures, or pancreatitis. He underwent parathyroidectomy, but his calcium levels remain elevated post-operatively.
Which of the following is true about the likely underlying condition?
questions.solution:
The scenario suggests familial hypocalciuric hypercalcaemia (FHH) due to persistent hypercalcemia with hypocalciuria post parathyroidectomy.

  • It has an autosomal-dominant pattern of inheritance with virtually complete penetrance.
  • Suspected in PTH-dependent hypercalcemia with low urinary calcium excretion (24 h urine Ca < 100 mg/day or urine Ca/creatinine ratio < 0.01)
  • Inactivating CaSR mutation reduces receptor sensitivity to calcium, causing increased renal calcium reabsorption in the loop of Henle.
  • Heterozygotes are usually asymptomatic; homozygotes present with severe neonatal hypercalcemia requiring parathyroidectomy
  • A very small subset of adult heterozygotes may develop recurrent pancreatitis and occasionally require parathyroidectomy.

Explanation of other options:

Option A) Primary hyperparathyroidism is cured by parathyroidectomy, unlike FHH.

Option B) FHH features hypocalciuria, not elevated urinary calcium.

Option D) Pancreatitis is uncommon in FHH.

questions.text: An X-ray chest showing globular cardiomegaly with oligemic lung fields in a cyanotic child is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
Ebstein's Anomaly - Explanation:

  • It is a congenital malformation of the tricuspid valve where the valve is displaced downward into the right ventricle, creating an "atrialized" portion of the RV.
  • This results in massive right atrial enlargement, which on X-ray appears as globular cardiomegaly.
  • Because of tricuspid regurgitation and right heart dysfunction, there is reduced pulmonary blood flow - seen as oligemic lung fields.
  • Cyanosis results from a right-to-left shunt, often through a patent foramen ovale (PFO) or atrial septal defect (ASD).

Key findings on chest X-ray:

  • Globular cardiomegaly: Indicates an enlarged, balloon-shaped heart.
  • Oligemic lung fields: Reduced vascular markings in the lungs, suggesting decreased pulmonary blood flow.
  • Cyanotic child: Suggests a congenital heart disease with right-to-left shunt or low pulmonary blood flow.

Explanation of other option:

  • Option A: Persistent Truncus Arteriosus usually causes increased pulmonary blood flow (plethoric lung fields) due to a single outflow tract and large left-to-right shunt.
  • Option B: TAPVC (Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection) - typically shows pulmonary plethora and snowman appearance in supracardiac type.
  • Option D: TGA (Transposition of Great Arteries) - may show "egg on side" appearance and increased or normal pulmonary vascularity, depending on associated defect.

CXR Comparison Table of Cyanotic CHDs


Reference: https://radiopaedia.org/articles/ebstein-anomaly

questions.text: A 35 year old woman presented with excessive hairfall. She has recently started treatment for breast cancer. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Anagen effluvium is rapid hair loss that occurs days to weeks after cytotoxic chemotherapy disrupts the mitotic activity of hair matrix cells during the anagen (growth) phase
  • Hair typically regrows within months after chemotherapy cessation
  • Cooling caps and dose modification may reduce severity

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A: Telogen effluvium: Involves excessive shedding of hairs in the telogen (resting) phase 2-3 months after a stressor (eg:- postpartum, stress); more gradual onset.
  • Option B: Alopecia totalis: An autoimmune condition causing complete scalp hair loss over weeks to months, not linked to chemotherapy.
  • Option D: Androgenetic alopecia: Patterned hair thinning over years due to genetic and hormonal factors; not acute or diffuse.

questions.text: The ultrasound image below shows the pectoralis major muscle (pink), the axillary artery (red), vein (blue), and a cluster of hypoechoic structures (yellow) immediately lateral to the artery. Which brachial plexus block is being performed?
questions.solution:
• In the infraclavicular block, the ultrasound probe is placed below the clavicle and lateral to the pectoralis major, visualizing the brachial plexus cords (cluster of grapes) surrounding the axillary artery.
  • The interscalene and supraclavicular approaches image the plexus higher in the neck, above the clavicle. (Option A & B ruled out)

Ultrasound interscalene block imaging


Ultrasound supraclavicular block imaging

  • The axillary block images the plexus at the level of the axilla, where the artery and plexus lie more superficially and are not under pectoralis major. (Option D ruled out)

Ultrasound-guided axillary block image

Key Takeaways:

questions.text: A 10-year-old child visits with generalized oedema for the last 3 days. He has proteinuria 4+ in urine routine with no haematuria. Previous history of 2 similar episodes were noted. You suspect Nephrotic syndrome in the child. Which drug would you prefer initially in the treatment?
questions.solution:
Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by heavy proteinuria, defined as >3.5 g/24 hours or a urine protein:creatinine ratio >2. The classic clinical triad includes:

  • Hypoalbuminemia (serum albumin ≤2.5 g/dL)
  • Generalized edema
  • Hyperlipidemia (cholesterol >200 mg/dL)

The most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children is Minimal Change Disease. Initial treatment involves prednisone or prednisolone, given as a single daily dose of 60 mg/m²/day or 2 mg/kg/day (maximum 60 mg/day) for 4-6 weeks. This is followed by alternate-day prednisone at 40 mg/m² or 1.5 mg/kg every other day for an additional 4-6 weeks.

Explanation of Other Options:

Cyclosporine (Option A):

  • Cyclosporine is an immunosuppressant used in cases of steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome or infrequent relapsing nephrotic syndrome but is not the initial treatment.

Cyclophosphamide (Option C):

  • Cyclophosphamide is used for steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome or frequent relapsers, but it is not the first-line therapy in newly diagnosed cases.

Methotrexate (Option D):

  • Methotrexate is not used for treating nephrotic syndrome. It is an immunosuppressive drug primarily used in conditions like rheumatoid arthritis and cancer.

Key Takeaway:

Prednisolone is the first-line treatment for minimal change disease (MCNS), the most common form of nephrotic syndrome in children.

questions.text: Identify the type of procedure done for pilonidal sinus from the given figure
questions.solution:
Surgical procedures for pilonidal sinus:

  • Options include laying open of all tracks with or without marsupialisation, excision of all tracks with or without primary closure and excision of all tracks with closure by some other means designed to avoid a midline wound (Limberg procedure, Z-plasty, Karydakis procedure).
  • Karydakis excision through a semi lateral incision and lateralized suturing of the wound away from the midline gives good result.
  • Excision with closure using Limberg (Rhomboid) buttock flap (single or double rhomboid flaps)-good result
  • Bascom's procedure involves an incision lateral to the midline to gain access to the sinus cavity, which is rid of hair and granulation tissue), and excision and closure of the midline pits. The lateral wound is left open to heal secondarily.
  • Failure to heal or recurrence is treated by a fap or cleft lift procedure, also described by Bascom.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male presents with fatigue, skin pigmentation, arthralgia, and new-onset diabetes mellitus. Laboratory tests reveal elevated serum ferritin and transferrin saturation. Liver biopsy shows iron deposition in hepatocytes. His younger brother has also been recently diagnosed with liver cirrhosis and diabetes.

What is the most likely mode of inheritance of this condition?
questions.solution:
Familial clustering of symptomatic iron overload (hepatic cirrhosis, "bronze diabetes," arthropathy) with onset in adulthood is characteristic of HFE-related hereditary hemochromatosis.

  • Haemochromatosis: features
    • Haemochromatosis is an autosomal recessive disorder of iron absorption and metabolism resulting in iron accumulation. It is caused most commonly by inheritance of mutations in the HFE gene on both copies of chromosome 6.
  • Epidemiology
    • 1 in 10 people of European descent carry a mutation gene affecting iron metabolism, mainly HFE
    • prevalence in people of European descent = 1 in 200
  • Clinical features
    • early symptoms include fatigue, erectile dysfunction and arthralgia (often of the hands)
    • 'bronze' skin pigmentation
    • diabetes mellitus
    • liver: stigmata of chronic liver disease, hepatomegaly, cirrhosis, hepatocellular deposition)
    • cardiac failure (2° to dilated cardiomyopathy)
    • hypogonadism (2° to cirrhosis and pituitary dysfunction - hypogonadotropic hypogonadism)
    • arthritis (especially of the hands)

questions.text:
Which of the following are associated with skin disease shown in the image?


1. Polycystic ovary disease
2. Obesity
3. Oral Contraceptive pills
4. Hemochromatosis
5. Addison's disease
questions.solution:
• Acanthosis nigricans presents as velvety, hyperpigmented plaques most commonly in flexures (neck, axillae, groin) due to epidermal hyperplasia and papillomatosis
  • It is a cutaneous marker of insulin resistance; associated conditions include:
    • Polycystic ovary disease (hyperinsulinemia stimulates keratinocyte proliferation)
    • Obesity (insulin resistance)
    • Oral contraceptive pills (can worsen insulin sensitivity)
  • Other associations: Type 2 diabetes, Cushing's syndrome, metabolic syndrome, certain malignancies (Gastric adenocarcinoma), nicotinic acid therapy
  • Histopathology of acanthosis nigricans classically shows hyperkeratosis and epidermal papillomatosis.

Explanation of other options:

  • Hemochromatosis causes generalized bronze hyperpigmentation, not velvety plaques
  • Addison's disease causes diffuse mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation from increased ACTH, not localized papillary proliferation

questions.text: During TLH for a large uterus, the surgeon encounters difficulty dissecting the uterine artery near the ureter. Postoperatively, the patient presents with abdominal distension and reduced urine output. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
When postoperative signs such as abdominal distension and reduced urine output are present, CT urogram is the investigation of choice because it provides detailed imaging of the ureter, detecting site and extent of injury, obstruction, or urine extravasation.

Ureteric injury is a significant risk during total laparoscopic hysterectomy (TLH), especially when dissection is difficult near the uterine artery, where the ureter runs close by. Risk factors include prior pelvic surgery, endometriosis, adhesions, large uterus and distorted anatomy.

The most common sites of ureteral injury in gynecologic surgery are:

  1. At the cardinal ligament, where the ureter passes beneath the uterine vessels
  2. Near the infundibulopelvic (IP) ligament
  3. Along the uterosacral ligament
  4. At the anterior vaginal wall

Explanation of Other Options:

Renal function tests (Option A): While renal function tests (e.g., serum creatinine) are useful for assessing overall kidney function, they do not provide anatomical details of ureteric injury or obstruction. They may be elevated in the case of ureteric obstruction but are not diagnostic for identifying the location or cause of the injury.

Intravenous pyelogram (IVP) (Option B): This older imaging modality involves injecting contrast dye and obtaining X-rays to visualize the urinary tract. It has been largely replaced by CT urograms, which offer superior anatomical resolution.

Pelvic ultrasound (Option C): This can detect secondary signs like hydronephrosis or fluid collections, but it lacks the detail needed to accurately identify ureteric injuries or localize the obstruction.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3410510/

ACOG: Management of Complications in Minimally Invasive Gynecologic Surgery, 2021

questions.text: A 28 year old male presented with multiple perianal lesions as shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Condyloma acuminata are anogenital warts caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) types 6 and 11, presenting as soft, pedunculated or papillary verrucous lesions in moist intertriginous skin.
  • Transmission: Sexual contact; incubation 1-6 months
  • Treatment: Topical podophyllotoxin, imiquimod, cryotherapy, surgical excision, or laser ablation
  • Prevention: HPV vaccination (covers types 6/11)

Explanation of other options:

(Option A) Condyloma lata: Flat-topped, smooth, velvety, moist papules of secondary syphilis; serology positive (RPR/VDRL)


(Option D) Hemorrhoids: Vascular cushions presenting as bluish, compressible swellings in the anal canal, not papillomatous skin lesions.


(Option C) Bowen's disease: Squamous cell carcinoma in situ presents as well-demarcated, erythematous scaly plaques, not papillary warts.

Key Takeaways:


  • Anogenital warts with a cauliflower-like or papillary surface in the perianal region = condyloma acuminata.
  • Confirm with HPV typing if needed and manage with lesion-directed and patient-applied therapies.

choices.text: Drain the hematoma and suture the bleeding vessel
Start intravenous antibiotics and provide analgesia

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida presents with severe perineal pain and swelling 8 hours after a normal vaginal delivery with episiotomy. On examination, a tender, bluish, firm swelling measuring 6 cm is observed at the episiotomy site. The patient is hemodynamically stable but reports increasing discomfort. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
The postpartum patient presenting with severe perineal pain and a tender, firm, bluish swelling measuring 6 cm at the episiotomy site is characteristic of a vulvar (infralevator) hematoma. Given the size (>5 cm) and severity of symptoms, the next best step is prompt surgical drainage of the hematoma and ligation of the bleeding vessel.

Pelvic Hematoma:

A pelvic hematoma is a collection of blood in the area between the pelvic peritoneum and the perineal skin. When located below the levator ani muscle, it is termed an infralevator hematoma, which commonly manifests as a vulvar hematoma.

Types of Pelvic Hematomas:

  • Infralevator Hematoma (common): Occurs below the levator ani, most commonly presenting as vulvar hematomas.
  • Supralevator Hematoma (rare): Occurs above the levator ani, often related to deeper pelvic structures or uterine rupture.

Infralevator (Vulvar) Hematoma:

Etiology:

  • Improper hemostasis during repair of vaginal or perineal tears or episiotomy.
  • Rupture of the paravaginal venous plexus, either spontaneously or after instrumental delivery.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Symptoms: Severe, persistent perineal pain, and swelling at the vulva, which may extend to the ischiorectal fossa causing rectal tenesmus or urinary retention.
  • Signs:
    • Tender, tense, firm swelling with bluish or dusky purple discoloration at the episiotomy site or vulva.
    • Rectal tenesmus or urinary retention if hematoma extends into ischiorectal fossa.
    • Possible signs of shock if bleeding is significant.

Management:

  • Small hematomas (<5 cm): Conservative treatment with cold compresses and close monitoring. (Option A ruled out)
  • Large or symptomatic hematomas (>5 cm) require prompt surgical exploration under general anesthesia, evacuation of clots, identification and ligation of bleeding vessels, and obliteration of dead space with deep mattress sutures to prevent re-accumulation.
  • A closed suction drain may be placed for 24 hours to prevent re-accumulation of blood, and a Foley catheter is inserted to relieve urinary retention and reduce local tissue edema.
  • Supportive care: Administer prophylactic antibiotics to prevent infection, provide adequate analgesia, and initiate resuscitative measures (e.g., fluid or blood transfusion) if there is hemodynamic instability. (Options C & D ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following is false about acute intermittent porphyria (AIP)?
questions.solution:
• Acute intermittent porphyria (AIP) is an autosomal dominant hepatic porphyria resulting from half-normal level of HMB-synthase activity.
  • AIP is especially common in Scandinavia & Great Britain. (Option C ruled out)
  • AIP is almost always latent before puberty. (Option D ruled out)
  • Defect in porphobilinogen deaminase, an enzyme involved in the biosynthesis of haem.
  • Presentation: severe abdominal pain, neuropsychiatric symptoms (delirium), dark urine on standing.
  • Acute precipitants: certain drugs (sulfonamides, barbiturates, phenytoin), fasting, infection, hormonal changes
  • Urinary porphobilinogen assay is the optimal way to establish the diagnosis.

Lab features:

Hyponatraemia, Mild Leukocytosis.

Treatment of seizures in AIP = Gabapentin


Treatment:

Glucose and heme, which inhibit delta-aminolevulinic acid synthase, thereby decreasing heme precursor synthesis.

  • The treatment of choice in acute porphyria is intravenous haem arginate.
  • High-glucose diets or infusions have been used for mild attacks of pain without neurological symptoms.

Topic: Occipitoposterior position

choices.text: Perform a lower segment cesarean section (LSCS)
Attempt manual rotation of the fetus

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents in labor at 40 weeks of gestation. The fetus is in the occipitoposterior (OP) position. After 4 hours of pushing, the fetal heart rate shows decelerations, and the presenting part remains high. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This case represents a prolonged second stage of labor complicated by fetal distress due to a persistent occipitoposterior (OP) fetal position. Prolonged pushing without descent and fetal heart rate decelerations indicate fetal compromise and failure to progress. The most appropriate management is a lower segment cesarean section (LSCS), as continuing vaginal delivery or attempting operative vaginal delivery carries significant risks of trauma and poor outcomes for both mother and fetus.

Attempt manual rotation of the fetus (Option B): It is inappropriate here because manual rotation is only considered when there is no fetal distress and the fetal head is low and engaged. In this case, the head is still high and there are signs of fetal compromise, so attempting rotation would be unsafe and unlikely to succeed.

Continue with vaginal delivery attempt (Option C): It is not recommended because the failure of descent after 4 hours of pushing, alongside fetal heart rate decelerations, represents a failed trial of labor. Further attempts risk exacerbating fetal compromise and increasing maternal morbidity.

Proceed to vacuum-assisted delivery (Option D): It is contraindicated here because vacuum delivery is only performed when the fetal head is low (usually at +2 station or more) and in the absence of fetal malposition and distress. Given that the presenting part is still high and the position is OP, attempting vacuum extraction would be dangerous.

questions.text: Which among the following diseases uses the rule of goodsalls for clinical assessment?
questions.solution:
• A fistula-in-ano, or anal fistula, is a chronic abnormal communication extending from the anorectal lumen (the internal opening) to an external opening on the skin of the perineum or buttock (or rarely, in women, to the vagina).
  • The majority are idiopathic or cryptoglandular and are lined by granulation tissue.
  • Anal fistula may be found in association with Crohn's disease, tuberculosis, lymphogranuloma venereum, actinomycosis, rectal duplication, foreign body and malignancy (which may also very rarely arise within a longstanding fistula).
  • Classification (Park's classification):
    • Intersphincteric (most common)
    • Transsphincteric
    • Supralevator/suprasphincteric
    • Extrasphincteric
  • Goodsall's rule:
    • Fistulas with an external opening in relation to the anterior half of the anus are of direct type.
    • Fistulas with external openings in relation to the posterior half of the anus, has a curved track may be of horse-shoe type, opens in the midline posteriorly and may present with multiple external openings all connected to a single internal opening.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man with a 20-year history of COPD presents with worsening dyspnea, increased sputum volume, and purulence. He is afebrile, and examination reveals wheezing and use of accessory muscles. Sputum culture is planned.

Which of the following organisms is least likely to be a cause of his acute exacerbation?
questions.solution:
• S. aureus is an uncommon cause in stable outpatients; it typically appears in severe disease, post-influenza, or in hospitalized patients with invasive devices

Bacteria that frequently implicated in COPD exacerbations include:

  • Haemophilus Influenzae (Option B ruled out)
  • Moraxella Catarrhalis (Option C ruled out)
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (Option A ruled out)
  • Chlamydia pneumonia

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with postmenopausal bleeding and a Pap smear showing atypical glandular cells. What is the next most appropriate management step?
questions.solution:
• In a postmenopausal woman with bleeding and a Pap smear showing atypical glandular cells (AGC), there is significant concern for underlying cervical or endometrial adenocarcinoma. 
  • The most appropriate next step is endocervical curettage (ECC), which enables tissue sampling from the endocervical canal-an area often involved in glandular neoplasia and not fully accessible by cytology or colposcopy alone. ECC is essential for detecting premalignant or malignant lesions that may not be visible on examination.

Explanation of Other Options:

Repeat Pap smear (Option A): It is not the appropriate next step because AGC warrants further investigation to rule out malignancy, not just observation.

Colposcopy (Option B): It evaluates squamous lesions of the ectocervix and transformation zone but cannot adequately assess glandular abnormalities higher in the endocervical canal. Therefore, in a woman with atypical glandular cells on Pap smear, endocervical curettage is the necessary next step to obtain tissue and rule out malignancy before or alongside colposcopy.

HPV testing (Option D): Useful in cases of squamous abnormalities but does not provide enough diagnostic value when glandular abnormalities like AGC are present.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common type of malignant anal cancer?
questions.solution:
• Anal malignancy is rare and accounts for less than 2% of all large bowel cancers.
  • The crude incidence rate is 0.65 per 100,000 in the UK.
  • The male-to-female ratio is approximately 1:2.
  • The great majority are SCCs.
  • Those arising below the dentate line are usually keratinising, whereas those above are non- keratinising squamous, variously termed basaloid, cloacogenic or transitional.
  • There is now broad consensus that both are similar in their presentation and response to treatment and should be treated as carcinomas whether keratinising or not.
  • Adenocarcinomas are the next most common and are thought to arise from anal glands.
  • Other tumours include melanoma, lymphoma, sarcoma and tumours of perianal skin.
  • Clinical features: Mass, bleeding.
  • IOC: Biopsy. (MRI for local staging).
  • Nigro regime:
    • Combined chemoradiation (Radiotherapy + 5-fluorouracil + mitomycin-C).
    • Administered 1 month prior to surgery.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents with polyuria and polydipsia. Two months earlier, she sustained a minor head injury but had a normal CT brain. She also has a history of recurrent pyelonephritis.

A water deprivation test is performed with the following results:

Water Deprivation Phase:
1. Plasma osmolality: 295 mOsm/kg (Normal: 275-295)
2. Urine osmolality: 220 mOsm/kg

After Desmopressin (2 μg):
1. Plasma osmolality: 300 mOsm/kg
2. Urine osmolality: 250 mOsm/kg

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Nephrogenic DI is characterized by resistance of the renal tubules to vasopressin: urine osmolality remains low (< 300 mOsm/kg) during water deprivation and fails to concentrate significantly (< 10% rise) after desmopressin
  • History of recurrent pyelonephritis suggests renal tubular scarring contributing to nephrogenic DI
  • Normal plasma osmolality with inappropriately dilute urine confirms DI rather than primary polydipsia

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A: Psychogenic polydipsia: would have low plasma osmolality and improve urine concentration during deprivation
  • Option B: Cranial DI: marked rise in urine osmolality (> 50%) after desmopressin
  • Option C: Partial cranial DI: intermediate response (10-50% rise) to desmopressin, unlike the minimal change seen here

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents with tall stature, small testes, and infertility. Chromosomal analysis reveals the presence of an additional X chromosome. Based on the given scenario, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the given scenario, the patient is diagnosed with Klinefelter syndrome, a chromosomal disorder in males caused by an extra X chromosome (47,XXY). It is characterized by:

  • Tall stature
  • Small testes
  • Infertility due to hypogonadism
  • Additional findings may include gynecomastia, reduced muscle mass, and learning difficulties.

Explanation of Other Options:

Turner's syndrome (Option A): Occurs in females with a missing or structurally altered X chromosome (karyotype 45, X). It is characterized by short stature, infertility, webbed neck, and other physical anomalies. This condition does not occur in males.

Down syndrome (Option C): Caused by trisomy 21 (karyotype 47, XX/XY, +21). It typically presents with intellectual disability, characteristic facial features, and developmental delays, which are not consistent with the patient's presentation.


Prader-Willi syndrome (Option D): Results from loss of paternal chromosome 15. It is characterized by hypotonia, hyperphagia causing obesity, developmental delay, and intellectual disability. Unlike Klinefelter syndrome, it does not feature tall stature, small testes, or infertility as hallmark findings.

questions.text: A woman presents with a history of recurrent spontaneous abortions. Which of the following investigations is least appropriate in the evaluation of recurrent pregnancy loss?
questions.solution:
• Recurrent spontaneous abortion (RSA) is defined as ≥ 2 consecutive losses before 20 weeks of gestation.
  • Evaluation focuses on identifying treatable causes, including anatomical, genetic, hormonal, and immunological factors.
  • TORCH infections are not established causes of RSA and are more associated with sporadic miscarriages or congenital anomalies. Routine TORCH testing is not recommended due to low diagnostic yield and limited impact on management.

questions.text: Miami criteria is for
questions.solution:
The Miami Protocol is used during parathyroid surgery to confirm whether the hyperfunctioning parathyroid gland(s) has been successfully removed - by measuring parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels intraoperatively. (PTH has a short half-life of 3-5 minutes).

A drop in the PTH into the normal range and to less than half the maximum preoperative PTH at 10 minutes appears to accurately predict single-gland disease.

Demyelination of the right optic nerve and multiple demyelinating plaques in brain and spinal cord
Space-occupying lesion in the occipital lobe

questions.text:
33-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of intermittent neurological symptoms. She initially developed blurring of vision in the right eye, which worsens after a hot shower. She now reports intermittent electric shock-like sensations radiating down her spine and into both legs, especially on neck flexion.

Examination reveals:
1. Right eye: Afferent pupillary defect, pale optic disc
2. Lower limbs: Spasticity, hyperreflexia, and bilateral extensor plantar responses

Which of the following findings is most likely on MRI of the brain and spinal cord?
questions.solution:
• The combination of optic neuritis (worsening vision with heat, afferent pupillary defect) and Lhermitte's sign (electric shock sensation on neck flexion) indicates multiple sclerosis (MS)
  • MRI in MS shows T2 hyperintense, ovoid plaques in periventricular white matter, spinal cord lesions, and optic nerve involvement
  • UMN signs: spasticity, hyperreflexia, and bilateral extensor plantar responses.
  • Cranial nerve symptoms: Optic neuritis, Facial palsy with sparing of taste sensation in anterior 2/3rd of tongue, gaze disturbances like INO, one and a half syndrome, 6th nerve palsy, pendular nystagmus.

Related important points and concepts:

  • Uhthoff's phenomenon: transient worsening of symptoms with increased body temperature (hot shower)
  • Lhermitte's sign: electric shock sensation with neck flexion, due to cervical cord demyelination.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A: Chronic infarct would produce fixed deficits without heat sensitivity or Lhermitte's sign.
  • Option C: Diffuse meningeal enhancement suggests meningitis, not demyelinating disease.
  • Option D: Occipital mass - causes focal signs (e.g., visual field defects) rather than multifocal, transient symptoms

choices.text: Seen in elderly women of child bearing age
Present in pancreatic body or tail

questions.text: Which among the following statements is false for mucinous cystic neoplasms of pancreas?
questions.solution:
Mucinous cystic neoplasms:

  • Frequently seen in young women, mean age 5th decade. (Option B)
  • More common in the body & tail of the pancreas (Option D)
  • MCNs contain mucin-producing epithelium, macrocystic
  • Histology: Presence of mucin-rich cells and ovarian-like stroma
  • Estrogen & progesterone staining are positive in most cases
  • Up to 50% of patients present with vague abdominal pain.
  • A history of pancreatitis may be found in up to 20% of patients, which explains the common misdiagnosis of pseudocyst.

Diagnosis

  • CT scan: Presence of a solitary cyst with fine septations & rim of calcification (Option C)
  • Cross-sectional imaging may not be able to distinguish between benign and malignant MCNs
  • Presence of eggshell calcification, larger tumor size, or a mural nodule on cross-sectional imaging is suggestive of malignancy. (Option A)
  • Cyst fluid analyses: Mucin-rich aspirate, high CEA & low amylase levels

Treatment

  • Surgical excision is indicated for all mucinous cystic neoplasm
  • Pancreatic resection is the standard treatment.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man is being evaluated for an ischemic stroke. He reports a long-standing history of burning pain in both feet, which began in his late teens. Family history is notable for early deaths from renal disease.

On physical examination, which of the following findings is most likely?
questions.solution:
• This young man's combination of early onset ischemic stroke, long standing history of burning neuropathic pain in his feet, and a family history of fatal renal disease strongly suggests Fabry's disease - an X linked lysosomal storage disorder due to α-galactosidase A deficiency.
  • Angiokeratoma's are the classic cutaneous hallmark: clusters of dark red to blue black, non-blanching papules most prominent between the umbilicus and knees.
  • Other features are hypohidrosis, vascular diseases of the heart, kidneys and brain. Lenticular and corneal opacities may also be seen.

Xanthomas, Central obesity occur in familial dyslipidemias that can also cause stroke in young. But here there is a history of burning paresthesias due to peripheral neuropathy which is seen in Fabry's disease. (Options A,B,C ruled out)

questions.text: All electrolyte abnormalities are seen in immediate postoperative period except:
questions.solution:
Option D: Following surgery there will be shifting of fluid into extracellular space seen that leads to Hypernatremia.

Option A: Due to increased catabolism in response to surgical stress there will be Negative nitrogen balance occuring.

Option B: There is frequently shifting of potassium into cells as well as losses occur in postoperative period that leads to hypokalemia.

Option C: Following surgical stress there will be increased glucose production but decreased glucose utilization at tissue level due to insulin resistance, that leads to glucose intolerance.

choices.text: They return to normal within 24-48 hours after myocardial infarction
Are seen in patients with NSTEMI
Can be used to distinguish Non-Q from Q MI

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true of raised cardiac troponin levels in the blood?
questions.solution:
• Troponin elevations occur in both NSTEMI and STEMI but are normal in stable or unstable angina.
  • The most sensitive markers of myocardial cell damage are the cardiac troponins T and I. Troponins are regulatory elements of the contractile apparatus in muscle. They are released within 4-6 hours and remain elevated for up to two weeks. (Option B ruled out)
  • Cardioversion can give rise to raised creatine kinase (CK) levels due to skeletal muscle damage and mildly raised troponins in a very small share of patients. (Option A ruled out)
  • Troponin levels reflect myocyte necrosis and cannot differentiate between a Q-wave and non Q-wave MI. They are electrocardiographic diagnoses. Myocarditis or Myocardial contusion can also cause raised troponin levels. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Partial closure of nasal orifice done in which condition?
questions.solution:
Partial closure of the nasal orifice (called Young's operation) is a therapeutic procedure used in Atrophic rhinitis to:

  • Reduce airflow through the nasal cavity
  • Prevent drying of the already atrophic mucosa
  • Allow the mucosa to heal and crusts to reduce

Atrophic Rhinitis:


Explanation of Other Options:

Rhinoscleroma (Option B): A chronic granulomatous infection caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, leading to nasal obstruction due to granuloma formation and fibrosis. It is treated with Antibiotics like streptomycin, tetracycline, rifampicin and ciprofloxacin along with steroids for 4-6 weeks

Hypertrophic rhinitis (Option C): Characterized by thickened, swollen nasal mucosa causing nasal obstruction, often due to chronic inflammation or allergies. Treatment involves decongestants, steroids, and sometimes surgery (like turbinate reduction)

Fungal mucormycosis (Option D): A serious, rapidly progressive fungal infection affecting nasal and sinus tissues, often in immunocompromised patients. Treatment involves urgent antifungal therapy and aggressive surgical debridement, not nasal closure.

choices.text: Inactivates the HPV virus by neutralizing its ability to enter host cells
Stimulates an immune response to produce antibodies against HPV's L1 protein
Inhibits HPV DNA replication within infected cells
Alters the host genome to prevent the integration of HPV DNA

questions.text: The HPV vaccine prevents cervical cancer by targeting specific viral components. Which of the following best describes the mechanism by which the HPV vaccine works to prevent cervical cancer?
questions.solution:
• HPV vaccines contain virus-like particles (VLPs) made from the L1 protein, the major capsid protein of HPV.
  • These VLPs do not contain viral DNA and are therefore non-infectious.
  • When administered, they stimulate the immune system to produce neutralizing antibodies specifically against the L1 protein. These antibodies recognize and bind to the virus during any future exposures, preventing it from entering and infecting host cells.
  • The vaccine does not directly neutralize active virus particles or alter the host genome. Instead, it prevents initial infection by eliciting a protective immune response.

Types of HPV Vaccines:

  • Cervarix (bivalent): HPV 16 and 18
  • Gardasil (quadrivalent): HPV 6, 11, 16, and 18
  • Gardasil 9 (nonavalent): HPV 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58

Schedule:


Reference:

Human Papillomavirus (HPV) Vaccines - NCI
